PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 139 citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace located in Klaipeda, Lithuania, was the only Church built in Lithuania after World War II;
(2) This Church was closed by the Soviet authorities on 15 August 1960 and confiscated in 1961 under the direct order of Mr Khrushchev.

Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs to raise with its counterpart in the USSR the great concern of many Australians that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the religious worshippers of Klaipeda in Lithuania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLAREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 43 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony, M.P.-

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony, M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75 per cent and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chipp I present the following petition from 47 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens in Victoria showeth:
That at a general meeting concern was expressed as to the necessity to retain the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous institution.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you would make note of the following resolution passed at a public meeting held in Melbourne on 12th August 1981:

We request that the Federal Government continue funding the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous specialist institution recognizing that it is unique in its capacity to serve the needs of the early childhood field in Victoria and throughout Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REID

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 23 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as 'Australian Soldier' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939- 45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BOLKUS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 15 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That since 1788 discrimination has existed in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference;

That since 1788 such discrimination has been accepted and promoted by Australian laws and practices, particularly in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be immediately formulated and passed through the Parliament to render unlawful discrimination in all areas over which the Commonwealth holds power, namely, in employment of all persons in the Commonwealth Public Service and employed in Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and other bodies, in the provision of accommodation and the provision of goods and services under Commonwealth jurisdiction and also in all areas over which legislation for the Australian Capital Territory would be valid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MASON

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chipp I present the following petition from 19 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation.
We agree that:
(1) PVR will aggravate the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding .
(2) PVR will not enhance Australia's access to improved plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
(3) PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
(4) PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interest not responsible to the Australian people.
(5) The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that parliament:
(1) refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR,
(2) calls for a public inquiry into the impact of existing overseas PVR schemes on the Australian seed industry and the international seed trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TEAGUE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 295 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown,
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or by marriage
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purposes for our nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Ryan I present the following petition from 205 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women, in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 11 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australian respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 140 citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Federal Government of Australia discriminates against Croatian migrants in Australia the target of combined Yugoslav and Australian security operations with the express purpose of discrediting the movement for Croatian independence and statehood, and that in so doing it is aiding and abetting the Yugoslav regime in the sentencing and imprisonment of Croatian intellectuals, students and priests and ordinary people in the thousands, the imprisonment of more than two thousand Albanians as a result of the uprising in Kosovo at the beginning of this year, and the murder by Yugoslav Secret Police of more than 70 Croats in Western Europe in the past few years.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate urge the Government that diplomatic relations with Yugoslavia be called into question and discontinued as a sign of protest, and that Australia ask the United Nations General Assembly to supervise a referendum whereby the constituent nations of the so-called federation of Yugoslavia vote on the question of secession.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 48 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aformentioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 10 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That public respect for the Government and the institution of Parliament is diminished by the non-disclosure of pecuniary interests of Ministers of the Government.

That on 2 August 1979, the Minister for Communications announced through the Parliamentary Press Gallery that he had agreed to repay in 3 instalments of $100 ,000 at 10 per cent interest the sum of $300,000 which had been misappropriated.

Your petitioners call upon the Senate to take steps to implement the recommendations on disclosure of the Joint Committee on Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament, 1975, agreed to by Committee members of all political parties.

In particular, your petitioners call upon the Senate to restore respect for the Parliamentary system by seeking a declaration from the Minister for Communications as to whether he has made the $100,000 repayment due on 1 February 1982.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That the right to work without discrimination on any ground including, inter alia, discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, pregnancy, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference is a fundamental human right; and

That it is both the duty and responsibility of society to fully support those denied work and therefore those who are unemployed as a result of society's inability to provide full paid employment should be guaranteed an adequate income without discrimination on any ground, including inter alia discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, or pregnancy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate and adequate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, in employment of individuals under federal awards, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws by formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Our complete opposition to any stage of the Nuclear Industry. We wish to inform you of our support for Union bans aimed against the uranium industry. We look towards a society that respects life, opposes violence, and recognises our total dependence on our global ecosystem.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament take action to halt the mining, milling and export of Australian uranium and put people before profit.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

We wish it to be stopped immediately and a ban put on all seal products coming into Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown,
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation

(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purposes for our nation.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the shortage of staff members in the Department of Social Security has resulted in poor service to clients and delays in payment of benefits.
That the recent standdowns of staff of the Department of Social Security have exacerbated the above situation and caused undue hardship to pensioners and beneficiaries.
Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
(1) Staffing levels in the Department be increased to a level acceptable to staff members.
(2) The Government demonstrate its concern for clients by rescinding the standdowns and allowing staff back to work with no loss of salary.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed hydro-electric developments in South-West Tasmania.

Your petitioners call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate or allow funds to be raised for construction of dams in the South-West of Tasmania but to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national asset and Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Laws Relating to Sexual Offences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, Canberra the humble petition of the undersigned members or organisations listed below and citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That current laws relating to sexual offences against women are discriminatory against all women, and in particular against married women; and that current laws relating to sexual offences are ineffective and inadequate to protect married and unmarried women; and that we believe that both married and unmarried women should be effectively and adequately protected by law against sexual abuse .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That laws relating to sexual offences against women must be redefined to include all forms of sexual abuse against married and unmarried women, including all forms of coercion-physical, psychological, exploitative, extortionary and authority-based, and including sexual harrassment in any form, particularly at work and in educational institutions.

That evidence laws applicable generally to assault crimes must be acknowledged as applicable to sexual offences and the rules relating to corroboration in assault crimes must be made applicable to sexual offences.

That laws must be reformed so that accused persons are not entitled to abuse the criminal justice system; and furthermore laws must be revised to give greater protection to the victim and to minimise her distress.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the introduction of the Plant Variety Rights Act.

Your petitioners call upon the Federal Parliament not to pass this Act because of the chemical company interests in plant breeding, the rigorous uniformity of crop varieties demanded by PVR, and the effect this may have on the vulnerability of these crops to pest and disease attack.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are opposed at the introduction of the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on a wide range of goods previously exempt. Consumers will be forced to pay higher prices and manufacturers will be faced with falling sales. The new taxes will particularly hit the building industry following rises in interest rates, and the Government's failure to revitalise the Home Savings Grant Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Import of Seal Products
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the continued slaughter of baby seals off the coast of Newfoundland and urge that you, (a) ban the import of goods made from these skins, (b) take immediate measures to have this appalling practice stopped.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free State: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that your petitioners seek you to take immediate measures to make Victoria a Nuclear Free State.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Youth Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia showeth that whereas a pilot program of emergency accommodation for young people ends in June 1982, many young people continue to be at risk in our local communities through lack of adequate housing and support.
We therefore pray that funds be made available to continue and extend the services available through the Youth Accommodation Services Program/Youth Services Program/Youth Services Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Sessional Orders relating to the precedence of Government and General Business and the consideration of Government reports be amended to read as follows:
Government and General Business-Precedence

On all sitting days of the Senate, unless otherwise ordered, Government Business shall take precedence of General Business, except that General Business shall take precedence of Government Business on Thursdays, after 4.30 p.m.; and that, unless otherwise ordered, General Orders of the Day shall take precedence of General Notices of Motion on alternate Thursdays.
Consideration of Government Papers

(1) That, unless otherwise ordered and notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, on Thursdays no petitions may be presented, and, prior to Formal Motions, Papers may be presented by Ministers. Upon the presentation of such papers a Senator may move, without notice, that the Senate take note of one , or several, of the papers. Senators may not speak to any such motion for more than ten minutes, and the consideration of any such motion shall be interrupted after the expiration of 90 minutes or at 1.00 p.m., whichever is the earlier.

(2) Provided that, if the consideration of all such motions has not extended for 90 minutes at 1.00 p.m., debate on any such motion interrupted at 1.00 p.m. may be continued at 4.30 p.m., and further such motions may be moved and debated , and such debate shall take precedence of other General Business until the consideration of all such motions has extended for 90 minutes, or until there is no further debate.

(3) Where debates on motions moved under the provisions of this Sessional Order are adjourned and are called on in the normal course of business, Senators who have spoken to the questions under the provisions of this Sessional Order may again speak for the time allowed under Standing Order 407A.
I seek leave to make a short statement on this matter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the motion is to vary the sessional orders to allow for the new sitting hours.

SPEECH.PARA: Although I give notice of the amendments today I do not propose that the motion be dealt with until next week. As Estimates committees are meeting tomorrow, there is not a requirement for the matter to be resolved this week.

Since it is proposed to list the Standing Orders Committee report for next Tuesday, I suggest that it may be more convenient for the Senate to resolve these sessional orders directly after the consideration of the Standing Orders Committee report.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Mason having given notice of a motion-
Senator Hamer-I raise a point of order. I understand that the honourable senator has just given notice of a motion that is already on the Notice Paper.
Senator Peter Baume-It is identical to a motion already before the Senate.
Senator Mason-It is not identical.
Senator Peter Baume-As you read it out, it is identical.
Senator Mason-Senator, have you forgotten the Moreton Island incident? Mr President, may I speak to the point of order?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask Senator Mason to present the notice to the table so that it can be checked.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Mason-I have presented the notice to the table. May I speak to the point of order?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Mason to hold his point of order until such time as we have checked the notice with the one on the Notice Paper.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Mason-Indeed. Mr President, you will find that it is not identical.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason, I have been informed by the Clerks, after doing a check, that the terms of this matter are substantially the same as those in a notice already on the Notice Paper and as such it could not be accepted as a notice of motion.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Mason-May I speak to the point of order, Mr President? There is a point of order before us, I take it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I will hear Senator Mason on the point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Mason-Mr President, you may recall that rather earlier a matter was raised concerning motions to introduce a Bill into this place concerning Moreton Island. At that stage I was Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats and I raised that matter with you and with the Standing Orders Committee. The reply I got was that it was perfectly in order, and completely in accord with parliamentary tradition elsewhere in the world and in this place, for a motion to be repeated. The situation is that this motion is similar in its terms to a motion in the names of Senator Hamer and Senator Peter Rae, which has been on the Notice Paper since 4 December 1980. For one reason or another it has not proceeded. The Australian Democrats would like to see it proceed. That is the reason I brought forward this motion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason, if you wish to go any further with it I suggest you write to the Standing Orders Committee. This chamber can interpret and apply the Standing Orders only as they exist at present.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Mason-Thank you, Mr President. I shall take that course of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What arrangements are made for Customs clearances when the Prime Minister, using his Boeing 707, flies directly into Canberra from overseas? What arrangements were made when the Prime Minister returned to Canberra after attending the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting in New Delhi in September 1980? Did any members of the Prime Minister's party or members of the media travelling with him declare any goods for inspection? Were those declarations made by members of the media or by members of the Prime Minister's personal staff, or both?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first point, the Government has arranged, at the Prime Minister's instance, that a Customs officer shall be in attendance to undertake the normal Customs procedures when persons enter Australia by VIP aircraft-for example, landing at Fairbairn. The understanding has been given to all persons so travelling that they will be cleared by Customs at that point. Senator Button raised matters concerning specific journeys. I have no specific knowledge of those, but I will refer them to the Prime Minister and seek an answer for him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs recall my asking her a question on 11 March 1982, recorded on page 692 of Senate Hansard, referring to a statement made by the Premier of Queensland, the Honourable Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, alleging that six Aborigines are presently in Libya undergoing guerrilla and terrorist training? I ask the Minister whether she is also aware of an answer I received from the Minister for Foreign Affairs in which he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Yes, I am aware of the article referred to by the honourable Senator. I am advised that inquiries conducted by my Department and other relevant authorities have produced no evidence to verify that Aboriginals are currently undergoing guerrilla or terrorist training in Libya.

Will the Minister convey this information to the Premier of Queensland and seek from him an assurance that he will desist from making these untruthful statements which denigrate Aboriginals and show us in a bad light?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do recall the question that was raised on this matter. I am not sure whether I was advised that the response had been given in the form that Senator Bonner has outlined. However I will draw the matter to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and ask him to note Senator Bonner's suggestion. No doubt if the Minister for Foreign Affairs considers it appropriate he will make some further comment, either publicly or privately, to Senator Bonner.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs: Is it a fact that an investigation was conducted by the Internal Affairs Unit of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs by a former senior officer of the Australian Federal Police who was seconded for that purpose, into the matters concerning the clearance of a colour television set through Sydney Airport by Mr MacKellar? If this is so, why was not that officer' s report included in the documents tabled yesterday in this chamber? Were the results of that report acted upon?
—I have no information on the matter which is now raised by Senator Grimes. I undertake to raise the matter with my colleague Mr Brown and obtain a reply for him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Have the severe backlogs reported last year in the connection of telephones in Queensland country areas and provincial cities been overcome? Is the Minister aware that the number of unsatisfied installations in Gladstone alone was estimated to be 500? Are adequate resources being devoted to this matter so that these fast growing, highly taxed areas, such as Gladstone are not disadvantaged?

—I am aware that Senator MacGibbon represents the very decentralised State of Queensland. I am also aware that he has a concern for the rights of those residents of non-metropolitan Australia who wish to have access to services at the same level and to the same extent as those who live in the major cities. To that extent I understand his concern that the people of Gladstone may experience some delay with telephone installations. At the moment it is not possible to advise him whether the figures he gives as to the extent of the backlogs are correct. But I am aware, as he indicated in his question, that Gladstone is the site of considerable development at the present time and that this would put some strain upon the resources available and the facilities and infrastructure. I will undertake to obtain facts about telephone installations, waiting times and other problems in this area in Gladstone and make them available to the honourable senator.

—Did the Minister for National Development and Energy note statements in yesterday's Australian to the effect that a Sydney University research team is attempting to see that a highly successful new form of solar collector developed there is actually manufactured in Australia? Is the Minister aware that what could have been a lucrative export market has already been prejudiced by allowing the situation to drift to the extent that these devices are being made under licence in Japan where they are being sold at the rate of a thousand a week? What action is the Minister's energy division taking to see that manufacture of such solar collectors for Australian use is carried out in Australia? Does the Government not yet see the need for adequate taxation incentives, such as those applying in the United States of America, Japan and New Zealand, amongst other countries, to promote such alternative energy and conservational practices, or does the Government not yet appreciate the fact that based on overseas experience such incentives actually save money by promoting more employment and additional tax revenues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw mention of this matter in the Australian yesterday. I have not had time to check the precise details. I will do so and relate to the earlier parts of Senator Mason's question in that regard when the information is fully available to me. The fact is that in Australia there is a viable solar energy manufacturing industry. Indeed it is so viable that we do export and sell solar arrays to places such as California. So there has been no reason to suggest that taxation or other incentives are not adequate enough to allow such a manufacturing industry. We are keen to do so. However, since the matter also concerns perhaps one or two other departments in terms of manufacturing, I will get the whole matter looked at and give Senator Mason a more detailed reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General in his capacity both as Attorney-General and as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to remarks by a Mr Don Stevens, Brisbane Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia , on the possibility of employment of women wharf labourers, 50 of the applications for 35 vacancies in Queensland having come from women? For the benefit of the Senate I will quote Mr Stevens's attitude on this subject. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The blokes have already decided that if women are put on, they must wear skirts at all times, go down to the ships' holds first and that the men come up last.

Can the Minister confirm whether any trade union has the ability to make any such decision, unrelated as it is to the requirements of the job? Will the Minister make it clear to the Waterside Workers Federation and the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour that Mr Stevens's grossly offensive and sexist requirements on employment of women are totally unacceptable in this country? If there is any evidence either that women withdraw their applications for these jobs on the Brisbane wharves for fear of humiliation as a result of the repugnant attitudes of Mr Stevens and his ilk, or that the women applicants are not seriously considered for any of these vacancies because of fear by employers that Waterside Workers Federation members would attempt to put unreasonable or humiliating conditions on their employment, will the Government urgently consider its powers and obligations to prevent such discriminatory attitudes affecting anyone's employment prospects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Martin drew my attention to the comments of Mr Stevens to which she refers. Of course, we have only the authority of the newspaper report about them. It may be that Mr Stevens does not take such extremely sexist views, which I am sure would be disapproved of by members of the Senate generally as well as by Senator Martin. It is an interesting development that with changes in the nature of the work force, the nature of work, mechanisation and so on, it does not seem to be unreasonable to expect that women may well work in the stevedoring industry on the wharves, which traditionally has clearly been an area where they have not been so engaged. With the sorts of changes that are occurring one must be prepared to accept that these things are likely to occur. It is unfortunately true that there has been a great deal of resistance to this development in parts of the trade union movement, so it is perhaps understandable that some views of that kind may still be prevalent although I agree that that is to be regretted.

ANSWER.PARA: The immediate method of resolving these problems is to go through the employment discrimination committees. They are part of a tripartite organisation which has been established in each State throughout Australia. They provide the avenue for attempts to settle any disputes of this kind. Anyone who felt that they had been discriminated against by either an employer or a trade union leader would, I believe, have the opportunity of taking that matter to those committees. In some States also, of course, antidiscrimination legislation may be applicable. As the Senate would know and as I have said on a number of occasions the Commonwealth Government is in close discussion with the States at present about the ratification of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women entered into in Copenhagen in 1980. As I have said, there are a number of ways in which people in such a situation-in this case women who felt that they were being discriminated against-could have avenues through which they could pursue the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to you, Mr President. I seek information on the number of citizens who have petitioned the Senate opposing the introduction of legislation for the introduction of plant breeders rights-plant variety rights-in Australia. Would it also be possible to ascertain the same information from the other place?
—I will take note of Senator Hearn's question and respond duly at a later date.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry to the Government's assistance scheme to eradicate bovine brucellosis and tuberculosis in Australian herds. I understand that over $250m has been spent by the pastoral industry in Australia in an effort to attain this goal by 1984. Bearing in mind the fact that the Government has so far met 7 per cent of its original commitment of 15 per cent of the cost of the program, will the Minister advise the Senate what plans are proposed to bring the program to a conclusion and, as it appears necessary, to extend the program beyond its present 1984 completion date to bring about the eradication and the essential control of bovine brucellosis and tuberculosis in Australia?

—The national program against brucellosis and tuberculosis commenced in 1970. The volume of money that the Commonwealth has paid to this point-some $32.6m-is about 12 per cent of the cost of the campaign. The figure about which we are talking was mentioned by the Industries Assistance Commission in its 1975 report and was arrived at by costing the Commission's recommended assistance and expressing it as a percentage of campaign costs estimated at that time. The Government recently considered a further IAC report on Commonwealth financial assistance after 1984. Not only did it accept the IAC's recommendations in full but also it agreed to provide additional loan funds where required by the States for compensation for reinfected herds. The provision of continued Commonwealth financial assistance after June 1984 is conditional on all States and the Northern Territory undertaking to adopt a program to achieve Australia-wide freedom from brucellosis and tuberculosis.
—Mr President, I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—I table the document.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether he has seen an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, the leading sentence of which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: The much discussed coal boom was finally buried at the third Australian Coal Conference on the Queensland Gold Coast yesterday.

Although I believe that that sentence is far too gloomy, as the tone of the meeting was set by Australia's leading institutional investors and bankers- namely, the AMP Society and the Bank of New South Wales-I ask: What representations have been received by the Minister or the Government concerning the imposition of a new coal export duty on steaming coal and concerning the concept of coal export duties generally? Do those representations indicate that the imposing of such levies has an adverse effect on the confidence of investors and producers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the article. The fact is that bodies such as the International Energy Agency had seen that the free world's consumption and export of coal would double in the next 10 years. That has been revised downwards to about 60 per cent. It was seen that Australia would increase its production of steaming coal, which was in the order of only 6 million tonnes a year, to about 100 million tonnes a year in a decade or more. I do not know what the present revision is. The fact is that a number of factors are slowing down the development but, as Senator Tate quite rightly says, are not in any way causing cessation. The present and very temporary oil glut has caused some cessation of the urgency to change to alternative fuels. Therefore, there has not been the movement of oil to coal at the rate one would have expected.

ANSWER.PARA: That article, if my memory serves me well, and other comments in the newspaper referred not only to the export levy but also specifically to charges and taxes which States have put upon coal. I thought the purport of the article was that governments and each of the spheres of government-Federal, State and local-have been putting burdens on the coal industry which were heavier than they might ordinarily bear. That is as I understand the situation. Against that background, I believe that there have been some representations from coal interests to suggest that the export levy should be removed or abated. I am not specific on this matter. I believe that in my presence I have had such representations around the Cabinet table. I do not recall the specific times. I know that the industry has been opposed to the levy. I will look towards the more recent specifics and will let Senator Tate know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Treasurer agree that the development of the new Australian film industry has been one of the most dramatic cultural events in our history? Have recent Australian films done a great deal to enhance our image overseas? In view of the extraordinary range of estimates of the costs to the community of support for the film industry-more than $100m a year has been mentioned-can the Minister give an estimate of the costs to revenue of the tax assistance for the film industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the development in the Australian film industry which I think has enhanced Australia's image overseas and also within our own country in the production of many excellent films recently. I understand that about $24m may be the cost for the income year 1980-81. As I understand it, the level of production this year is broadly at the same level as the previous year. It may be that a higher proportion of that will be eligible for income tax concession. This would mean that there may be a slightly higher cost to revenue in the next year. In the Budget of this year, we included a figure of about $20m with an amount of $5m which was in respect of the deductions that might be claimed for the 1980-81 year. I will have a check made through the Treasurer's office with regard to these figures. As I understand it, on the information available-this is perhaps drawn largely from a report that was made to a film industry body-about $24m would be the level, which will perhaps be slightly higher in the next year.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. It concerns the case of an unemployed school leaver who was rejected for a job under the Special Youth Employment Training Program because he had not been registered as unemployed for four months but, in fact, had been out of work since leaving school and had only just registered and was not accepting benefits. In addition to Press coverage of this young man's unfortunate dealings with the Commonwealth Employment Service, the Minister recently announced a national promotion of the Special Youth Employment Training Program this month within the Commonwealth Employment Service and agencies. I ask the Minister: In order to prevent further discrimination and bureaucratic bungling will he, firstly, immediately remedy the conflicting and confusing statements in the Adelaide Press by the Commonwealth Employment Service and his Department as to what constitutes 'employed' within the Special Youth Employment Training Program guidelines on eligibility? Secondly, as a matter of urgency, will he give an assurance to facilitate standard policy and practice whereby those unemployed, registered or not, are guaranteed equal rights of access to job vacancies and employment programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will draw the Minister's attention to the particular case that was mentioned by Senator Elstob. I agree with him that it would be unfortunate if someone who had not been drawing unemployment benefit but was unemployed was not able to enter a training program that would give him a wider eligibility for employment. As far as conflicting statements in the Press are concerned, I will draw that aspect to the Minister's attention to see whether he feels that some public statement would be appropriate. I will also draw his attention to the suggestion with regard to standard policy and practice . I hope that the objective throughout the Commonwealth Employment Service is to have the administration of programs at a standard and at an understandable level . If matters which arise from this question result in some further changes I will see that the Senate is advised about that. I am sure that the Minister will appreciate that the spirit in which the question was asked was to enable us to assist as many young people as possible to enter the training programs and to benefit from them.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has his attention been drawn to newspaper reports this morning stating that as a result of strike action by 12 sewerage workers-members of the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia-the Bolivar treatment works near Adelaide were closed and millions of gallons of raw sewage poured into St Vincent Gulf? I understand that from Monday afternoon until yesterday some 140 million litres of untreated sewage was discharged into the sea. Does the Minister recognise that this industrial action can cause severe health problems and that the South Australian Health Commission warned people not to swim near the area and suggested also that this could seriously endanger juvenile fish stock which breed in the area and which are vital to the South Australian fishing industry? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the progress of this morning's talks on this dispute? I understand that these workers were making extra claims on a recently granted Federal wages and conditions package. Can the Minister indicate what action the Government intends to take to ensure that the situation is swiftly resolved and the outfall of raw sewage is prevented in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate of some background information in regard to the matter raised by Senator Jessop. About a dozen Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association members employed at the Bolivar treatment works stopped work at 5 p.m. on Monday this week in support of claims which included seven weeks annual leave and other things. The workers concerned are State Government employees covered under the federal engine drivers and firemens general award. They recently received substantial benefit from the agreement of the Government of South Australia to flow on to its Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association members the settlement reached in the metal trades industries. The agreement was ratified earlier this year by the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It should be noted that the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association undertook to make no additional claims for the 12-month duration of the agreement. Of course, we now have a small group of members in violation of that undertaking.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the workers returned to work on Tuesday afternoon. However, during the period of the stoppage, as Senator Jessop said, sewage was discharged into St Vincent Gulf. The matter has come before Commissioner Turbet of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Inspections, I understand, have taken place at the Bolivar treatment works. I am not able to advise the Senate any further in relation to what has been the outcome of the inspections. I will refer the matter back to the Minister for Industrial Relations and ask him to keep me informed so that I can answer further questions as to any developments that Senator Jessop is interested in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—Yes.

—My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate is simply this: If the Government has nothing more to hide in relation to the MacKellar-Moore affair why has it rejected the Opposition's call for an independent judicial inquiry into all unresolved aspects of the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, yesterday the Prime Minister and the Government indicated that the Government was concerned that there had been some conflict within the Bureau of Customs between the managerial level and the Custom officers. The Government believes that a form of inquiry should take place. The Government had asked that the Attorney-General's Department, the Public Service Board and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs should look towards determining the nature of such an inquiry and its terms of reference. At any early date the Government will indicate its proposal as to such an inquiry. The Government has not rejected the concept of an inquiry. It is directing its attention at this moment to the nature of the inquiry and the terms of reference.

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the inquiry, whatever its nature, result in a public report? Will it deal with questions of not only internal departmental or administrative behaviour but also ministerial behaviour , and, in particular, the remaining central question in issue as to how Mr Moore was able to create the impression in the minds of his senior officers that the set in question was a black and white one in October 1981, when, according to him, the question of whether it was black and white or colour simply did not arise until April 1982?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I pointed out, at this moment the various departments are looking at the whole matter. I will direct the substance of that supplementary question to those concerned. The matter will be dealt with when the announcement is made as to the nature of the inquiry and its terms of reference.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the Minister's statement in Hobart on 6 April that the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme would be extended to air freight during maritime disputes and that details would be announced as soon as possible . Is the Minister in a position to tell the people of Tasmania how this subsidy extension will operate and when it will commence? If not, when does he hope to be able to do so?

—I am aware of the statement that was made in Hobart by the Minister on 6 April 1982. I understand that the details of any arrangements concerning the operation and extension of the scheme to include air freight during industrial disputes are being finalised as a matter of urgency. As soon as the arrangements have been completed, the Minister no doubt will make his announcement appropriately.
—I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister give some indication as to how long that would be?
—No, I am not able to do that. But I will convey Senator Walters 's concern to the Minister and ask him to be as quick as possible with his reply .

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PENSIONS AND OTHER FACILITIES FOR FORMER GOVERNORS-GENERAL

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I preface the question by reminding him that the answer to Question No . 1945, which was replied to a couple of days ago, set out certain details in relation to former Governors-General. Can the Minister tell me in which countries the five persons live, where the five offices are situated and what is the individual cost incurred in the provision of the five offices, secretaries and car transport for the financial year 1980-81? Further, is this cost in addition to the stated figure of $203,784 which is the figure stated in paragraph (1) of the reply to the question referred to as being the amount expended on pensions for the five persons whose names have not been listed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly that question seeks detailed information. I ask that it be put on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the oil refinery proposed to be built in the Iron Triangle region of South Australia and, in particular, to the application made recently to the Department of National Development and Energy by Southern Cross Petroleum for approval to have the contingent advantages of being declared a ' small remote refinery'. Is it true that the Stony Point connection with Santos Ltd condensate from the Cooper Basin gives this location ideal advantages? Also, is it true that the resources available for such a mini-refinery will directly match the current capacity of the local market in that region? Has the Minister been able to give favourable consideration to this South Australian proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am familiar with the whole situation. Some months ago , indeed in company with Senator Jessop, I made an inspection of the whole Iron Triangle area and the line of the pipeline down to Whyalla and Stony Point. I am aware that the timetable is that the pipeline will be finished by December with a capacity of some 35,000 barrels per day without pressure. So that is of particular significance. I have had before me an application from the Southern Cross Petroleum company asking that it be declared what is called a small remote refinery. The effect of that would be that it would not come under the crude oil allocation scheme and would not be required to take a portion of imported oil as do all other refineries. I and my Department have given very full consideration to the matter. I have written to the firm and informed it that, within the meaning of a small remote refinery, I cannot, however regrettably, accept that a refinery at Stony Point close to Whyalla could come under such terms. But I have said that I believe nevertheless that that ought not to be an impediment to the establishment of such a mini-refinery.

ANSWER.PARA: There are reasonable ways for Southern Cross Petroleum or any other refinery to make certain arrangements with other refineries. Therefore I do not regard this as an impediment. I would be very keen to follow up any difficulties that might emerge in that regard. Senator Teague asked me whether the refinery was ideally situated to serve that area. I understand that its output would certainly meet the fuel requirements for the whole of that Iron Triangle area. But because of the projected development of Roxby Downs the matter becomes increasingly important. The whole of the potential development, including Roxby Downs, the pipeline and Stony Point, is exciting in the development of South Australia. Whatever my Department and I can do to help that process we certainly will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Do Federal transport regulations require that Cessna Citation jet aircraft be operated by two pilots? Has the Premier of Queensland made a formal submission to allow the State Government's new $2.3m Cessna Citation jet to fly with one pilot only? If so, has the Government acceded to this request or is it standing firm on its established safety requirements?

—In regard to the machine to which Senator Colston refers I understand that the Queensland Government has submitted a proposal to the Department of Transport that it be allowed to fly that aircraft with one pilot only. Arrangements in the United States of America cannot be directly related to the Australian scene, it is true, but all operators and manufacturers' agents in Australia were informed that all models of Cessna Citation aircraft going into operation in this country would require a minimum crew of two pilots, even though in the United States of America, apparently, depending on particular circumstances of operation, one pilot is allowed to fly from time to time. No decision has been made by the Department with regard to the Premier's proposal. I think the Minister for Transport would feel that he doubts that the Premier deserves a lower standard of safety than members of the general community.

—I am not asking a question about the Cessna Citation jet aircraft. My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, pertains to the pattern of Federal Government funding to the performing arts through the Australia Council. In particular I refer to the level of funding to the Queensland Theatre Company-a level which theatre company officials consider to have now reached crisis proportions. Is the Minister aware that the future of many theatre companies in Queensland is in jeopardy due both to an increase in costs and a reduction in funds through the Australia Council? Will the Minister give an assurance that this matter will be carefully and sympathetically considered in the forthcoming Budget with a view to increasing the allocation of such funds so that all Queenslanders and, indeed, all Australians, may have the chance to enjoy the performing arts?

—I am aware of concerns that were expressed during last year on behalf of the Queensland Theatre Company. I think the honourable senator would understand that one cannot try to anticipate the Budget process or what the Budget outcome will be. I believe Senator Bjelke-Petersen would recall that the Government was able to provide the Australia Council with an extra $800,000 in December of last year and that these additional funds were used by the Australia Council to reinforce the Council's challenge grant scheme and to enable its boards, including the Theatre Board, to give further assistance to organisations not receiving a challenge grant. There is no doubt about the Government's commitment to assist the arts. The amount of money going through the Australia Council is substantial and has increased. Nevertheless, I will make my colleague Mr Wilson aware of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's concern on behalf of the Queensland Theatre Company and ensure that he is able to give consideration to the point that she has raised.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment inform me whether it is a fact that Mr Justice Gallop of the Northern Territory Supreme Court invalidated the Fisheries Act, which was a valuable weapon in fauna protection? If the answer is yes, does the Australian Government propose to fill the gap by the proclamation of any Federal powers to combat any further fauna destruction?

—I was aware of Senator Mulvihill's interest in the Fisheries Act and Mr Justice Gallop's determination. The question is a complicated one. It involves not only the Home Affairs and Environment portfolio and other portfolios at a Federal level but also a State government. I think it will be necessary for this question to receive quite detailed consideration. We will give it serious consideration. I will refer it to Mr Wilson and will respond to Senator Mulvihill at the earliest opportunity.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware that there has been a continual decline, in real terms, in the funds allocated to road building and maintenance over the past three years? Has there been a 40 per cent fall in funds allocated to road works over the past three years? Is the Minister aware that the road building industry is working at 31 per cent of its normal capacity? Has the proportion of the Budget devoted to road building and maintenance fallen from 2.6 per cent to 1.7 per cent in the lifetime of this Government? Will the Government consider diverting a small proportion of its oil levy-say 1c a litre-to a highway trust fund for the maintenance and construction of the nation's road system?

—The Commonwealth is currently committed to the provision of grants of about $3,650m to the States and to the Northern Territory for roads over the five years from 1980-81 to 1984-85. The purpose of a Bill introduced into the House of Representatives on 18 March is to appropriate the levels of funds which the Government has undertaken to provide over the remaining three years of the current roads program. The Minister for Transport, during his speech on that Bill, referred to the fact that he would be further examining road funds during the coming Budget discussions and consequently would be taking into account the kinds of points which Senator Siddons has made during his question. Whether any change might be undertaken is, of course, definitely a matter of Government policy and would be a matter for Cabinet to consider. I will refer that aspect of the question to the Minister and obtain an early reply for him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is there any substance in allegations that work that could be performed at the Launceston Railway Workshops by the Australian National Railways Commission is being transferred interstate? Further, are Tasmanian employees of ANR being overlooked in promotional advances in Tasmania in favour of staff from South Australia?
—I am afraid that I have no information on the question that Senator Watson raised. I will refer it to the Minister and get him an early reply.

—I refer the Minister for Health to representations which I believe have been made by various colleges of nursing regarding the implementation of the Sax Committee report into nurse education which has been in the hands of the Government for more than two years. Can he state when, if ever, and what, if any, recommendations of that report the Government will decide upon?

—Honourable senators will be aware that many reports have been prepared by Dr Sidney Sax. The one to which Senator Giles referred related to nurse training. It placed in sharp relief before the Government the choices between the academic training for nurses and the old style training in hospitals under what might be called an apprenticeship system. I remember that that report appeared some time ago. Honourable senators will be aware that I have had the health portfolio for only a little over 24 hours. I ask for some indulgence on this matter. I will try to obtain details of the present situation of our consideration of the matter. I recall that the Government undertook that there should be a pilot program to implement at least some of the suggestions which Dr Sax put forward and that this was to be done to let us see how the system would work. I am unable to say what stage that pilot experiment has reached or what the current situation is. I will advise the honourable senator when I am able.

—Did the Minister for Finance see the article in yesterday's Australian which was headed 'Bureaucrats sabotaging $50m program'? Has the Department of Finance, without recourse to the Parliament, reduced the allocation of $50m for industrial research and development to $33.5m? Incidentally, the appro- priation of $50m was passed by the Parliament. Does the Minister recognise that this action hits hardest at small industries and that it will cause some of them to abandon, curtail or delay some research programs with this country, I believe, being the loser? Will the Minister agree that the Government must be committed to improving technology in this country if some companies are to remain competitive on the world market? Does the Minister remember the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, which pointed out that Australia's expenditue on industrial research and development is very low compared with other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries? Finally, is it essential that these cuts be made? If so, will the Minister suggest to the Government that the possibility of fostering greater interaction between industry and universities in the form of joint researches be investigated and, at the same time, that it should provide additional funds for university projects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am aware of the report that appeared in the Australian yesterday. The article contained a number of errors and half truths. Perhaps I ought to refer the Senate to a response that I gave on 24 March when I tabled in the Senate a statement which set out in considerable detail the background to the 1981-82 expenditure on each of the three forms of industrial research and development expenditure-the commencement grants, the project grants and the public interest projects. The response to the article, I think, should draw on that statement made by me in March. I think I ought to state that the assertion that the Department of Finance acted without reference to Cabinet or without regard to government policies is just not accurate at all. The relevant Ministers have been in full discussion on these matters, both before and since the Budget of last year.

ANSWER.PARA: The other matter I want to add is that my own Department has very limited discretion in an area of this kind. The Cabinet was advised at the time of its consideration of the 1981-82 Additional Estimates that savings this year of some $16m were expected against the Budget appropriations for the industrial research and development grants. I should also say, in view of earlier statements made, that the Parliament also has been kept informed. A statement of savings expected in annual appropriations, prepared as a Department of Finance information paper, was provided to the Parliament with Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4. This paper includes information that savings of almost $16m were expected this year. I gave much of this information on 24 March.

I would have to say that the article is a complete misunderstanding or misstatement of the position with regard to support for industrial research and development. I take up further Senator Townley's suggestion with regard to support for such projects from government expenditure. Of course, there is substantial government support for research and development to assist productivity. When we compare figures for this country with those of other countries, I think we need to look at what industry does in a number of instances and what is done in our academic institutions as well as at what is done through some of the grants that we are now speaking about. I can understand the interest of Senator Townley in this matter and I will draw it to the attention of the Minister concerned. But in response to his inquiry about that article in the newspaper, I draw attention to its inaccuracies and refer to the information given in March which I think provides a clearer picture of the situation with regard to this sort of project in the current Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the Minister representing the Minister for Communications is aware that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal ruled that television commercials promoting Federal Government housing policies before the recent elections were electoral matter within the meaning of the Broadcasting and Television Act. In view of this ruling, what action is now being taken to recoup from the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party the costs of producing and broadcasting these commercials?
—I will refer that question to Mr Sinclair and get an answer for the honourable senator.

—Has the Minister for Finance noted an item in the Sydney Morning Herald dated 29 March entitled 'Warning on East Bloc loan defaults' which quotes the West German Foreign Minister, Mr Genscher, in regard to the problems of any country of the European Economic Community declaring an East European country in default on loans? According to this article, diplomatic sources say that Hungary could join Poland and Romania as being in difficulties over credit repayments. Can the Minister inform the Senate what are the total amounts of credit granted by Australia to the Eastern Bloc countries? What guarantees has Australia obtained to secure the repayments of the credits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether I have that information available. It is not readily available to me but I will seek it for Senator Lajovic and see that he gets an early response.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I preface it by reminding the Minister that the Australian Government joined with the Pacific nations at the South Pacific Forum, the South Pacific Commission and also the recent Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in condemning nuclear dumping and testing in the Pacific region. Is the Minister aware that the Australian yacht Pacific Peacemaker, which was protesting at the French nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll, was impounded by the French authorities at Papeete in Tahiti? Is the Minister aware that the captain and crew of the Pacific Peacemaker claim that their yacht was deliberately rammed by a French vessel and that film of this incident is now being processed in Australia? I ask the Minister: If the ramming of the vessel is substantiated by a court of marine inquiry, will the Government be prepared to seek an apology from the French about the whole incident and also support a claim to be lodged by the owners of the vessel for proper compensation for damage caused to the yacht?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer that matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for an early response.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the anticipated report of the Iron Triangle Study Group, which is partly financed by the Commonwealth, on the importance to South Australia of the Iron Triangle cities and in particular recent developments including the fractionation plant at Stony Point, the potential for servicing and supply of Roxby Downs, the continuing interest in the development of a petrochemical works in the area and other developments reflecting the economic upturn in South Australia resulting from good government. Bearing in mind the need for co-ordinated and planned development to the benefit of the total region and the State as a whole, I ask whether the Minister has yet received a copy of the report of the Iron Triangle Study Group, which I understood was to be completed by the end of February. If so, when is it to be publicly released?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Hill's interest in the whole of this development, particularly the importance of the pipeline to Stony Point, the bringing of petroleum liquids to Stony Point, and also, of course, the development of Roxby Downs. I am aware of the report of the Iron Triangle Study Group. My memory is that it had reached a point either of preliminary report or of report. I am not quite clear as to whether the full text of the report is available or whether, having been prepared, it is waiting clearance at State level. I will look at it and let the honourable senator know. Nevertheless he can be assured that the Commonwealth will do everthing it can, in conjunction with the South Australian Government, to bring the development of this area and indeed the whole of South Australia into line with the great prospects and potential that are now there.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware that in the compilation of the joint electoral rolls there are different qualifications between State and Commonwealth elections? Is the Minister aware that in Victoria prisoners are entitled to vote in State elections but are not entitled to vote in Federal elections and hence the roll is marked 'not entitled to vote for Federal elections'? Would the Minister agree that this sort of marking on the roll readily identifies, and unfairly so, those who have been prisoners? Could he look at the productions of the rolls in such a way that that marking will no longer occur?

—While I endorse completely Senator Robert Ray's concern that there should not be inappropriate endorsement of electoral rolls, could I suggest to the honourable senator that endorsement of the kind he suggests does not necessarily represent discrimination. The honourable senator might be aware that as a senator I have the right, and he has the right, to register in any division we wish in our electorate.
