In New South Wales I have chosen to register to vote in a division which is not the division in which I live.
—A marginal seat.

—It is no longer a marginal seat since I have registered to vote there. The roll for the State electorate of Gordon, which is where I live, contains my name with a notation containing, I think, exactly the words that Senator Robert Ray indicates. Similarly the roll for the Federal electorate of Cook in the subdivision of Carringbah, where I choose to vote federally, carries the same notation. So there are some notations indicating that people are not entitled to vote for certain classes of elections, which have nothing to do with our status of prisoners, unless one considers that service in this place represents a form of imprisonment. I adopt the point Senator Ray is making, that he wants to ensure that there is no discriminatory marking on the rolls. I will refer that matter to Mr Newman. I would be interested to see what the Minister can offer to overcome that. I just make the point that it is not necessarily a pejorative note should it appear.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport whether it is true that at some test corners in New South Wales cars are now allowed to proceed through a red light after stopping if they are turning to the left, something, incidentally, that I have been advocating for several years. Is the Minister able to say how long those tests will go on before it is suggested to all State departments of transport and within the Commonwealth territories that the whole of Australia follow some States in the United States of America and allow this turning to the left through a red light as a real means of easing traffic flow in some of our cities and, of course, resulting in a consequent saving of fuel? Perhaps I should point out that two of the States in the United States that use this system are California and New York. Both seem to live with the risk that is associated with turning through the red light.

—I am indebted to my New South Wales colleagues for informing me that this is, in fact, the situation in New South Wales. I was not aware of that . I am not aware of the length of time for which the tests to which Senator Townley referred are being carried out or when the results of them are expected to be assessed and a longer term policy adopted. However, I will endeavour to find out some more information about that for Senator Townley. I will draw that matter as well as the other issues which Senator Townley has raised to the attention of the Minister for Transport and obtain a reply on those points.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add to the answer to a question raised yesterday by Senator Watson. It was a question about the Falkland Islands. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information: The Australian Embassy in Buenos Aires has reported regularly to the Minister and the Department of Foreign Affairs over a long period on negotiations between Argentina and Britain over the future of the Falkland Islands. The Embassy reported the landing by Argentines and the raising of the Argentine flag on South Georgia Island on 19 March and subsequent activity. The Argentine Government's preparations and decision to invade the Falklands on 2 April were carried out in secrecy and were not known in advance to the Embassy.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion for Disallowance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Public Assemblies Ordinance 1982, contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 10 of 1982, and made under the Seat of Government ( Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The manner in which the Prime Minister supervises the conduct of his Ministers.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very sad, scandal-ridden Government we have in Australia. It is probably the most scandal- ridden government in Australia's history. If one thinks back to the days of Sir Robert Menzies who used to refer to the once great Australian Labor Party one knows that he would, of course, turn in his grave if he saw what was happening to a successor Liberal government. I do not want to dwell on the details of recent events involving ex-Ministers Moore and MacKellar. One should just be reminded that it took four days for those Ministers to resign. There was no rush on behalf of those Ministers to embrace the Westminster tradition. Of course, they committed no minor offence. Trivial as the incident may seem to be, it would not have been trivial if an ordinary citizen had been involved because the ordinary course of the law would have taken its effect. That, of course, is the important point. What is the difference between members of parliament and ordinary citizens in relation to standards of conduct?

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened to the present Government is upsetting to me not only because it is bad for this Government but also because it is bad for the whole Parliament. We have a government which has a paralysis in respect of dealing with tax avoidance. We have a government which is guilty of gross economic mismanagement and a government which has allowed enormous inequities to develop in this country. It is in that environment that the seemingly trivial conduct of a Minister evading duty on a television set becomes important because that evasion represents a manipulation of a position of privilege in a society where privilege is becoming more and more entrenched at the expense of the vast majority of Australians. So do not let us talk about it entirely as a trivial matter.

What I want to suggest in the course of what I say today about this matter of public importance is that if this Government from the beginning of its history, rather than making pious statements about ministerial integrity and standards which it would apply to the conduct of Ministers and members of parliament, had said that it was prepared to have a publicly available system of declaration of Ministers' interests and accountability in respect of the financial conduct of members of parliament, we would have had an objective test rather than the present system whereby Ministers report their financial involvements to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) who himself is not, in the eyes of many people in the Australian electorate, beyond reproach. If we had such a system the Prime Minister of the day really ought to be a presidential figure quite beyond reproach-a monarchial figure. Perhaps that is how the Prime Minister sees himself but it is not how a very large percentage of the Australian population sees him. We have this situation of Ministers reporting to the Prime Minister on their pecuniary interests which is, to adopt a somewhat hackneyed phrase, like putting Dracula in charge of a blood bank.

If we look over this Government's record we see that there have been a total of 21 sackings, resignations and suspensions from the Fraser Ministery since it took office-I repeat 21. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, whose fixation is with comparative statistics of the past, will have the gravest difficulty in adding up that number of Ministers. He will have the gravest difficulty in the course of the development of his fixation about the years 1972 to 1975 in pointing to any Minister in the Labor Government who was charged with and shown to be guilty of an act of financial impropriety. Those are the considerations which are of the utmost concern when we consider the public standards of the Government and this Parliament. Of the 25 Ministers of the first Fraser Ministry sworn in in January 1976, 12 have gone. The Prime Minister, on 12 March 1978, had the gall to say:

One of my Government's first promises when we were elected just over two years ago was to restore the integrity and honesty of government. As long as I lead the Government, there is no way known that anything less than the highest code and practice of public administration will be tolerated.

It is arguable that this week a standard of public conduct of Ministers was enforced. That is to the Government's credit in a sense. But one of the strange things about that enforcement is that it took a process of four days, 24 hours of which was spent with two Ministers trying to arrive at what they saw as the truth of a situation. Then there was a long process of delay. There was no question of a prompt response to a situation which should have produced a prompt response.

One of the aspects which need to be addressed is the uneven attitude which the Prime Minister, having chosen to be the administrator of the standards of the Ministry and the standards which should pertain in this Parliament, adopts to Ministers belonging to different parties. Of the 12 Ministers who have left the Fraser Government through resignation, dismissal or suspension, only one was a member of the National Country Party. I refer to Mr Adermann, a fairly elderly Minister who was replaced by a junior Minister from the National Country Party. The rest were Liberal Party Ministers. There has been no real loss to the National Country Party in this non-stop unseemly game of musical chairs that has gone on in the Fraser Cabinet. Liberals are expendable; National Country Party Ministers stay put, whatever the circumstances and however grievously they may have betrayed their trust as Ministers.

I could dwell on a number of cases but I will refer particularly to one. It involves a Minister of this Government who sat in judgment on two other Ministers this week. I refer to the case of the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Nixon). One could, of course, mention his colleague the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony). Let us look at the case of the Minister for Primary Industry, who sat in judgment on Messrs Moore and MacKellar this week. In 1975 a joint committee of this Parliament reported on the declaration of interests of members and Ministers of the Parliament. Mr Nixon was a member of that committee. The committee recommended that a number of decisions be taken-public decisions which would involve an ongoing review of situations which have never been reviewed seriously by the Fraser Government. That was a parliamentary report expressing the unanimous view of seven members of this Parliament. One of the things they recommended was the establishment of a joint parliamentary committee which would carry on a continued investigation of the public's right to know about conflicts of interest and other matters involving the behaviour of Ministers and members of parliament.

The committee recommended that members of parliament should disclose the names of all companies in which they had a beneficial interest in shareholdings no matter how insignificant and whether held as an individual or a member of a company, partnership or trust. It said that members of parliament should disclose the location of any real property in which they had a beneficial interest excluding, of course, a family home. The committee said that members of parliament should declare the names of all companies of which they were members. It said that MPs should provide all this information to a parliamentary register . The committee recommended that the public have access to this information. Nothing came of these recommendations because the Fraser Government came into power and the recommendations were too unpalatable to the Fraser Government.

I ask: What is so different about Australia under the Fraser Government in comparison with countries such as the United States of America on the one hand and Papua New Guinea on the other, which have very strict requirements about the public conduct of Ministers and members of parliament? After all, we import deregulation and monetarism from the United States as desirable intellectual concepts in politics. The things that we do not import from the United States are things which deal with public standards, and those things are too embarrassing and too difficult for the Fraser Government to accommodate. As I said, the Prime Minister came to power with promises of absolute propriety, but the recommendations of that committee were not acceptable to his Government. He then set up a committee-the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interests-under Sir Nigel Bowen, a former Liberal Attorney-General, to devise a code of conduct. That Committee has reported. For over two and a half years I have been asking Senator Sir John Carrick in this place when the Government is going to implement in full the recommendations of the Bowen inquiry. I have also asked him whether there will be a debate on the recommendations of the Bowen inquiry. On each occasion I have been told that the matter will receive attention shortly. The last occasion was on 22 September 1981 when Senator Sir John Carrick, in answer to a question from me, said that at that moment the Government was in the process of having discussions to extend the provisions to members of parliament. That was in September 1981. He continued:
We will be bringing into this Parliament . . . recommendations for the implementation, for members as distinct from Ministers, of the remaining provisions of the Bowen Committee report.

Nothing has happened since. The Parliament will probably grind to a halt and be closed down in two or three weeks because this Government has no legislation, because it has nothing to say on the grave economic crisis which is confronting this country, and, again, those issues will not be dealt with because they are unpalatable issues for the Government. The Government ignored the findings of the joint committee of 1975. It has done very little about implementing the Bowen Committee's proposals on public duty and private interest. That was a mild report indeed, but it seems to have been burdensome for some Ministers. Among its provisions was the provision that when a conflict of interest arose in the administration of a department a Minister should inform the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister should then authorise the Minister to proceed with the matter or hand it to another Minister. The Committee suggested that a Minister should not hold shares in a company which deals with his department. The Prime Minister said that he accepted those recommendations in relation to Ministers. But the saga of Mr Ian Sinclair's business and political activities spans the period before and after the acceptance of the Bowen report. Mr Sinclair was acquitted of charges relating to family business affairs. He remained a Minister who was living on misappropriated money-$300,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. That is completely offensive. Let me state the situation. There is no evidence at all that Mr Sinclair was living on misappropriated money. That remark is utterly offensive under Standing Orders. I remind the Chair that the court acquitted Mr Sinclair on all counts. The ordinary processes of law were followed to make arrangements for moneys due to various people, to various estates, to be processed. It is utterly untrue, therefore, to suggest that he was living on misappropriated money. I ask that that statement be withdrawn.
—Mr Sinclair was not living on misappropriated money.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask that that statement be withdrawn without qualification.

—With respect, I said that Mr Sinclair was not living on misappropriated money. But on 6 June 1979 Mr Sinclair tabled in the House of Representatives a statement in which he undertook to pay back $300,000 which had been misappropriated by his father. That is in the Hansard record of the House of Representatives. I withdraw the suggestion that Mr Sinclair is in fact living on that money, but I am saying that that is the situation.

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Button cannot have it both ways. It was not the situation that Mr Sinclair was living on misappropriated money. Senator Button cannot withdraw the statement and then say that that was the situation.
—I think Senator Button has satisfactorily withdrawn.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, we will leave Mr Sinclair alone.
—So you should.
—Why should we? He has never been delicate with us and I do not propose to be delicate with him.
—He has been honest.
—Oh, yes, very honest.
—He stood over Carrick in that room three years ago and sent him in here to lie to get Webster off the hook.
—On a point of order. Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to take note of what was said. The imputation that I was sent in here to lie is an offensive remark and should be withdrawn.
—I withdraw that.
—Senator Walsh, for the record, will you withdraw your remarks?
—I said so.
—I am asking you to do so now.
—I withdraw.

—I wanted seriously to devote some time to the question of the standards of ministerial conduct which are laid down by the Prime Minister and the way in which they have been applied in the first place to Liberal Party members and in the second place to Country Party members. I say that they have not been applied to Country Party members at all. I mentioned the particular situation of Mr Sinclair. Senator Withers, who sits in this place and by virtue of whose impropriety Senator Sir John Carrick now takes points of order from the Leader's chair, knows full well what I am talking about. Different standards are applied by the Prime Minister to Liberal Ministers from those applied to Country Party Ministers. Nowhere is that more manifest than in the case of the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon.
—Is that being said because Senator Withers is not here to deny it?

—Senator Withers would not deny it. He is a very honest man. The real test of the Bowen guidelines was the disclosure of the fact that the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, and his family held 1,244 shares in the Murray Goulburn Co-operative Co. Ltd at a time when he was Minister for Primary Industry. If honourable senators read the Bowen guidelines, they will see that the holding of those shares is quite inconsistent with the guidelines. A great number of questions arose from the Minister's decisions relating to the production by that Co-operative of a large quantity of butter. It was butter which was subject to a levy of $2.3m. The Co-operative had tried to disguise that butter as milk fat concentrate rather than butter in order to avoid the payment of penalties to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Many decisions of the Minister for Primary Industry in relation to that matter remained un-answered. Why did he not disclose that he had authorised payment to Murray Goulburn of amounts totalling $800,000? These payments effectively reduced the liability of Murray Goulburn which had tried to deceive the Government. It reduced its liability from $2.3m to $1.6m. The Minister for Primary Industry, as a shareholder in that company, presided over that situation . Why did the Minister not enforce section 22 (2) of the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Act which provides a penalty for false and misleading statements? Why was the company, in which he was a shareholder, exempt from the provisions of that legislation? What influence did he have in changing the long-standing policy of the Australian Dairy Corporation so that Murray Goulburn received a payment of $100,000 to cover interest on loans related to the disputed so-called 3,000 tonnes of butter?

Why were manufacturers of other dairy products not given the same concessions which were given to the company in which the Minister for Primary Industry was a shareholder? Why did the Minister for Primary Industry not inform the Prime Minister or Cabinet of the decision which he was taking? Why did he not tell the Prime Minister that he was a shareholder in the company which had constant dealings with his Department? The scale of those breaches by the Minister for Primary Industry is enormous in terms of the Prime Minister's own stated standards. It did not involve just the non-payment of duty on a $200 television set. The unfortunate Mr MacKellar was caught red handed in a parliamentary session. The situation with the Minister for Primary Industry was that it all happened over Christmas and the matter was glossed over. Even with the standards which this Government says it has, there is a gross inequity in its administration between various Ministers. It is an horrendous situation for any government to get itself into. Why does that Minister continue to hold his post when Mr MacKellar and Mr Moore have to go for breach of ministerial conduct? Why does Mr Nixon not abide by his own recommendations? Why is what is right with-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that is being debated is the manner in which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) supervises the conduct of his Ministers. I stress that the conduct of Ministers is of very great importance indeed. The Parliament and the people of Australia are entitled to expect from Ministers a conduct higher than that required of the general community. I submit that that is the normal behaviour common amongst Ministers of both sides of Parliament. One will find, as one expects, that Ministers do seek to have such high conduct.

SPEECH.PARA: I leave aside the melodrama of the rhetoric of Senator Button. He related straightaway to the sad events of recent days. The whole of the Parliament and the community will be sad that two young Ministers of very considerable promise should have found it necessary to resign within the Westminster process. Senator Button said that there was an unduly long period in that process. From the emergence of the issue on the Friday to the resignation on the Monday, there was a span purely of a weekend. Those who reflect on this matter will know that in order for this matter to be documented and so that the world should know it was necessary that files had to be got from the State. The head of Department who had the function at that time was no longer the head and had to be located. Various statements had to be made. I put it to honourable senators that it was with expedition that something that emerged on the Friday should have been resolved, however sadly, on the Monday.

With regard to that incident, some three months or less after the Fraser Government came to office, following the Whitlam Government, for whatever reason the Prime Minister found it necessary to set out an instruction as to the conduct of Customs officers with regard to parliamentarians and other dignitaries coming through Customs. This ought not to have been necessary. In order to establish those standards, the Prime Minister set out those standards. That is a token of the behaviour of the Prime Minister and of his Government. The late Mr Carmody, then the Secretary of the Department, made it abundantly clear that there was to be no difference in the treatment of parliamentarians. The letter of the Prime Minister in that regard and the statement of Mr Carmody are documented and circulated and that is, and remains, the instruction of the Prime Minister and this Government to every Customs officer on the floor and to every officer in the Department. There have been some disabilities in the system . This is the reason why, at this moment, there is a problem on our hands. The Government does not disguise that problem and is seeking honourably to resolve it.

Let me make it clear that the standards are set, and were set after the Whitlam Government, at the highest possible level. Every Customs officer must have known that. To have said various forms of rhetoric-such as that there is a paralysis of the Government that can be demonstrated by the inactivity on tax avoidance-is , of course, to the nth degree absurd. Our Government came into office following a Labor government that did nothing on tax avoidance. The history of the Treasurer, Mr Howard, on this is one of persistent pursuit of tax avoiders. No government has done more on this matter. I put that in perspective. The Government set up, several years after it came to office the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest. The Bowen Committee sat for a considerable time and then produced a report, which has been circulated. It has been said that the Government has not acted on this matter. That is patently untrue. The Government has announced quite clearly that it has acted to adopt the section relating to Minister's conduct to enforce those provisions. The matter that is being discussed today concerns the conduct of Ministers. The recommendations of the Bowen Committee apply to Ministers today and have applied now for some considerable time.

Much has been made of the fact that a previous committee in 1975 recommended a public register. On the one hand, Senator Button says that we should have adopted the Bowen Committee report; on the other hand, he says that there should be a public register. In fact, the Bowen Committee did not recommend a public register nor was this idea adopted by the Prime Minister or his Government. I repeat: The Bowen Committee has made its report; the standards set out in that report are now applicable to all Ministers and are to be observed by them. That means that each Minister must disclose by way of written statement his or her pecuniary interests. Those interests are made available to the Prime Minister and to the head of the Prime Minister's Department. In any discussion on matters which involve self-interest, it is the obligation of the Minister to indicate that he or she has such a self-interest. I want to make it abundantly clear that the recommendations of the Bowen Committee have been implemented and are, in fact, enforced upon Ministers.

There was some talk of a list of some 21 sackings, resignations or suspensions. I will come to that in a moment. The interesting point is that two Ministers were picked out for criticism; one was Mr Sinclair, the other was Mr Nixon. There were no others. Whilst I do not want to make any comparisons-I do not believe that one helps one's argument by saying that the other fellow is worse- nevertheless, since that comparison was sought, I will refer in a moment or two to the record of the Whitlam Government.

I refer firstly to Mr Sinclair. It is time that this matter was put to rest. It is time that the interjections and innuendoes in this Senate were stopped. I emphasise that because these actions do nobody any credit. The facts are that a series of events occurred. It emerged that Mr Sinclair's father, an accountant, had apparently misappropriated large sums of money. The Labor Government of New South Wales, through its law officers, prosecuted the son-Mr Ian Sinclair-on a wide range of charges. On every charge he was acquitted. He made it quite clear that he intended, because he had not known of the circumstances, to make reparations. He made that voluntary statement. In any case, the ordinary public processes of the law existed to ensure that any moneys wrongly held would go to the proper persons. I emphasise that. Mr Sinclair has said:
No moneys are outstanding between the company and myself or the other shareholders and myself other than those covered by formal agreement entered into with independent legal advice.

That statement had been made by Mr Sinclair before Senator Button made his allegations today. It does Senator Button no credit that he made those allegations in that knowledge, in the knowledge of the findings of the court or in the knowledge of the ordinary processes for recovery of moneys. Let me make that abundantly clear. I repeat what Mr Sinclar said:
No moneys are outstanding between the company and myself or the other shareholders and myself other than those covered by formal agreement entered into with independent legal advice.

Today, quite deliberately, a misrepresentation was made by Senator Button. He said that two standards are held by the Prime Minister-one for Liberals, which is punitive; the other for the National Country Party which is not. How can he say these things when he knows that, in fact, Mr Sinclair stood down during the whole of the time there were charges against him, during the whole of that sad period when, because of a family tragedy, he was forced to undergo public scrutiny? Can there be a greater punishment for any man than that? He was proven innocent in the end. He stood down at the time of the Court-hearing. How can Senator Button have such selective knowledge that he fails to know that a National Country Party Minister-former Senator Sheil-within hours of his being sworn in was forced to have his portfolio withdrawn because it was considered that his behaviour in his approach to the Press was against the Government's policy? Could there be a more drastic enforcement of the strict rules of proprierty than that? In fact, this matter was not mentioned. It was hugged to the breasts of the members of the Opposition because they want to create some disaffection between the National Country Party and the Liberal Party. Indeed, full enforcement of the standard was applied in all its forms.

The issue of Mr Nixon, the Minister for Primary Industry, and his shares in a dairy co-operative has been raised. The fact of the matter is that shares in a co-operative are, of course, completely different from shares in a normal profit -making company enterprise where one gets large and significant dividends and expects to get earnings capital accretions from those shares. Basically, in normal, legitimate trading, those who are involved in particular farming activities take out a nominal series of shares in co-operatives so that they have the capital to function as marketing or processing bodies. There can be no attempt to correlate this activity with some other business venture.

There was never an attempt to disguise the fact that Mr Nixon, being a farmer and processing dairy products and marketing vegetable products, was part of a co -operative and, therefore, held nominal shares in that co-operative. Mr Nixon has never sought to hide that. Mr Nixon has never at any time indicated otherwise. We have had selective details given to us today. One measure of this is that Senator Button sought to show that by an action of the Minister a known or sane benefit was given to the co-operative. He failed to disclose that, by a parallel action of the Minister, a punitive action was levelled against that co- operative. It is just not good enough for honourable senators to talk in the Senate about the propriety of Ministers when one by one the statements made are proven to be wrong and indeed, to be improperly made because they are wrong. Who , then, is the improper person? To whom does the saying 'Physician heal thyself' , relate? This Government set up standards for Customs officers' behaviour, and never modified them. It set up the Bowen Committee and adopted the report of that Committee. This Government had a situation in which a Minister, Mr Sinclair proven wholly innocent-nevertheless stood down. This Government, the day before yesterday, accepted the resignations of two of its Ministers. So, all that has been said is utterly wrong.

I turn to a matter which I did not want to pursue because I do not believe that comparative impropriety is any justification. I raise it only because it has been raised. Honourable senators will recall that Senator Button said: 'Even Senator Carrick cannot refer to the Whitlam Government'. The Whitlam Government was in office for three years. This Government has been in office for seven and a half years-more than two and a half times longer. It is interesting that at the end of the three years only seven Ministers held the same positions in November 1975 as they held in December 1972. That is not a bad track record! It is interesting that two Ministers were dismissed for misleading Parliament. Is not one of the major improprieties that a Minister can commit that he or she should mislead Parliament?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—Yes, it is.
—You should know. You know all about misleading Parliament.
—Order! Senator Walsh. Come to order, please.

—Two Ministers were sacked for misleading Parliament. One of these, Dr Cairns, was sacked twice as well as losing the deputy prime ministership. One refused to resign and the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, had to instruct the Governor-General to terminate his commission for a misleading of parliament. These are the things that Senator Button seeks to gloss over. In three years of the Whitlam Government there were three Deputy Prime Ministers, three Treasurers, three Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs, four Ministers for Secondary Industry, three Ministers for Works and Housing, three Ministers for Immigration, three Ministers for the Northern Territory, three Ministers for Customs and four Ministers for the Environment. Only seven of the original Ministers were still there after three years. Two Ministers were sacked. One had to be sacked for misleading Parliament. One refused to resign.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat-I do not want to take any pride in this-that there is no joy at all in comparative propriety of impropriety. I did not raise this matter. Senator Button raised it. He does not come out of this debate with any sense of propriety at all. Each of the main claims he made were in fact, I put it to this Senate, improperly made. On each of the occasions that this Government has had a problem, it has set up the standards and has endeavoured to enforce them. In Mr Sinclair's case, he stood down. When we have had sad problems, as we did several days ago, the Ministers involved have resigned. We set up the Bowen Committee. We adopted the principles of its report. It does no credit at all to the Labor Party to raise these matters. I apologise to the people of Australia that the incidents of recent days occurred. But because they have occurred is no justification for the misrepresentation by Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has proposed for debate the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The manner in which the Prime Minister supervises the conduct of his Ministers.

This debate is highlighted by the unfortunate events that surfaced last week. Whilst Senator Carrick, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, has made some comments about those aspects, I do not comment one way or the other on them. The fact is that two Ministers have resigned as a result of certain conduct on their part. The unfortunate thing is that the whole incident, and particularly the way in which it has been handled by the Government, has further belittled the important office of Minister of the Crown and has further belittled Parliament and parliamentarians in the eyes of the ordinary Australian man and woman. These people look to government, to Ministers and to parliament for leadership to overcome the economic problems that this Government has forced upon them. They look to government and to Parliament to uplift them and give them faith in their own and in their nation's future.

Since this Government came to office the system of parliamentary democracy has received a constant battering. The system continues to reel from the blows delivered by a government which daily and wildly accused its predecessor in office. Those accusations have been repeated here today by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. This Government, in Opposition, said that when it obtained and held the reins of office it would do something to clean up the rules. I intend to show in the short time available to me that the conduct of the then Opposition, the present Government, before the election of 1975, its statements during the election of 1975 and its standards since then are completely inconsistent one with the other. As the only remaining ex-Minister of the Labor Government in this Senate, I well remember the debates that took place in this Parliament in 1975. I then had the honour of being the Minister in charge of Government business in the Senate. I remember the constant and repetitive terms-'deceit', 'duplicity', 'dishonesty' and 'discrimination'. I remember the fishing expeditions that the then Opposition, the members of the present Government, embarked upon at meetings of Senator Estimates committee and by the establishment of Senate select committees when looking for the tiniest piece of evidence that they could dig up against some Labor Minister of the Crown.

I remember this Senate being recalled by the then Opposition, the members of the present Government, in the winter recess of 1975 and seeing senior public servants such as the present Solicitor-General, the then head of Treasury and the then head of the Department of Minerals and Energy sitting in the south- western corner of the Senate chamber waiting, as it were, like kids going into a dentist's chair to be called before the Bar of the Senate. Along with ordinary, decent Australian citizens they were called before the Bar of the Senate to answer questions, to be cross-examined and to be humiliated in the hope that members of the then Opposition might be able to dig something out against some Labor Minister of the Crown. I remember the suspicion, the mistrust and the urge on their part to pin something on somebody. I remember the monotony of the repetitive 'C' speeches-the speeches that collectively gathered the names of Cairns, Crean, Connor, Cass and Cope, decent Australian citizens, and honourable members of this Parliament-to give the impression that we, the Ministers and the members of the Labor Government, were a bunch of hoods fit only to ride with the Kelly gang. As Senator Button has said, no Minister of that Labor Government was ever charged or indicted before any court of this country. But tragically for the Australian people, the vicious and wicked propaganda of the then Opposition paid off. We were sacked and the Fraser Government came into office. What did Mr Fraser say in his policy speech of 1975? He said:
Australia needs an immediate change of direction.
What can be done immediately, and must be done, is to establish-for the first time in three years-sound and honest management of Australia's affairs.
He went on to say:

There will be an end to Government extravagances and excesses. There will be no international safaris by members of Parliament. The purpose and nature of overseas trips will be subject to clear guidelines. Australia does not need a tourist as Prime Minister. There will be no more jobs for the boys.

That was what Mr Fraser said in 1975. What did the present Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Country Party (Mr Anthony) have to say at that election? Government members have said that they did not cast aspersions on the Labor Government. Mr Anthony in his policy speech in November 1975 stated:
The real lawlessness to be feared in Australia today is lawlessness in government.
He then went on at page 10 of his policy speech to say:
. . . I ask you this:
Do you want the same dishonesty, the same corruption, the same incompetence, the same mismanagement?

Should an incompetent government have three years? Should a dishonest government have three years? Should a corrupt Government have three years? Should a Prime Minister accused of lying have three years?

It was on those sorts of statements that tragically the Australian Labor Government of 1972-75 in which I was proud to be a Minister, lost office. So the present Government having made those pledges to scour out and clean up the system, what has been its sorry record in office and particularly the record of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)? I say, in reply to what Senator Sir John Carrick has just said in his speech, that we do not complain about the setting of the standards by the Government or by the Prime Minister. We complain that the standards that have been set have been ignored by the Government. Senator Sir John Carrick said that this Government has been in office for seven and a half years. In the six and a bit years that the Government has been in office we have seen the demise of some 21 Ministers including the resignation and/or dismissal of 12 Ministers of whom nine were members of the Liberal Party and three were members of the National Country Party. Of course, one of those members from the National Country Party was a Minister for one day only-the former Senator Sheil. Another of those members has been restored, as Senator Button has said, to his senior Cabinet position. In addition to that what appear to be countless numbers of others have been made ambassadors, high commissioners , consuls-general, administrators or even chairmen of some Commonwealth statutory body. Yet we were told in 1975: 'There will be no more jobs for the boys'. Therefore one reads with some cynicism in this morning's Australian Financial Review that now that it is certain that there are to be several Cabinet changes, it means that at least two Ministers are destined for ambassadorial or judicial posts. It is a fact that Ministers are moved either sideways or upwards, or they are dismissed, or they are feted for resignation, or whatever it be, not according to the standards that have been set by the Government or by the Prime Minister, but according to the political climate at the time. Yesterday the Prime Minister said:
This Government has always upheld the fundamental principles of ministerial responsibility . . .

Rhetorically I ask: What happened to any Minister when there was a serious leak of Budget documents in the Budget before last to a prominent Australian journalist when Australian police were called in to investigate? Had that happened in London in the British Parliament the Treasurer would have had to resign. But what happened in this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —He was promoted.

—As my colleague Senator Bolkus has just said the Minister has now been promoted. What has happened to any Minister over the meat scandal racket, something that has cost Australians hundreds of millions of dollars and which has seriously depleted and damaged one of our primary production industries? What has happened to any Minister as a result of the serious deficiencies in, and the leaks from, the disbanded Federal Narcotics Bureau? These matters are now the subject of a royal commission. The Minister responsible was transferred but he still remains a Minister in the same government. What happened to any Minister after the revelations of the incompetence of the Department of Primary Industry and the questionable overseas activities and dealings of the Australian Dairy Corporation which was the subject of a report to this Senate by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations?
—A million dollars lost.

—As my colleague Senator Sibraa said, $1m was lost. The answer in all of those cases where the doctrine of ministerial responsibility should have been applied in short has been absolutely nothing. Every day this Government lurches from crisis to crisis. It lurches from embarrassment to embarrassment and from blunder to blunder. The public is exhausted, bewildered and concussed. The public seeks a change of government. Certainly that will come when the election is called whenever that might be. I support the matter of public importance which has been introduced by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) has introduced into the Senate for discussion this afternoon a subject which he describes in his own words as:

SPEECH.PARA: The manner in which the Prime Minister supervises the conduct of his Ministers.

Those who have been listening to this debate will recall that Senator Button sought to place a general smear on the financial propriety of a large number of Ministers who have served in the various Fraser Ministries since November 1975 when the first Ministry was formed. I propose to go back and to say something about that because I think that is one of the most unfair insinuations that I have heard in the Senate. Following as I do Senator Douglas McClelland in this debate I immediately take up some of the matters with which he has dealt in his contribution to this subject. I was amazed to find that, in debating the subject which has been introduced this afternoon, Senator Douglas McClelland should have spent quite a bit of his time recalling the events and the record of the Labor Government between 1972 and 1975. He told us how he remembered the events of 1975 and he compared them with events during the Fraser Government's term of office. He complains that some Ministers have been appointed as ambassadors, that some have been given other posts and that others have been appointed to statutory authorities. Let us recall the record of the Labor Goverment under this head. Who appointed Mr Grassby, the Commissioner for Community Relations? Not only did the Labor Government appoint Mr Grassby, a defeated Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —A fine job.

—I am not complaining about Mr Grassby. This is the record of the Labor Government which Senator Douglas McClelland has asked us to recall. Mr Grassby was a Minister in the Labor Government. He was defeated and appointed Commissioner for Community Relations. The Labor Government did one better in fact. It passed an Act of Parliament and created the position of Commissioner for Community Relations. Mr Grassby was appointed to that position. Do honourable senators recall that the Deputy Prime Minister in the Labor Government, Mr Lance Barnard, was sent off as Ambassador to Sweden, I think it was. Who appointed Mr Justice Murphy, the Attorney-General in the Labor Government, to the High Court? I am not for one minute criticising any of those appointments. I am simply recalling, as Senator Douglas McClelland has invited us to recall, some of the highlights during the Labor Government's term of office.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Douglas McClelland told us that he remembers the events of 1975. He asked us to recall those events. He seemed to be particularly concerned- certainly he was very impressed as he remembers this in great detail-with events in the Senate when we were in opposition at that time and we called to the Bar of the Senate a number of public servants. Why were a number of public servants- they were perfectly distinguished people and no reflections were cast upon them- called to the Bar of the Senate? It was because we could not get answers. Not only could we not get the truth but also we could not get answers out of the Ministers of the Labor Government about the greatest scandal which had ever occurred in this country and which was known as the loans scandal. We tried for months to get answers in this Parliament about what happened. We got the truth only after months and months of investigation. Finally, the truth did come out about the squalid dealings with Mr Khemlani, an international broker, and the continuous dealings with that gentleman by Ministers of the Labor Government.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I call the Senate to order . I point out to Senator Evans that he is out of his seat. He is in error on that account. He is in error also because he is interjecting.

—It was only after months of endeavouring to get the truth-not day, not week, but months-that the truth did come out. That, in effect, was the end of the Labor Government. But I do not want to dwell on that today. I was asked to recall it by Senator Douglas McClelland. I thought that we should get the full recall, the full flavour of the event.
—What about the Gair affair in 1974?

—Senator Teague is quite right. We could on on and on. But I do not want to take up time with irrelevancies in this debate today. The subject that we are discussing is the manner in which Prime Minister Fraser is supervising the conduct of his Ministers. I think it is wise to set the scene by recalling the events of those three years of office of the Labor Government of which Senator Douglas McClelland was a proud member. The fact is that the present Prime Minister was at great pains, and rightly so because of the events, to emphasise the importance that he attached to the proper conduct of Ministers. He has laid down standards. There seems to be no doubt about that. I think the Opposition has made it quite clear that it is not complaining about the high standards which the Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser has laid down and which he has reiterated. I believe that he has enforced them in relation to ministerial conduct. He laid them down at an early stage of his administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, during that administration he set up the committee which was presided over by Sir Nigel Bowen and which reported in July 1979 on the disclosure by Ministers, members of parliament and officers of the Public Service and statutory authorities of their pecuniary interests. The Prime Minister put into force the recommendations in that report relating to Ministers. Those recommendations were adopted, have been in force and have been acted upon. In fact, the major provision-namely, the disclosure by Ministers of their pecuniary interests to the Prime Minister-had been a feature of Prime Minister Fraser's earlier requirements in relation to ministerial conduct. All Ministers in the Fraser governments have been required by the Prime Minister to provide that information and to keep it up to date.

The case of the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, has been mentioned in this debate. The fact is that Mr Nixon's interest was disclosed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister knew of it. I do not want to repeat what Senator Sir John Carrick said about it. But the fact is that Mr Nixon's interest, which has been discussed in this debate today, was the subject of disclosure under that requirement of the Prime Minister.

I turn now to the insinuations of Senator Button about financial improprieties. That is my note of the phrase he used. He coupled that with the 'sacking of Ministers' and mentioned a figure of 21. He let all these things float around to give the impression to those people listening to this debate today that something like 21 Ministers of this Government had been disposed of in one form or another as a result of some sort of financial impropriety. That is how it sounded to me. He did not specifically say it in that many words but his remarks were coupled to give that impression. Of course, it is a totally false impression. The only cases of Ministers actually being sacked were the cases of Senator Withers and Senator Sheil. Most of the cases involved Ministers resigning for one reason or another. Some resigned on matters of principle, such as my predecessor, Mr Ellicott, and, recently, Mr Peacock. That is a very fine example of Ministers upholding the standards of ministerial responsibility because they had a difference with the Government or with the Prime Minister on a matter of principle.

Other Ministers have stood aside, either temporarily or permanently, because of questions that were raised and inquiries that were made into alleged misconduct. Examples of that, of course, were the cases of Messrs Garland, Robinson and Sinclair. It is worth remembering that no actual findings of criminal conduct were made in regard to those allegations. Messrs Garland, Robinson and Sinclair returned to the Ministry because they had been cleared of the allegations made against them. Other Ministers have simply resigned. In some cases, such as the cases of Mr McLeay and Mr Garland, they were appointed to posts outside the Parliament. Both persons were interested in pursuing other careers. In no sense were they sacked. They are perfectly normal situations which occur from time to time with Ministries.
The recent events which have given rise to this debate-the resignations of Messrs MacKellar and Moore, which I think everybody recognises were most unfortunate, arose--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator McLaren does not. He likes to put the boot in whenever he can; we know that. The fact is that all comment about the matter has recognised that if they had been ordinary citizens of this country this matter would have been dealt with as a most minor legal affair. But because they were Ministers and because they had high standards to maintain they resigned.
—What do you mean by 'a minor legal affair'? There is a $2,000 fine.

—What fine does Senator Evans think would be imposed for that offence? He knows perfectly well that if Mr MacKellar had been dealt with under section 209 of the Customs Act he would have been dealt with at the barrier, because it was a minor matter, and the duty would have been paid. It would then have been over and done with and there would have been no prosecutions at all. That is the fact of the matter. He recognises that. The fact is that they resigned because they had high standards to uphold. If the Opposition is suggesting impropriety, I point out that Mr MacKellar wrote, as we all know, to the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs within a few days and offered to pay any duty that he was liable to pay. He has now said that he will pay the duty when the assessment is made. I believe that this Government and this Prime Minister have upheld the most high standards of ministerial propriety .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday night the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) knew that Mr MacKellar had not paid duty on a colour television set, that a false declaration with Mr MacKellar's name on it had been filed and that the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Moore, found out about those incidents the next week and did nothing. The Prime Minister did nothing on Friday night or Saturday morning. On Monday night, he accepted the resignations of the Ministers as their fingertips touched the tops of their spines. No relevant facts were known on Monday night that were not known on Friday other than the fact that every major newspaper in the country had editorially demanded that the Ministers go. The Ministers went, not because of their offences, but because the Government's position was politically untenable given the unanimous reaction of the Press on Monday. According to Press reports, Cabinet unanimously decided that the resignations be insisted upon. In the greatest of ironies, Mr Nixon and Mr Sinclair voted for the resignations. Fancy putting Mr Sinclair on a jury, as my friend Mick Young said in the House of Representatives yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people might think that the Prime Minister's attitude towards Mr Moore and Mr MacKellar was slack-and so it was. People are right to think that, especially given that a member of the Prime Minister's staff was this morning telling anyone around Parliament House who would listen that Moore and MacKellar would be back. Compared with some Ministers who are still in the Fraser Cabinet, Moore and MacKellar were victimised. For example, our old friend Mr Sinclair on his own admission in a statement in the House of Representatives on 6 June 1979, which I have with me, acknowledged that his father had misappropriated from the Reliance group of companies $292,000. He undertook responsibility to pay the money back under terms to be determined later. The terms were determined and released to the Press Gallery in a statement from Mr Sinclair on 2 August 1979, which I also have with me. Mr Sinclair received and, according to the terms of that statement, continues to have in his possession $100,000 of the nearly $300, 000 stolen dollars which he undertook to repay.

Senator Carrick, in his usual obfuscatory style, said that Mr Sinclair was cleared by the courts. It is true that he was found not guilty of three charges of forgery, three charges of uttering and three offences under the Companies Act of New South Wales. It is true that he was cleared of those charges after the jury had deliberated for seven hours and in spite of a rather extraordinary direction to the jury by the presiding judge. But the facts about Mr Sinclair having received the money which he said was misappropriated and being in possession of some of it still came from his own mouth and pen. Whether he is living on the money or whether he is just holding it to finance the private business and accumulate more Sinclair family capital has no relevance to the fact that he received, knowingly or unknowingly, the money in the first place, that he certainly retained possession of it after he became aware of the fact that it was misappropriated, even after he had publicly acknowledged that it was misappropriated, and he has some of it still.

A Senate committee only last year unanimously found that it preferred the evidence of the former Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, Mr Webster, to the evidence given by Mr Sinclair. Mr Sinclair declined to take an oath or to make a statutory declaration to the Committee. In fact, one wonders whether, if MacKellar's secretary had written George Sinclair across the bottom of the declaration, Mr MacKellar would still have been in the Ministry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn Senator Walsh that he is sailing very close to the line when he makes remarks like that. I ask him to be very careful in his choice of language. He has made an insinuation which is barely inside the lines of creditable language in this place.

—It was disclosed last December that Mr Nixon, acting alone, had authorised a discretionary payment of three-quarters of a million dollars to the Murray-Goulburn dairy co-operative, a company in which he and his family have 2, 000 shares. It is true that penalty payments of $2.3m, about which he had no option because the question was one of legal definitions and he had obtained legal advice on the matter, were made by the company. According to both Senator Carrick and the Prime Minister that action is also quite acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bowen guidelines, said to have been adopted by this Government, in relation to ministerial behaviour say quite explicitly that when a Minister is directing the business of his department he must inform the Prime Minister of any real or apparent conflict of interest and that the Prime Minister, having been informed, unless he asks the Minister to divest himself of the shares, must appoint another Minister to make the decision or personally authorise the decision made by the original Minister. In any case, the guidelines say that the matter must be recorded. The Prime Minister's excuse for the suspension of the guidelines as they might apply to National Country Party Ministers was that the guidelines stated that the Minister should inform him and not that the Minister must inform him. From what Mr Fraser has disclosed to us, whether he was informed remains a mystery.
I do not want to dwell at great length on this matter. I could not do any better than quote the editorial judgment of the Melbourne Age on this subject when, on 8 December, it stated:
Reminded of this-
that is the Bowen guidelines-

the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, has resorted to semantics. The report, he has said, uses the word 'should'. It does not say that a Minister 'must' divest himself of his shares or interest. The distinction is an artificial one; and the fact that Mr Fraser felt the need to make it will be seen by many as proof of his insincerity in the matter.

Then, of course, Mr Nixon, acting in the style to which he has become accustomed , attempted to intimidate the Australian Broadcasting Commission for reporting the incident. This was reported in the Canberra Times of 5 January. Senator Carrick prevaricated and obfuscated in a different way on this matter both yesterday in answer to a question and again today. He said that shares held in a co-operative do not establish a financial benefit which, by and large, is correct insofar as the profits of such a co-operative are usually disclosed according to the volume of trading done through the co-operative instead of the shares held. Mr Nixon is, of course, a supplier to the co-operative as well as a shareholder in it. Therefore, contrary to what Senator Carrick claims, he stood to gain financially by making a $750,000 discretionary payment to the co- operative for interest and storage charges which would ultimately be distributed to the suppliers of the co-operative, including himself. So Mr Nixon made a grant to the co-operative, portion of which was destined to be made to himself, and said nothing about it. As Senator Carrick put it yesterday with respect to the way in which such co-operatives operate, everybody knows that is a basic principle within the rural community. Therefore, apparently, the principles which are accepted with respect to the operations of co-operatives are those which will guide the ministerial behaviour of this Government, and to hell with the Bowen report.

Senator Carrick reminded us that the Government said it has adopted the Bowen guidelines, which is true. What we are concerned about and what the country is concerned about is not what the Government says but what the Government does. As this case makes perfectly clear, the Government says it has adopted the guidelines but in fact it has not. The Government says it has done a good job in managing the economy, and in fact it has not, and so on. What we are concerned about is not the excellence or the piety of the Government's rhetoric; what we are concerned about is its actual performance. The outstanding features of the principles of Fraserism with respect to ministerial behaviour are these: Firstly , they are, to say the least, permissive; secondly, there is an even lower standard for the National Country Party Ministers. Even a Country Party backbencher remarked recently, 'Even our people reckon Nixon and Sinclair should go'. Senator Carrick, of course, defends that double standard. Indeed, he is a beneficiary of it. If Country Party standards had been applied to Senator Withers nearly four years ago, Senator Withers and not Senator Carrick would be Leader of the Government in the Senate today. Senator Carrick indeed has good reason to defend the double standards of which he is a beneficiary.

Compliance with the needs of the Country Party has on some occasions got other members of this Government into trouble. Back in 1978 identical questions were asked in both Houses of the then Minister for Science, the former Senator Webster, and Mr Newman, the then Minister for National Development, regarding the Great Barrier Reef and whether oil drilling permits had been delaying the declaration of a section of the Reef as a marine park. Contradictory answers were received, which caused some embarrassment even to this Government. Five hours later Mr Newman came back into the House of Representatives and said that the answer he gave was not correct because he had not heard the question properly. He did not explain why it took him five hours to discover why he had not heard the question properly. The truth was published in the National Times of 6 October 1979 under Stuart Simson's byline. The article gave some background information on Mr Newman and indeed detailed circumstances in which Mr Newman was with a group of journalists late one night in Charlie's Restaurant in Canberra. The article states:

One of the matters on which Newman bared his soul was his dramatic change of story on the proposed Barrier Reef National Park in May. Newman took the politically unusual step of changing from the right story to the wrong story.
His action severely damaged his credibility but, he confided to his breathless Charlie's audience, probably saved the Government.
The article goes on to state that Newman and Webster gave different answers to Parliament and that he realised something was wrong after he gave his answer. The article continues-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance brought on by the Australian Labor Party to interrupt the General Business because it is regarded by its movers as a matter of extraordinary and great importance. What we have heard to support its argument is a reiteration of what has been said in the media, in this chamber and in the other place, and what was said time and again in previous attacks by some of the same speakers about a matter which I should have thought was dealt with finally by the very heavy penalty paid by two Ministers concerned. We should perhaps, as this matter has been raised, ask: 'What is this question of ministerial responsibility and what are the obligations of Ministers when they assume that high office in this country?'

SPEECH.PARA: The first point to be made is that it is a convention. The doctrine of ministerial responsibility does not exist in a written form but rather it exists by convention. It is not legally enforceable but is a matter of the utmost good faith. I shall refer to the matter of the utmost good faith a little later. It is said to relate primarily to official activities, and to the responsibility of a Minister for the policies which he adopts. Perhaps the best example in recent times that can be given is the regrettable incident in the United Kingdom, at Westminster, involving the resignation of Lord Carrington as Foreign Minister in the Thatcher Government. Lord Carrington, I believe, upheld the very finest traditions of the Westminster principle, the doctrine of ministerial responsibility. Whilst saying that he did not believe he was culpable, he believed that the policy was demonstrably wrong in the events which transpired and that he as the Minister must accept the responsibility and resign. One of the finest Foreign Ministers in Britain's history and in the world today was forced to resign under this principle. I believe that if we have a further look at ministerial responsibility we will see that its nature has changed somewhat with the growth in the size of government. We find that some authors suggest that the convention-that is the doctrine of ministerial responsibility-has become ineffective. One author stated:

Without examining all these factors in detail . . . ministerial responsibility developed in an age of limited government, when government responsibilities were restricted, when departments were small enough for the minister to be in close contact with his officials and when departments were responsible for administering a small number of relatively straight forward statutes. Today the scale of these operations has enlarged enormously, sufficently so in fact to question whether it is reasonable to hold a minister personally responsible for administrative errors.
The author also claimed:
. . . a minister's ability to defy critics with the aid of his party may often outweigh Parliament's capacity to dismiss a minister even when the circumstances warrant dismissal.
The article further states:
. . . the secretive habits of modern government increase the minister's chance to evade Parliamentary scrutiny.

I think they are important words because brought before us today, at the behest of the Opposition, is a comparison between the behaviour in 1972 to 1975 of the Australian Labor Party Government under Mr Whitlam and the behaviour of the present coalition Government. I think it is important to acknowledge that there has been a change in the general view with regard to ministerial responsibility, but there is still behind it a belief that there must be, so far as Ministers are concerned, the utmost good faith, that standards of behaviour must be of the highest. What do we find? We find that the former Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar, resigned not because of action taken by him as Minister but because of what has been described in the Age editorial as minor acts of foolishness. The editorial of the Australian newspaper describes the matter as one which may 'itself appear trifling'.

I am not trying to suggest that the Ministers should not have resigned. I believe that they properly resigned. I believe it is that demonstration of the utmost good faith which has been demonstrated in this case by these two Ministers who, for what is described by two of the leading newspapers in Australia as acts of foolishness or matters of a trifling nature, did do what is expected under that convention should be done by a Minister where there has been fault on his or her part. What happened in 1974 and 1975? As Senator Durack stated we tried to drag out little by little some honest answers but they were not forthcoming from a government that preferred to cover up the iniquities, the deceit and the deception which was practised during that time.

Let me compare bringing in a television set which was dutiable-because it was colour; it would not have been dutiable if it had been black and white-with attempting to bring in half a million dollars of hot money from some shonkey, revolutionary regime in the Middle East. Let us compare that and see the comparison in standards of behaviour. Let us compare the Khemlani affair--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did anyone make a dollar out of it? Was there ever a prospect that the Minister would make a dollar out of it? Answer that, because that is relevant to the moral credibility of your case.

—Senator Evans asks: Was there any prospect that anyone would make a dollar out of it? All I can say is that if Mr Whitlam and the others who were involved in the Iraqi breakfast affair did not think that they were going to get some advantage out of it, why did they attend and why did the negotiations take place? The second point I want to make concerns a matter about which there was a cover up, in which there was deception and there was a misleading of the Parliament, and that is the matter which became known as the Khemlani affair. I think it is still sufficiently clear in the minds of the average Australian for me not to need to remind them in detail about what was involved-the way in which there was deception, the way in which the Minutes of the Executive Council were not properly dealt with, the way in which there were refusals to answer, wrong answers and misleading answers. Let me just compare that with the matter which has been brought up today by the Opposition. Two Ministers, for what has been described by those newspapers as an extremely trifling matter, displaying the highest possible principles, have in fact resigned. Yet that Government, between 1972 and 1975 to which I have referred had to be dragged screaming out of its office. It would not resign. It did not do the decent thing, having been found out, eventually, for what it had been doing.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe we should not be taking the time of this chamber this afternoon discussing these matters. I believe they have been dealt with. The Ministers concerned have paid a very high price. They have paid a proper price but a very high price, a price which the ALP when in government, was not prepared to pay and a standard of behaviour which it was not prepared to observe. I believe we should be getting on with debating some of the important matters which are facing this country, matters about which apparently the Labor Party has no real concern, matters which it is prepared to put aside whilst it raises something that one would think has been, relatively speaking, done to death in the past few days.

Let us get on with discussing questions of superannuation, the problems of interest rates and the effect that they are having on small business, on home building, on home purchase and all the other problems that arise from that. Let us get on with the question of the development of the possibility of tax cuts within our economy. Let us get on with the question of how we can increase productivity in this country to enable us to pay for the welfare programs, the defence programs and in particular the tax cuts which so many people believe are necessary. Let us get on with the debate about industrial relations and how we can overcome some of the real problems that are so demonstrable to every Australian so far as that field is concerned. There are a number of real problems to be debated. For members of the Labor Party to rehash again today a matter which has been dealt with, and dealt with according to the finest standards of the doctrine of ministerial responsibility, is, I believe, to demonstrate the paucity of the argument available to them about matters of real importance to this country. So that those who are interested in that can get on with the debate in relation to it, I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ELECTRICITY SUPPLY EMERGENCY ORDERS GUIDELINES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Paper and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 35D (2) of the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Act 1962, I present the guidelines for the drafting of electricity supply emergency orders . I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —These guidelines have been prepared in accordance with section 35D (1) of the Act which provides that the Minister may, by instrument in writing, make guidelines to be applied by the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority in making emergency orders pursuant to section 35C of the Act. The Authority may only make emergency orders where the Minister has declared that an electricity supply emergency exists in the Territory. The emergency orders must comply with the guidelines, which are required to be laid before each House of Parliament and are subject to disallowance within a period of five sitting days. The guidelines do not come into force until after the five sitting days and the Authority cannot make emergency orders until the guidelines are in force.

SPEECH.PARA: During the debate on the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Amendment Act 1982, the honourable member for Canberra, Mrs Kelly, and Senator Chipp indicated that there should be public input into the framing of the guidelines. The guidelines were referred to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, and at its meeting held on 14 April 1982, the Assembly agreed to them without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventy-second report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The purpose of this report is to acquaint the Senate with the Committee's consideration of the Public Assemblies Ordinance, contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 10 of 1982 and made under the Seat of Government Administration Act 1910. One important reason for presenting the report is to enable substantive debate to take place which the Senate Committee regards as socially innovatory and affecting fundamental rights and liberties. The Committee has taken this step in accordance with the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs that ordinances of this nature should be the subject of substantive debate. I point out that today Senator Ryan gave notice of disallowance which will, in any event, bring this Ordinance on for substantive debate.

The report reminds the Senate of the undertakings from the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) following the Committee's consideration of the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981, which gave rise to the most unusual proceedings followed by the Committee in relation to this legislation. The Committee, during the period October 1981 to March 1982, examined working papers and successive drafts of the proposed ordinance at eight meetings and examined the final instrument on 20 April 1982 in accordance with its normal procedures. In the course of its examination, the Committee had detailed discussions with officers of the Department of the Capital Territory and the Attorney-General's Department on four occasions. The Committee also met with the Select Committee on Public Assemblies of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. A copy of the Select Committee's report is tabled for the information of honourable senators. The Committee draws the attention of the Senate to the objects of the Ordinance contained in section 3 which states:
(a) to recognize the right of peaceful assembly in accordance with article 21 of the Covenant-
That is, the International Convenant on Civil and Political Rights-

(b) in conformity with that Article, to ensure, to the greatest extent that is practicable, that persons in the Territory enjoy the freedom to participate in public assemblies subject only to such restrictions as are necessary in the interests of public order and safety or to protect the rights and freedoms of other persons,
and this Ordinance shall be construed accordingly.

The Committee has determined that the Ordinance does not offend against the principles under which it operates and will take no action in relation to it. The full text of the Ordinance together with the explanatory notes provided to the Committee, are attached as an appendix to the report. As the report indicates, the Committee has been engaged in a unique exercise in considering this Ordinance and now lays its report before the Senate to enable debate to take place. That completes my statement as Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, but I wish to mention one other matter in relation to the Public Assemblies Ordinance simply as a Government senator. It seems to me that there is one fundamental question in relation to assemblies, that is, whether participation in an assembly should be limited or unlimited. The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which is attached to the report, states:

The right of peaceful assembly shall be recognised. No restrictions may be placed on the exercise of this right other than those imposed in conformity with the law and which are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security or public safety, public order . . . the protection of public health or morals or the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.

This Ordinance has been tabled by the Minister but was prepared with a great deal of input by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, a bipartisan Committee which contributed an enormous amount of work along with the officers of both the Department of the Capital Territory and the Attorney- General's Department.
