The Ordinance certainly reflects a majority view of the members of the Committee.

I turn to the fundamental question which I mentioned before and that is whether participation in an assembly should be limited or unlimited. That is the kernel of what it is all about. The International Covenant provides that assemblies should be unlimited except in those circumstances which it sets out. But if we have unlimited participation, which I understand some members of the Senate would prefer, then it must be up to the police on the day of the event to resolve any disputation. With unlimited participation there is the possibility that there will be major conflict and major disputation on the day of the event. One could envisage a situation in which some person perhaps dresses in a uniform which is offensive to others. He could maintain his silence while dressed in this uniform and, therefore, create no disturbance which would enable him to be arrested or in some other way taken away from the assembly. Yet the mere presence of him in that uniform could create an enormous disturbance to others who are trying to utilise their right of peaceful assembly. That is just the sort of disturbance which might occur on any day.

The alternative to unlimited participation is to determine disputes before the event. The only way in which a dispute can be determined before the event is if, in some way or other, there is an application to someone to enable people to participate in the event and that application has been resolved. That is the procedure which has been adopted in the Australian Capital Territory by the Government and which, in fact, has been suggested by the Committee. In other words, the only way in which a dispute can be determined in relation to a particular event before the event takes place is if a course of action is taken similar to that adopted under this Public Assemblies Ordinance.

In order to ensure that those who wish to participate in an event have the weakest possible limitation on their right to assemble the Ordinance provides, firstly, for the Commissioner of Police to make a determination in relation to those who have applied to participate and he is bound to take into consideration a number of things. Secondly, if any person or group who has applied is dissatisfied with the Commissioner's determination that person or group has a right to apply to a Supreme Court judge and the application will be heard de novo. The court has to apply the same principles as those which are set out for the Commissioner to apply. With all due respect to the people who have indicated publicly that they will speak and who I anticipate will speak in this place against this proposal, I cannot imagine anything which could be fairer than the resolution of these disputes before the event takes place by, firstly, the Commissioner of Police who does not have an unlimited discretion but who has to take into account certain matters which are set out in the Public Assemblies Ordinance, which could not be fairer. Secondly, if people are not satisfied with that they have the right to apply to a Supreme Court judge with a completely fresh application, not as a matter of appeal on a point of law or any such thing , but with the Supreme Court judge having a completely unlimited discretion except insofar as he must apply his decision in relation to the principles espoused in the Ordinance. I cannot imagine anything which would be fairer. The alternative to this, as I have said, is to have unlimited participation, which would mean that the police would have to resolve the conflicts on the day and at the place. I do not see unlimited participation as in any way advancing the civil liberties of people involved in the matter. On the contrary I suggest that it is the road to anarchy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on the report brought down by the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on the Australian Capital Territory Public Assemblies Ordinance. I will say at the outset that the Senate is indebted to the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee. What I have to say subsequently is not fundamentally a criticism of this Committee of the Senate or its work. It is rather a criticism of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) who has created in this Territory an intolerable situation surrounding what is certainly one of the most important days of the year. Speaking as an Australian Capital Territory senator I must say that I very much regret what happened with the commemoration of Anzac Day in this Territory last year. Now it appears to be the case that the commemoration of Anzac Day in the Australian Capital Territory this coming weekend will be an occasion of difficulty, of tension within the community and of polarisation of community groups. We would have avoided all these things if we could have. All of these things, I believe, are directly the result of the incompetent actions of the Minister for the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis has given us an account of the work of the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee in respect of this Public Assemblies Ordinance. Certainly it is true that that Committee sought, and I think achieved, some improvements to the Ordinance, but the Ordinance is still fundamentally unacceptable. I said that I am not critical of the work of the Committee and that we are indebted to it for the effort it has put into considering this Ordinance. However, I must say that I am critical of and I fundamentally reject its ultimate conclusion. I disagree with Senator Lewis. I believe the Ordinance does trespass unduly on personal liberties. However, I will not go into my specific criticisms of the Ordinance at this stage because, as Senator Lewis has pointed out, I have given notice of a disallowance motion in relation to this Ordinance which I will move at the earliest opportunity. That will be the occasion for me and other honourable senators who support me in this move to go into detail about the unsatisfactory legal and civil liberties aspects of the Ordinance. However, I want to make a couple of general comments now.

Senator Lewis has given us an account of the development of this Ordinance from the time last year when the Minister for the Capital Territory, Michael Hodgman, wrote to the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee asking it not to disallow last year's Ordinance-although by implication he admitted a number of inadequacies in it-on the grounds that he undertook to develop a new ordinance and to make that ordinance available to the locally elected body for consultation with the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee. He gave other undertakings. The letter that he wrote to the Committee is recorded in the Senate Hansard of 14 May 1981. I will not take the time of the Senate by reading it now. My criticism of the Minister is fundamentally that he did not keep to the terms that he undertook to meet in that letter. Yes, he did develop a new ordinance, but he introduced it at such a late stage, at a date so close to the Anzac Day memorial service, that there was not adequate time for public discussion of the ordinance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you see that we started to consider it in October of last year?

—Yes, there was an earlier draft, but the House of Assembly received it only at the end of February and had to conduct a very hasty public inquiry. Had the Minister been sincere in his attempts to involve the community in the development of this very important Ordinance he would have made a draft available to the House of Assembly much earlier than the end of February this year. As it was, public discussion could not take place. I, as an Australian Capital Territory senator, could not answer the queries that my constituents kept bringing to me. Various organisations and various individuals kept asking me: 'What are we going to do about Anzac Day? What law is going to prevail with regard to the holding of the Anzac Day memorial service? What do we do if we wish to participate?' These queries from my constituents were genuine. I could not answer them. I am not a member of the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee.
—You could not answer them if you had been.

—As the Chairman of the Committee rightly points out, I could not answer the queries anyway because all the Committee had was a series of working drafts. So the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory did not know where they stood. They did not know what restrictions would be placed on their rights to assemble, their rights to march and their rights to commemorate Anzac Day in the way they choose. They did not know what their rights would be. The whole planning and organisation for Anzac Day this year has been in a vacuum. It has been chaotic. The Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee finalised its view only a few days ago.
—That is when it is tabled. You see, it was tabled only today. We can consider it only when it is tabled.

—The honourable senator is supporting my case. He is saying that we can consider the report only when it is tabled. We can consider it only today. When is the Anzac Day memorial service to be held? It is to be held this weekend . Why was the Ordinance not completed and tabled six months ago so that there could be proper understanding, proper criticism and proper debate?
—It was made public in February.

—The honourable senator interjects constantly but whatever he says cannot alter the fact that the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory have been given very little time indeed in which to comprehend this Ordinance. The Australian Federal Police, which will have the unfortunate responsibility of implementing this Ordinance, has been given very little time to study it and to work out how it can make it work. I do not think it will be able to. The various groups which have been involved in the whole debate, including the Returned Services League, which requested the very first ordinance, are, I understand, dissatisfied. All the community groups are dissatisfied. We have a situation in which the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory are to be bound by a law which it seems now nobody, except Senator Lewis and the Minister for the Capital Territory, wants. I point out that the House of Assembly, as a result of the public inquiry it was able to conduct, has recommended that the Ordinance not be proceeded with. He produced a report with which I think Senator Lewis was presented.
—That was a sub-committee of three Labor members of the House of Assembly.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I ask that you give some protection to the speaker. The interruptions that are being made are quite unseemly.
—There is no point of order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to speak to the point of order. I recall that there was no interruption at all while Senator Lewis was speaking, despite some of the provocative remarks that he was making. I ask that you apply the Standing Orders, despite the noise from the other side, to protect honourable senators who are making contributions to this debate.
—There is no point of order. Strictly, under the Standing Orders all interjections are unruly and out of order.

—The House of Assembly concluded that it was of the view that the proposed Ordinance would represent a serious and unwarranted infringement of civil liberties and set out the detailed reasons. It said that a more general reason related to the complexity of some of the procedures which are laid down under the Ordinance. These, it believes, would present a major obstacle to the exercise of the right of free public assembly in the Australian Capital Territory. It is all very well for Senator Lewis to give the Senate a lawyer's view of the alternatives available to the legislature in these circumstances. What I, as a representative of the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory, am concerned about is that we have an Ordinance which satisfies nobody and which very few people can understand. It is so badly formulated and contains so many confusing aspects that a citizen picking it up to see how he or she should behave if he or she wished to participate on Anzac Day would not receive any illumination at all. For that reason alone it is a bad Ordinance. As I said, I will not at this stage go into the technicalities of my objection to the Ordinance. I will do that when I move the motion of disallowance.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very disappointed that Senator Lewis has presented the Senate with a report from a most prestigious Committee of this place that amounts to a whitewash job on the behaviour of the Minister for the Capital Territory. The Minister for the Capital Territory gave certain undertakings to the Committee and thus to the Senate. He did not fulfil those undertakings. Through his negligent and incompetent behaviour he has created a most unfortunate situation for the Australian Capital Territory community. I ask honourable senators to consider that. It is not a matter that will affect their own electorates, but citizens of the Australian Capital Territory simply do not know how they will be able to behave on Anzac Day. I am sure that the Federal Police does not know how it is going to try to enforce this Ordinance. People know that their rights have been restrained and constricted under this Ordinance but they do not know precisely in what way. Some groups which have applied to participate on Anzac Day have been refused permission whereas others have got it. The reasons for the distinction between the applications are not clear to the general community.

I conclude by saying that we have a chaotic situation in which many people's rights, including the rights of people who want a traditional Anzac Day observance, are being eroded in a very serious way. The responsibility is that of the Minister for the Capital Territory, Michael Hodgman. I recognise and acknowledge that the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee made serious efforts to resolve some of the difficulties. Its efforts, in my view, were not successful. I will attempt to have this Ordinance disallowed. However, it is not likely that that will happen before Anzac Day. It seems that we are to be faced with all sorts of community problems on Anzac Day. The effect of this law will be the very opposite of what a law ought to do. It is a most unfortunate situation and I very much regret it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which dealt with this matter over the last few months. I wish just briefly to mention my position. As other members of the Committee would know, I disagreed with the Committee's involvement in this matter. I was not convinced-I am still not convinced-that it is yet proper for the Regulations and Ordinances Committee to help to draft regulations and ordinances. Being a relatively new member of that Committee I ended up going along with its procedure in co-operating with the Government in having discussions with officers of the Department of the Capital Territory and of the Attorney-General's Department in an effort to improve the initial drafts. I agree with Senator Ryan's criticism of the Government in that the departments and the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) in particular were slow in commencing work on this Ordinance. The matter had been a problem from almost this time last year, but it was not until October or November that an initial draft was provided to the Committee. That is the time which can be most criticised. A lot of work has been done since but, in view of the fact that everybody knew that the revised Ordinance had to be provided for this time of the year, a lot more work should have been done sooner rather than being in a position where the first draft was available only shortly before the end of the sittings before Christmas.

SPEECH.PARA: I disagree with the fact that the Committee became involved to the extent that it did. I have a feeling that it really ought to be a matter of the Government, within its own counsels, determining its position, providing the Ordinance, tabling it and then the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the Parliament as a whole determining their attitude to it. I have to acknowledge that the Committee's involvement improved in many respects, the various drafts provided by the Department.

Many aspects of the Ordinance were totally unsatisfactory. I think it has been improved a great deal. No other Ordinance has been gone through with such a fine tooth-comb as this one. Perhaps it is just as well that not every piece of legislation is drafted as thoroughly as this one. That is not to say that I agree with the Ordinance as it has been made and tabled. Aspects of it can be criticised in general terms, such as the unwieldly procedure and the possible costliness, which I gather is even objected to by the Returned Services League, in access to the appeal procedures. I guess one cannot object to the principles of the appeal procedures provided for. I still have some objections to certain sections, such as section 6 and section 24. I will not go into this aspect now as there will be another debate on this matter when Senator Ryan's motion for disallowance is considered.

My main objection to the Ordinance is the inclusion of the limited participation provisions. I point out that the limited participation proposal was not included in some of the earlier drafts; it was something which was included part way through the consideration. I make the point that the question of availability of limited participation is the wrong way round, if it is to be applied at all. Senator Lewis argued in favour of all marches being of limited participation. The basis of his argument was that because definition of people and classes of people who could be included were better able to be sorted out in advance so that everyone knew where they stood rather than it being open slather , that system ought to be available to everybody. That was the way he was arguing. He did not raise an argument which explained why limited participation should be available only on days of special significance. He talked in terms of determined disputes before the event.

I have a problem on the question of limited participation per se. If this is able to be justified, all the procedures for limited participation as far as I am concerned should be available for everyone and for all marches. I would have thought that there was more argument for it being available for a more private march for a particular section of the community demonstrating its point of view than for a march or a demonstration which was of more national significance. Section 4 defines a 'day of special significance', as meaning Canberra Day, Anzac Day or as sub-section (c) states:
a day declared under section 5 to be a day of special significance for the purposes of this Ordinance.
Section 5, sub-section 1 states:

Where the Minister is of the opinion that a day is a day of national, historic, religious or social significance or solemnity to or for the people of Australia, the community in the Territory or a section of that community, he may, by notice published in the Gazette not later than 21 days before that day, declare that day to be a day of special significance for the purposes of this Ordinance.

It strikes me that, if a day is of such national importance, it is precisely that sort of day which ought to be more available for everyone to participate in if it is to be a national day, a day of special significance, rather than be limited. We have a situation where it is precisely that sort of day which is to be limited to marches which perhaps involve a mere section of the community expressing a particular ideological or very limited point of view. They are the ones which will not be able to be limited to those people who have that point of view, but will be open to anyone who wishes to participate. I make those comments at this stage. I will reserve further comments for the debate on the disallowance motion when it arises next week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is more in sorrow than in anger that I make the point that for the second year in a row the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is in real danger of losing its credibility as one of the most hitherto respected Senate committees. It is a committee which has traditionally acted without regard to party political considerations, which has looked at the merits of delegated legislation by reference to civil liberty criteria, and when delegated legislation has been manifestly offensive, has reported and recommended disallowance accordingly. That has been the tradition of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee ever since it was founded in 1932. That is the tradition which has made this Committee the model for so many similar exercises in legislative scrutiny in other countries around the parliamentary world. But that Committee will only preserve its credibility if it produces reports which have regard-much more seriously than I suspect this particular report does-to the true merits of the legislation before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it impossible to believe that this Committee could come to the conclusion that the Australian Capital Territory Public Assemblies Ordinance 1982, now reported to us as not deserving of any condemnation at all by the Senate, does not unduly trespass on the rights and liberties of the subject. It is a manifestly unacceptable piece of delegated legislation by any civil liberty standards and certainly by the standards of the Committee as they have been applied over several parliamentary generations. I am prepared to believe that the Committee struggled for a long time to improve the original legislative model that was put before it by the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) some considerable time ago. I am prepared to believe that the Committee did make a number of quite genuine attempts to improve that legislation.

I readily acknowledge, as Senator Ryan has before me, that at least the product we have before us now has fewer holes numerically and quantitatively, than the original draft which was abominable beyond belief. I acknowledge that the Committee, to that extent, has played a positive and constructive role. But I find it difficult to credit the Committee's role in the final conclusion that it has come to after adding up the merits, such as they are, and the many more obvious demerits of this legislation. It has chosen to recommend to the Senate that this piece of delegated legislation does not offend the traditional criteria. I find it difficult to credit that that was a conclusion that could responsibly or sensitively have been reached by any group of legislators, let alone those constituting this particular highly respected Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you looked at the law?
—I have looked at the law very closely indeed.
—Have you bothered to read the Ordinance?

—I have bothered to read the Ordinance very closely indeed, Senator Lewis. I will not, because of the nature of this parliamentary occasion, which is simply to respond to the report that has been put down by the Committee and not to deal with the question of the disallowance of the Ordinance, go into any great detail as to the many defects of this legislation as I perceive them and as we on this side of the chamber perceive them. I will say only that which is sufficient to indicate the range and the diversity of the objections which, I believe, can legitimately be made-not from a party political viewpoint but on an objective commitment to basic principles-to this legislation. I hope that an early opportunity will arise to proceed with the disallowance motion which was moved by Senator Ryan.

SPEECH.PARA: There appears to be some uncertainty as to whether procedurally it will be possible, given the nature of our business tomorrow, to bring this matter on for debate tomorrow. There is a further difficulty in that if the debate were called on tomorrow and the disallowance motion were to be passed, we do not at the moment have a provision in our law whereby any pre-existing ordinance would leap back into life. We would to that extent have something in the nature of a legislative vacuum governing the Anzac Day march as it is to operate on Sunday. I think that argument can be very much overstated because there is quite a considerable amount of statutory authority vested in police officers under traffic Acts and other pieces of Australian Capital Territory legislation, not to mention the traditional common law powers, to deal with unlawful assemblies, breakers of the peace and so on that may still be available and applicable to govern this event on Sunday. I think it will add even more confusion and uncertainty to an already very confused and uncertain situation were the law, as it were, to be snatched out from under the feet of those trying to administer it on this coming weekend. It may be better as a result-I still have an open mind on this subject-for the debate on the disallowance of this matter to proceed in a more calm and reasoned way when the immediate context in which it will be applied is over.

Let me simply say rather quickly what I perceive to be the major problems with this Ordinance. I think they fall into four main categories. Briefly, they are as follows. The first problem is simply that the Ordinance was not approved by the Australian Capital Territory House of As- sembly. That is an important consideration. Not only was it not approved; it has been manifested and directly disapproved. If we are to have any sensitivity to the principles--

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it rejected?

—It was rejected, on a close vote, but it was rejected. After a proper scrutiny by a committee-admittedly hastily-it was rejected. If we are to adopt the principles of respect for the institution of local self-government, such as they are in the Territory, I think we should take that very seriously indeed. That is perhaps not a conclusive ground for the Senate acting to disallow anything but it is certainly something that should weigh very strongly indeed and should have weighed, to my mind, much more strongly in the views of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, it is the case that this Ordinance-I will not go into any of its procedural detail-is complex and confusing in the extreme. Moreover, as a result of that complexity and the various procedures and counter-procedures that are built into the Ordinance, it will be extremely expensive to apply from the point of view of those organisations whose rights to demonstrate or whatever depend on its application. So much was demonstrated, I understand, earlier this week when the RSL, which one would not have thought to be a peculiarly impecunious organisation, found itself unable to justify to its members the cost of appealing to the Supreme Court, as the terms of the Ordinance allow it to do, against the decision of the Police Commissioner to allow various other non-RSL organisations to march. If that is the case for the RSL how much more obviously is it the case for the litter of voluntary organisations around the place, usually with not a penny to save themselves with, which are likely to be the main bodies to which an ordinance of this kind will have immediate application. The rights thus created are to that extent illusory because on any view they require money for them to be exercised through the procedures of the courts. There are many more things that can be said about that but I will leave that to the proper occasion of the scrutiny of the detailed terms of the Ordinance itself.

The third area of objection to this Ordinance must be the very peculiar concept that it creates of the so-called limited participation assembly. I very briefly indicate the grounds of objection to this concept as it is embodied in this Ordinance. They are as follows: First of all, there is the fact that this has essentially been devised as a way of achieving the goal of making special legislative provision for Anzac Day. Rather than just letting the Anzac Day march be treated on its merits like any other public assembly, special provision has been made for Anzac Day and such other days, including Canberra Day, to be the subject of special gazettal and notification to that effect. This is in breach of the clear expression of ministerial intention which was offered publicly a year ago that any re-write of the manifestly unacceptable Anzac Day Ordinance that we debated last year would not specifically deal with the Anzac Day situation but would be a public assembly law of general application. But what we have here now is simply another Anzac Day Ordinance, a not very effective one, dressed up in generalised clothing. The Minister to that extent, I believe, has not honoured his statement of intention.

There are also conceptual problems of the kind that were referred to by my colleague Senator Coates in relation to the very concept of a limited participation assembly, particularly when it is made clear that the limited participation assemblies are primarily to be those kinds of assemblies like Anzac Day and Canberra Day which hitherto have been regarded as of significance to the community as a whole not just some particular sectional interest within it. It is odd, is it not, that the very assemblies which from that point of view ought to be most accessible to the community at large, most open to popular participation, are the very assemblies which under this delegated legislation are the most closed off to such access? There is that conceptual problem. I think it has to be grappled with. Also a problem in relation to this limited participation assembly concept is the obvious difficulty it will create in its practical application. We have seen the bizzare situation during this week when eight or nine groups, at last count, had applied for permission from the Police Commissioner to join this limited participation assembly-to join, in other words , the ranks of the RSL in marching on that particular demonstrative occasion. We have had a situation in which the Commissioner of Police has let in some groups and excluded others by applying-no doubt very genuinely and sincerely-the statutory criteria that are open to him. But how on earth will the working policeman on the ground next Sunday in the context of Anzac Day distinguish between those individuals who, on the one hand, are members of or associated with the Interim Committee for the Council of Civil Liberties in the Australian Capital Territory who are allowed to march and on the other hand those who are members of the Australian Capital Territory Committee for the Defence of Human Rights? What will distinguish the individuals? Will it be their dress, their mode of behaviour, their hair cuts, their beards or the length of their trousers ? What will it be? How will the police make those sorts of distinctions? A potentially nightmarish situation has been created. Many more things could be said about that. They will be said in the context of the further debate on this Ordinance. No doubt we will be debating this in the context of what happens-I hope that nothing happens-next Sunday although all the indications are that a shambles can be contemplated as a result of the operation of this Ordinance.

The remaining point I simply make about the limited participation concept is that I think the only real utility that comes through from the concept itself as it appears in the legislation is the requirement that it, in effect, imposes some sort of prior notification of the intention of non-mainstream groups to join the mainstream on a demonstrative occasion. I think it is important that the police, so far as is possible, have prior notification so that they can plan the occasion accordingly and anticipate difficulties accordingly. I argue that what is a benefit--

TALK.START.PARA: —I wouldn't agree with that.

—Maybe not, Senator Chipp, but that is a concept which has been accepted in other cities in other parts of Australia which has really worked quite well. A voluntary notification system has operated in Melbourne since the troubled days of the city square and the Melbourne City Council's overreaction to various demonstrations in the late 1960s and early 1970s. That has worked well, and essentially--
—That assumes a benign and responsible police force.

—That is true. Of course, I am not saying that conduct should be criminal which is not the subject of a prior notification. I am saying that it should be removed altogether from the ambit of the language of the statutory law and that there should be introduced, so far as possible, a voluntary system of prior notification rather than the compulsory permit system that is enshrined in this particular legislation. It is a permit system which goes further than any comparable permit system in any other jurisdiction in the Western world of which I am aware.

SPEECH.PARA: Many other things can be said about this. However, I think the best way the public assemblies law can proceed so far as these sorts of occasions are concerned is by this voluntary concept of prior notification not being reflected in the actual terms of the legislation, with the legislation itself simply being couched in such a way as to enable the police to deal properly and effectively with the mischief to which the limited participation concept is directed, the mischief being the possible provocation-response situation that can arise when groups with competing interests and beliefs mingle in a public demonstration. That is the mischief that has to be anticipated in legislation of this kind and it is proper that there be legislative guidelines to deal with that.

The failure of this legislation to deal with that kind of situation is the substance of my fourth and final objection to this Ordinance. Here I am referring to what I think is the extremely objectionable language of clause 24 of this Ordinance dealing with breaches of the peace, a section of the Ordinance which was manifestly designed to deal with the classic public order problem of provocation response-Orangemen versus Catholics on St Patrick's Day; Nazis and Jews perhaps, to take an example which was made notorious in London's East End in the 1930s and which provoked legislation there; Vietnam demonstrators and those supporting the Vietnam war, the kind of situation which for a time at least was relevant in public order law in the 1960s here in Australia; the RSL marches--

TALK.START.PARA: —Black and white.

—Black and white indeed, as Senator Button said. It has been a week for black and white matters of all kinds, and where more appropriate than here? A further example, of course, is RSL marches and the attempts to march of those who are likely, for good reason or ill, actually to offend the ranks of the RSL marchers in question. A legitimate public order problem has to be anticipated and, I think, has to be dealt with. But I think the way in which clause 24 deals with this is just outrageous because it makes explicitly criminal and subject to sanctions not only conduct which is motivated by an intention to cause a breach of the peace but also conduct which is merely likely to cause a breach of the peace, without more. Of course, as I argued in the context of last year's ordinance and as I will argue until I am red in the face in the context of this year's ordinance, that creates a situation in which a person, however benignly motivated and however anxious merely to express a point of view, who provokes an irrational, outraged response from an indignant RSL marche or anyone else can be hauled off and subject to criminal penalty. That is the way in which the Ordinance operates at the moment. It is manifestly unsatisfactory to the extent that that is so.

SPEECH.PARA: It can be fixed up, as I would hope the Committee in its wisdom would have suggested, by adding additional criteria in those breach of the peace provisions to ensure that the conduct of the provocateur, if you like, is such as to be actually offensive and insulting and, more importantly still, to be objectively offensive and insulting. By the latter, I mean that a reasonable person-not just a person in the position of a peculiarly sensitive marcher-would be offended by it. If the Ordinance had in it language of that kind, which has become traditional in more enlighted public law legislation in various other jurisdictions, this problem could be cured. But so long as it remains uncured this Ordinance will create far more difficulties than it can solve. It will remain manifestly unacceptable by reference to any kind of enlightened civil libertarian principles and, I think, unworkable by reference to the public order principles that it is quite proper for the Australian Capital Territory authorities and the police force to want to be able to apply.

I am sorry that I have spoken rather longer than I intended to at this stage, but even so that has merely opened up the matter. I am delighted that Senator Lewis at least showed some superficial signs, whatever was going on inside his head-of which I am never quite sure-of listening intently to what I was saying. I hope that even Senator Lewis may not be beyond redemption so far as exercising some sensitivity in a civil liberties area is concerned. I hope that when we come to the more extended debate of this matter we will be able to approach it calmly and rationally and reach the conclusion, as a result, that this is an unacceptable Ordinance and must be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the concern expressed by Senator Evans and Senator Ryan. I join with them in saying that I would have been happier had the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances 'fixed it up', to use Senator Evans's words. That is not necessarily to criticise Senator Lewis and his Committee because, as I understand it, he and his Committee had very little time in which to contemplate such a vexed and complicated question. To begin with I would like to be vigorously critical of the Government-I am sure that Senator Lewis, had he free rein, would be as critical as I am-for waiting so long before bringing down such a controversial ordinance to be contemplated by the national Parliament. We will not forget the monstrous and boorish ordinance brought down by Mr Hodgman about this time last year.
—What would you expect from Mr Hodgman?
—Do not knock him. He got 27 votes in the Liberal Party's deputy leadership contest. That caused a great series of divisions in this community.
—The 22 votes?

—No, not his getting 22 votes. The Ordinance of last year caused great division in the Canberra community, as Senator Lewis knows. Because the matter was debated in the national Parliament it caused divisiveness in the nation as a whole and, I believe, brought that precious and sacred day-Anzac Day -into disrepute. This year, instead of having the thing brought forward six months ago, as I understand it, the timetable was that it hit the House of Assembly in Canberra round about February. I regard it as almost unforgiveable that the Government and the Department of the Capital Territory should wait from April last year until February this year before bringing down an ordinance to control a march on Anzac Day. The Assembly, quite properly, believed there should be some public debate on it and it initiated some public debate. But the timescale precluded a proper debate and proper evidence being taken. In any event, finally the Assembly agreed by a small margin to reject the Ordinance, which again indicates its divisiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: I have great sympathy with the Returned Services League in wanting the march to be restricted to members of the RSL or to ex-servicemen. I am an ex-serviceman. I have marched in Anzac Day marches. Even though I did not see action or hear shots fired in anger, I would be offended if facetious people joined that march. I can understand the RSL's apprehension about it. It is different, although not excusable, for a returned soldier, who has seen comrades killed beside him or her, who has seen the actual horrors of war and who marches on a day sacred to him or her to remember his or her fallen comrades, to have that march intruded upon by other groups. I can understand that sort of reluctance on the part of people in the RSL. I have a personal view. I would not mind if Woman Against Rape or someone else, provided they were sincere, joined on to the rear of that march in which I was marching on Anzac Day. But, as I say, I did not suffer- thank God-the horrors suffered by some people in the Army, the Navy and the Air Force. On the other hand I have marched and I have been privileged to lead a number of anti-nuclear and anti-uranium marches. I would not have minded one scrap, in fact I would have welcomed, the pro-nuclear groups joining those marchers, carrying their banners and projecting their signs provided they did it in a peaceful and dignified way. As Senator Evans has said, if such a march were likely to cause an obstruction to traffic, the groups concerned should voluntarily advise the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police or whoever was responsible that they were going to do just that. That is my personal view. If we took a vote in this chamber I think that view would be shared by about half the honourable senators and the other half would be vigorously opposed to it. We are talking about something which is very controversial and very divisive . I think the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, should be condemned for waiting so long to bring before the Parliament such a controversial Ordinance for ratification.

I turn briefly now to the Ordinance. There will be a vote on this matter next week. No doubt all honourable senators will be wanting to contemplate the pros and cons of this Ordinance and will be wanting to debate it more thoroughly. I join with my friend, Senator Evans, in saying that I find it particularly repugnant that the concept of a limited public assembly should be brought into legislation in the national Parliament. More particularly I find it disturbing that a police commissioner, honourable though he might be, broadminded though he might be, should be able to determine whether the purpose of an application to march in an Anzac Day march or any application to participate in a public ceremony is consistent with the purpose for which it was designed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly since he can delegate his powers down to sergeant level.

—At that stage it becomes terrifying, not because sergeants or police constables are less intelligent necessarily than commissioners of police but, because of the reasons that Senator Evans gave, the power is delegated to whoever is on the beat to make an instant decision on the intentions of the person participating in the march. I think that is unfair to the officer and it is unfair to those people participating. I find even more offensive section 13.4 (c) of the report which states that the commissioner has a discretion as to whether there is any likelihood of serious public disorder. He has a discretion as to whether there is a likelihood, in his mind or in his delegate's mind, of serious public disorder. I need only mention that to send chills through any defenders of civil liberties in this country. If that precedent were established I believe it would be a most dangerous occurrence. One shudders when one thinks of how people such as Mr Russell Hinze, that champion of democracy in our northern State, might ask his police force to pursue that policy if that sort of ordinance were introduced by him in Queensland. It concerns me particularly that that kind of legislation could be introduced into the national Parliament without time for proper debate. As I have said, we will have further time, as I understand it, to debate this matter more fully tomorrow or next week. It is a pity that a decision cannot be reached before Anzac Day. I join with Senator Evans and other speakers and say that we hope that on Sunday no incidents of an unpleasant nature occur as a result of or caused by this Ordinance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be a fair amount of misunderstanding by honourable senators on the Opposition benches of the Australian Capital Territory Public Assemblies Ordinance that has been described in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. Senator Evans, Senator Ryan and Senator Chipp have all said that the time within which the Committee had to consider this matter was very short. That is not a fact. We first looked at the working paper on 22 October last year. I do not believe-I do not think anybody else would believe-that that could be considered a short time. We finally got the first draft on 18 February of this year. After all the work which had been done on the working paper after we had received the first draft I believe we were most of the way along the line.

SPEECH.PARA: The public has been aware of this Ordinance since 26 February. Senator Ryan said that the public did not understand it and did not know about it. It has been very clearly put. Anyone wanting to march on Anzac Day has only to apply to have the details spelt out. It is like saying that people do not understand any other legislation and, therefore, the Government should not introduce it. That is a ridiculous statement. Anyone who does not understand this Ordinance has only to go to his parliamentary representative to have it explained. I am sure that Senator Ryan can cover that situation for those of her constituents who may wish to march.

There seems to be tremendous concern on the Opposition benches regarding the rights and the civil liberties of those who want to march on Anzac Day apart from the traditional marchers, apart from the men and women who served their country in time of war who, as Senator Chipp has said, saw the horrors of war and who march on a solemn occasion such as this. This is the traditional day on which they care to remember those who died beside them. Those are the people that honourable senators on the Opposition benches are not thinking about at all . They are interested only in those people who wish to march on that day for different reasons. Senator Evans in his arrogance stands up in this chamber and says that he is the only one in this place who is interested in civil liberties. That is a lot of rubbish. I am particularly interested in the civil liberties of those people who have traditionally marched on 25 April. Those are the people about whom we should be thinking. Members of other groups who wish to march for other reasons but who wish to be associated with those thoughts on war can pick another day. They can march in the evening, the early morning or at some other time that will not interfere with the traditional Anzac march. I have no sympathy for those sorts of people who try to enter this traditional march.

The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police has been ridiculed both by Senator Evans and Senator Chipp as not being the person who should make these decisions. I believe that the police Commissioner is the right person to make these decisions. If any group believes that he is not the right person or that he has not made a decision according to its liking it has the right of appeal to the court. There are certain criteria that the Commissioner must take into consideration. The court takes those same criteria into consideration when it is looking at an appeal.

Senator Evans said that there were three main areas which he found objectionable. The first was that the Legislative Assembly does not agree with this Ordinance. Traditionally the Legislative Assembly has not always had to agree with this place. This Senate is responsible for governing the Australian Capital Territory. We seek the opinion of the Legislative Assembly. We hope that it will be in agreement with us. But that has never been one of the reasons why we have said that we would not agree with it. We have never said that we would back down just because the Legislative Assembly did not agree with us.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Select Committee was not very impartial.

—The Select Committee on Public Assemblies was a committee of Labor Party men and women. I believe that they certainly were not impartial. Secondly, Senator Evans said that as the Legislative Assembly was not in agreement it was all very complex and confusing. Senator Evans said that there is a cost of appeal. There is a cost of appeal. The Committee was concerned that the cost should not be too great. But there is always a cost in an appeal. It is something which one cannot get away from. He spoke then of limited participation and problems with identifying people. That underlines, probably more than anything, the fact that Senator Evans has not studied the Ordinance at all because he would not have been asking those questions if he had. Limited participation and how the people are identified is easily explained because the person putting in the request to march gives an estimate of how many people he intends to have marching in his group. He will be readily able to identify them. There is no particular problem in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan, Senator Evans and Senator Chipp failed to come up with remarks about what they consider the Ordinance should do. I can only presume that they think it should be open slather. Senator Chipp ended by saying that we will not be able to debate this matter before the Anzac Day march and that he hoped that nothing untoward happens. If it were open slather everyone would be marching. The participation last time by the Women Against Rape organisation certainly offended the Returned Services League and many returned men and women. An open slather situaton could only create problems. I think Senator Chipp should understand that. Senator Evans did. He said that there should be some guideline, some indications. He suggested that at the most the police should be notified about who was going to march so that they could cope with the disruption and, perhaps, the violence that could occur if people with different opinions are allowed to march on the same day, at the same time and in the same procession.

We have seen such violence occur in many cities in other countries. Fortunately we have not had a great deal of violence in Australia. There has been some violence in Sydney and Melbourne. We are trying in this place to avoid what happens overseas. Ten years ago there was never a thought in any Australian's mind that people would disrupt an Anzac Day march. Ten years ago thought was never given by any group to daring to march and upset the Anzac Day traditions. Times have changed. We now have radical groups which would like to march and upset the traditional Anzac Day service. I believe that it is the duty and responsibility of government to protect the right to march of people who fought in wars to protect our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aah!

—Senator Evans, in his traditional way, is sighing at the mention of the very men who fought to preserve his right to stand up in this place and say anyone should be able to march and upset their day.
—Don't dramatise.

—Senator Evans is the last person in the world to say 'don't dramatise'. After speaking for two minutes he said that he would not speak for much longer. He spoke for nearly 20 minutes and then apologised to us all because he got a bit carried away. He became intoxicated by his own verbosity. Senator Evans regularly becomes very intoxicated by his own verbosity in this place. We on this side of the chamber have to put up with that. I do not believe for one moment that I am dramatising the situation. I do not believe for one moment that, in referring to the traditional Anzacs or the men who like to remember the Anzacs, I am being too dramatic.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans said that there should be no special day, that Anzac Day should be treated as any other day and if people want to march on that day they should be entitled to do so. The fact that Mr Hodgman has set aside a special day is repugnant to the Opposition and the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Hodgman himself said he would do 12 months ago.

—Senator Evans said that no special day should be set aside. He said that there should be no special law or no special ordinance that deals with the traditional Anzac Day march. Senator Chipp estimated that if a vote were taken the result might be 50-50. It would be nothing like that if a conscience vote were allowed. If the Labor Party did not force its members to vote according to Caucus and if the Australian Democrats were also allowed to vote in the way they chose, the vote would be overwhelmingly in support of the Ordinance . There is nothing further I wish to add. I will speak on this matter again, perhaps tomorrow. Senator Ryan said that she wants to bring the matter forward tomorrow and move for disallowance. I will leave the remainder of my remarks for that occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel I may have been misrepresented by Senator Walters in the earlier part of the debate when, in interjecting on Senator Evans, she suggested to him that he was being critical of his colleagues on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in respect of this matter. Perhaps for the record I should point out that the Committee as a whole decided not to move for the disallowance of this Ordinance but that, within the Committee, I moved for giving notice of disallowance but was unsuccessful. It was a majority decision that led to the Committee's report.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, intervening business be postponed until after consideration of General Business, Order of the Day No. 200.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.
SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Roads Grants Act 1981.
Honourable senators will be aware that the Government made a commitment in June 1980 to provide grants totalling $3,650m under a five year roads program covering the period 1980-81 to 1984-85.
An allocation of $628m has already been provided in 1980-81 under the Roads Grants Act 1980. A further $685 million is currently being provided in 1981-82 under the Roads Grants Act 1981.

The Bill before the Senate will enable grants of $734 million in 1982-83, $778m in 1983-84 and $825m in 1984-85 to be made available over the remaining years of the five year program. The Bill subsumes the amounts appropriated by the Roads Grants Act 1981.

The amounts to be provided in the next three years involve annual increases of 7 per cent in 1982-83, 6 per cent in 1983-84 and 6 per cent in 1984-85. All States and the Northern Territory have been allocated corresponding annual increases in funding. As a result the 1981-82 funding relativities will be maintained through to 1984-85.

When determining the levels of funds to be provided under the five year roads program, the Government intended that the allocations would be firm and final amounts. The Government was not willing to encourage inflationary pressures by building into its expenditure programs open-ended commitments to meet unlimited future cost increases.
However, there is increasing evidence becoming available that the Government's expectations in relation to future cost increases in the roads area are being exceeded.

The Bureau of Transport Economics has recently completed a report on the development of a national road construction price index. The report, which the Minister for Transport tabled on 17 March 1982, indicates that in recent years increases in Commonwealth road grants have not kept up with movements in road building costs.

Therefore, the Government will be examining in the Budget context the scope for the provision of additional road funds. However, it is clearly not possible right now to say what might emerge from this. It needs to be recognised that the Government's deliberations on road funding have to be undertaken in the light of the need for continued overall restraint on the Budget and, within that, the competing funding demands of other Commonwealth programs.
The Bill apportions between road categories on the same basis as in 1981-82 the funds to be provided in each of the next three years.
However, the Commonwealth is not committed to maintaining the existing funding relativities indefinitely.
For instance, a recently released Commonwealth-State officials study shows that there are major deficiencies in our National Highways system in all States.

Furthermore, the most pressing problems are in Queensland and New South Wales. The Minister for Transport recently had the opportunity to examine at first hand the state of the Bruce Highway between Rockhampton and Townsville. He has agreed to a Commonwealth and Queensland officials examination of the feasibility of a jointly funded project to bring the Bruce Highway to an acceptable standard within 10 years.

The Explanatory Memorandum that has been circulated sets out in detail the features of the Bill. The conditions under which Commonwealth assistance is to be provided are identical to those in the Roads Grants Act 1981.
Therefore, I do not propose to deal further with individual sections of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sibraa) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Papers and Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed from 20 April, on motion by Senator Grimes.
That the Senate take note of the papers and the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter was the subject of some debate in the Senate yesterday. In the course of that debate, my colleague Senator Grimes moved that the Senate take note of the papers and the statement. I wish to move an amendment to that motion. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion add:
', and the Senate is of the opinion that a judicial inquiry should be established to inquire into and report on-

(a) whether the proper procedures were followed within the Bureau of Customs and at ministerial level to investigate the importation of the colour television set by the former Minister for Health in October last year and, if not, whether there was a cover-up;
(b) whether a junior officer was victimised for carrying out his duty, both at the point of Customs entry by the former Minister for Health and in the officer' s later complaint;

(c) what actions were taken by the Head of the Department in respect of all matters relating to the former Minister for Health and whether these actions were taken with the knowledge and approval of the Government;

(d) more generally, whether the Bureau is effective in performing its functions and the steps that need to be taken to ensure that it is an effective organisation and carries out its functions under the customs Act;
(e) whether any other Minister was aware or should reasonably have been aware of these matters and failed to take appropriate action.'

The matters which were raised yesterday in the Parliament were, as I think Senator Carrick appropriately put it today, matters of tragic concern to the two Ministers concerned. But they are also of grave concern to the community at large in respect of the procedures which were followed and the investigations which have been conducted into those procedures. What in fact has happened is that two ministers have resigned, presumably because they regard their conduct as reprehensible or because someone else regarded their conduct as reprehensible and inconsistent with the proper approach and standards which should be applied to Ministers. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has indicated that there will be a departmental inquiry into the procedures which were followed by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in relation to the Bureau of Customs .

A number of documents have been tabled in order to put the whole matter beyond doubt. The sad thing about the documents is that they do not put the whole matter beyond doubt. In advancing reasons why the amendment expresses the opinion of the Senate in relation to the establishment of a judicial inquiry, I will deal one by one with the questions which are raised in the paragraphs of the amendment. They go to the crux of the matter because they are questions which have not been answered by the Ministers' resignations, by the statement of the Prime Minister in which he indicated that an internal departmental inquiry will take place or by the tabling of the documents. In fact, there is some doubt whether all the documents have now been tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is your amendment, in general terms, the same as the amendment sought in the other place?

—Yes. In the first of the reasons given for the establishment of a judicial inquiry, the question is raised whether proper procedures were followed within the Bureau of Customs to investigate the importation of the colour television set by the former Minister for Health. The answer to that question, if one can prejudge the findings of a judicial inquiry, is clearly no. The question is then asked whether there was a cover-up. It is not sought to have a judicial inquiry to determine whether there was a cover-up in order to pursue the two Ministers concerned. What is a matter of public concern is that this matter sneaked out publicly as a result of the statements of a particular Customs officer, both to the secretary of his organisation and to the Press, about what had taken place. Even at that stage, after those statements became public knowledge in the Press, there was a very considerable delay in order, in the words of one of the Ministers concerned, that they might determine the exact truth as to what had happened.

SPEECH.PARA: That course of conduct following Mr Mayhew's statements and so on revealed very simply that the procedures to which this part of the amendment refers were not clear. It was not clear precisely what happened. It is clearly suggested and in the minds of large sections of the public, one suspects, that there were attempts to cover up. In essence, apart from a number of details to which I shall refer, this set of documents amounts to the revelation of a tortuous bureaucratic process whereby a colour television became a black and white television.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Transmogrification.

INTERJECT.PARA: Seantor BUTTON-That is what happened in these bureaucratic documents. It is a very interesting question as to who misled whom in that process. If one person has been consistent about the matter, it is quite clear that it is the Customs officer who originally had the conduct of the matter at the point of entry and who maintained that it was a colour television throughout. After that in a tortuous process of-what was the word that Senator Evans used?

TALK.START.PARA: —Transmogrification.
—There has been a strange process of osmosis whereby a colour television-
—Not osmosis, maybe mutation.

—Perhaps the word is 'mutation'. The colour television set became a black and white television set. That set of documents is extraordinary for that reason alone. We think there should be a judicial inquiry into the following of proper procedures or otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: The second element is probably the most crucial of all. What emerges in the course of these documents is the very clear suggestion that a junior officer- this issue has not been resolved-was told to keep his mouth shut about the incident involving a Minister of the Crown. If that is the way the Public Service or any section of it operates, it ought to be horrifying to a parliament which talks about freedom of information legislation, for example. If a member of a government elite, a Minister of the Crown, is involved and a junior officer who tells the truth-perhaps the only person who did, if we look at this great book of documents-on the basis of his own empirical investigation of the matter, is victimised, that officer in his section of the Public Service is in the same situation as confronted Galileo. That is a most undesirable situation which ought to be the subject of judicial investigation.

The other comment I wish to make is that in that context, if a junior officer is victimised for telling the truth because the truth is unpalatable in respect of senior bureaucrats and a Minister of the Crown, an internal departmental investigation into that matter is not good enough because we will only lay ourselves open to a continuation of the same process. The third point, of course , is this: What actions were taken by the head of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in respect of all matters relating to the Minister for Health and were these actions taken with the knowledge and approval of the Government? I do not think the answer to that question is revealed by these documents. It is a question which ought to be determined because the head of the Department is responsible for the activities of the officers of his Department, the procedures followed in the Department and for reporting to the Minister the truth in relation to those matters of fact which are relevant and the truth in relation to the procedures followed. I do not know whether a judicial inquiry might lead to this conclusion. I have a sneaking suspicion that one Minister was not told the truth. If that be so I think it ought to be a matter of public knowledge and judicially determined--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not told the truth by whom?
—By members of his Department, not necessarily in the sense of deliberate fabrication but as a result of a series of misleading statements by one public servant or bureaucrat--
—That is what Spanswick says.
—Yes, but I do not in any sense wish to prejudge that issue.
—No, I am only trying to clarify what you are saying now.
—It may be that a Minister was told an untruth by another Minister; I do not know. I do not want to know. I am not making that suggestion.
—I did not want to intervene. I was trying to see that both of us were utterly fair in what we were saying.

—That is a matter which concerns the head of the Department, who is responsible to report the truth to the Minister on the facts and on the procedures which, in my view and in the view of the Opposition, should be a matter of judicial investigation. It may be that that process will not result in anything to the detriment of the Minister concerned. Maybe it will result in something very much to his benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth point is whether the Bureau is effective in performing its functions to ensure that it is an effective organisation and carries out its functions under the Customs Act. Mr Deputy President, that very important matter of wider ramifications is being debated here and was referred to in the Senate at Question Time. It is a matter which I have raised in the Senate in the past. It was a matter of considerable concern to me in the month of January when I saw women with young children waiting for 3 1/2 hours to be cleared in a Sydney Customs area on a very hot day. That is a totally different issue but it goes to the administration of the Bureau of Customs and to the general desirability of investigating those many questions involved in dealing with passenger traffic at peak time, the hours worked and so on. All those issues go to the level of performance of the Bureau of Customs.

The fifth point is whether any other Minister was aware or should reasonably have been aware of these matters and failed to take appropriate action. I suppose in a sense the Minister to whom that query is most appropriately directed is the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. There may well have been other Ministers who might have offered some advice in this matter , who might have been aware of the circumstances and who might have seen that appropriate action was taken before it got to the resignations of those two Ministers.

Mr Deputy President, I have not had the opportunity to peruse all the documents which were tabled yesterday. I am not even sure that they represent all the documents, but a number of issues I have seen have, quite frankly, been of considerable concern to me. They are documents relating to reports on the conduct of Mr Mayhew when he persisted with his allegations that it was a colour television set. These documents contain highly bureaucratic suggestions, the validity of which I have no idea. Mr Mayhew became very excited about the issue. He was in fact almost hysterical and unbalanced about it, but the fact remains that he was right. I think it is unfortunate that those sorts of documents should not be further investigated to find the facts of the matter in the interests of establishing a proper relationship between the various levels of officers in the Bureau and in the Department. I am particularly concerned about a report from the Senior Assistant Collector, Mr F. I. Kelly, to which I will refer briefly. That document states that Mr Bennett should be informed of these matters. I will refer to two of them. The report states:

Mr MacKellar has informed the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs that he imported a radio/cassette/black and white television combination unit on 5 October. Such a unit is admissible free of duty as part of the general concessions available to arriving passengers.
The next paragraph states:
There can be no question of any inconsistency in application of the law to arriving passengers and V.I.P.'s;
(f) no further action is proposed.

In a sense that is a summary of what happened. No further action was proposed because there could be no question of inconsistency between the way in which ordinary citizens and VIPs are treated. That is the way the argument runs in this document. Of course, Mr MacKellar informed the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs that it was a black and white television. As I said earlier, these documents are about an extraordinary process by which people decide a colour television is black and white because there can be no question, in the words of that document, of different treatment of VIPs and ordinary citizens.

What we are concerned about is that these issues should not lie about unresolved. If they lie about unresolved they will not go away and they will not lie about unresolved to the benefit of anyone-the officers of the Customs Bureau , the public servants involved or the two Ministers who resigned. I do not know what the truth is on all these matters. All I know is that, in moving this amendment to the motion moved by Senator Grimes that the Senate take note of the paper, the amendment being that in the opinion of the Senate there should be a judicial inquiry into a number of matters, we would like a resolution of some of these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support the amendment moved by Senator Button. From time to time there seemed to be some conflict in the wording of that amendment.
—The spirit was the same.

—The spirit was the same. We wish to abstract ourselves from the party political nature of this amendment and we do not necessarily support all the sections of the amendment or feel that they are necessary. However I think one particular item in that amendment would certainly warrant a judicial inquiry -that is the reason we support it-and that is the serious allegations of victimisation of a public servant who was engaged in carrying out his duty to the best of his intentions. That allegation is serious enough to warrant a judicial inquiry on the basis that the law, as established by the Parliament, has to be carried out without fear and favour and must be seen to be carried out in that way. We believe the population of Australia is entitled to have that particular item clear in its mind that there never has been, if that is the case , and never will be any favours given to people who hold public office in this country simply because they hold public office and that the law applies to them as it does to all other citizens. On that basis we support the amendment moved by Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter is, as has been said, a very unfortunate one, and one which has resulted in two very fine people paying a very high price. That, in the Westminster spirit is, however severe, nevertheless a proper situation. It comes against the background that when this Government came to office it thought it necessary to put out a clear instruction, from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) by way of letter and from the Secretary to the Department by the way of instruction, that every person coming through Customs should be treated equally. Honourable senators may think that that ought not to have been necessary but apparently at that time--
—Perhaps there had been some prior experience.
—There may have been some prior experience; that is perfectly true. In fact one would say--
—Jock Pagan was one.

—I think that remark is offensive and out of the spirit of this situation. I think one should never in this place use names of people who cannot defend themselves here. If Senator Button wants to say these things outside he can.
—You talk about Gough Whitlam all the time. He cannot defend himself here.
—He can defend himself very well indeed. I repeat that to understand this matter the then Secretary, in a minute to the Collector of Customs in all States, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has decided that all Australians on their return from overseas journey receive equal treatment in respect of the enforcement of the Customs and quarantine regulations. I have been instructed that all Federal and State parliamentarians (including Ministers of State), government officials, and notable Australian dignitaries of every description undergo the same Customs and quarantine formalities as other Australian citizens.

This does not mean that our present procedures for processing passengers are to be varied, but it does mean that no special courtesies and facilities may still be granted to foreign dignitaries repeat dignitaries including passengers subject to diplomatic privilege.

That minute originated because the Prime Minister had written a letter to originate it. I want to say here and now that that was the clear and unequivocal instruction of the Prime Minister and his Government. It is against that background that we look at this incident. An incident certainly occurred. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill in fact amends the parent Act, the Repatriation Act, in four respects and in doing so corrects four of the many anomalies which are contained in this complicated parent Act. The first amendment relates to the Government's attempt to provide equality of treatment for veterans suffering serious service-related mental illness as compared with veterans suffering other forms of war-related illness. The second amendment extends the repatriation benefits to Australian members of the Sinai peacekeeping force. The third amendment facilitates the Commonwealth's recovery of moneys expended on health care for repatriation patients eligible for workers compensation or third party payments. The last amendment is aimed at protecting from legal action employees in repatriation hospitals who have to carry out tasks specified by State laws.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill corrects four anomalies in the repatriation legislation and these anomalies may be considered minor in that only a few hundred people are primarily affected by them. We support these measures but we intend to move an amendment in an attempt to correct further anomalies which also exist in the repatriation system in this country. We know that the Repatriation Act has a lot of difficulties and anomalies. What we should also be keenly aware of is the fact that too many of these are a direct result of successive conservative governments which were less anxious to care for those who returned from war than they were to send them off in the first place. Too many of the measures taken to correct these sins of omission are noteworthy for the miserable economy of their application in line with what has been a fairly parsimonious approach in paying a nation's debt to its ex-servicemen and ex-servicewomen.

Three of the amendments that we propose tonight and which I will move deal with three anomalies which will be more than obvious to honourable senators in this place. The first would extend repatriation benefits for those Australians who served in peacekeeping forces prior to the Sinai. If we are prepared to provide repatriation cover for those who are serving in the Sinai force-we certainly should-it is surely equally appropriate to provide such benefits for those Australians who served in other peacekeeping forces prior to the Sinai. There were a surprising number of them and they should not be forgotten.

Secondly, as we have argued before and as I have moved before in this place, we believe the Government should extend eligibility for service pensions to allied ex-merchant mariners as it has previously extended service pensions to cover allied ex-servicemen and, more recently, to cover Australian merchant mariners who were in war zones. We suggest that there is no logical reason why allied merchant mariners should be denied this benefit, but this amendment was defeated in both Houses last year. We hope it will receive more favourable passage this time.

The third anomaly which we would seek to correct is the provision of equality of repatriation benefits between the veterans of the two world wars and the campaigns in Malaya and Vietnam. It is an extraordinary situation that our well- meaning repatriation system should provide different entitlements for Malaysian and Vietnam veterans. The differences between sections 6 (1), (4), (5) and (6) of the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act of 1962 and section 101 of the Repatriation Act of 1920 should not exist and, as these veterans are aging and increasingly more likely to seek claims for occurrences which arose out of war-caused disabilities, we believe that they, in fact, should receive the same treatment under the legislation.

We believe this is a sensible amendment. While we are devoting our attention to correcting anomalies percieved by the Government, let us do the right thing and correct anomalies which exist for other ex-servicemen, particularly those to whom I have just referred.
