Whilst the amendment the Government is proposing in respect of section 49 of the Act seeks to end the existing discrimination against veterans suffering service-related mental illness, it is significant that the repeal of section 49 was viewed with great suspicion by many of the totally and permanently incapacitated associations and other associated organisations in the country. I believe this amendment correctly ensures that the mentally ill veteran's pension and any accumulated money will become his property, as it is for any other veteran, and that in the event of his death, without recovering from his mental illness, his pension will be distributed according to his will or, according to intestacy laws if there is no will, rather than its being left simply to the discretion of the Repatriation Commission. In addition the trustee provisions have, on the surface of it, been improved. But this aspect of the legislation will require continuous review and will be watched by both the Opposition and, I am sure, by all veterans' organisations.

It would clearly be wrong, I believe, if we chose not to consider the reservations which have been brought to our attention by TPI members, especially as the speeches of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) are riddled with references to the importance of consultation with veterans' organisations in drawing up repatriation legislation. Both the Minister and I were privileged to attend the first national conference of ex-service organisations which was held in Canberra in August last year. This conference drew together some 50 veterans and dependants organisations to discuss their common concerns. One of those concerns, in fact, was to deal with the repeal of section 49. At that conference the following motion was passed:

That the action of the Lynch Committee in recommending the repeal of Section 49 of the Repatriation Act dealing with the transfer of pensions of veterans who are deemed incapable of managing their own affairs to the individual States, if accepted or implemented, be deplored and that any moves in this direction, either through Parliament or Regulation be publicly debated.

I was one person at that conference who expressed support in general for the repeal of section 49 and I certainly express it now. The fact that this motion was passed demonstrated the concern of these organisations that these few hundred veterans were to be left without proper support. As recently as last month, March, the issue was raised again at the Biennial Federal Congress of the Associations of TPIs in Canberra. The Minister and I were there and we were both questioned about the repeal of section 49. Again at this conference, concern was expressed about this proposal. As a result of this concern the Department and the Minister have reassured the TPI Association and the Returned Services League and have made what they believe and I believe to be satisfactory arrangements to cope with the new situation and, we hope, to provide for the future care of the unfortunate veterans concerned.

There are still those who are concerned that these veterans-admittedly, they are few-suffering from chronic mental disorders will not now be cared for as well as they have been in the past by being primarily the responsibility of State mental health authorities. We must be concerned to ensure that this is not so in the future, and be vigilant about it. My inclination is to take the attitude that the sooner we get rid of section 49 the better. I have made no secret in the past of the fact that I believe it to be an archaic provision, riddled with the particular injustices so frequently meted out in the past to the mentally ill in this country. It is in fact a discriminatory hangover from less enlightened days. I can appreciate the concern expressed by those members who in a very real way have represented over the years the best interests of all their disabled comrades, not the least their often forgotten mates in mental institutions.

In an attempt to establish the number of veterans directly affected by the proposals arising out of the review of government expenditure Senator Coleman asked at Senate Estimates Committee G in May of last year for figures over a five-year period and received a reply in the form of a table which I will later seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard. The numbers at 30 June 1980 totalled 477-141 in New South Wales; 207 in Victoria; 79 in Queensland; 12 in South Australia; 27 in Western Australia; and 11 in Tasmania. They are not large numbers but they are nonetheless important and, of course, deserve our protection.

The second anomaly corrected in this Bill relates to the direct collection by the Commonwealth from insurance companies of reimbursements for patients who are eligible for workers compensation or third party benefits. At present compensation can only be claimed directly from the injured individual and not from any third party. We agree with the proposal in the Bill that the Commonwealth should be able to recover those moneys directly from a third party, which is in most cases an insurance company. This is clearly a much more humane and sensible way of treating this issue, rather than having to put pressure on the injured person to pay money and leaving him or her with the responsibility of collecting it from the insurance company. Incidentally, it is likely to be a much more efficient way to collect money. We support these proposals. Similarly, we support the measure to protect repatriation employees in carrying out duties required by State law. A matter which comes to mind is the taking of blood alcohol tests from accident victims, which is a compulsory procedure in many States. People carrying out such work in repatriation hospitals need to be covered under this legislation.

The Opposition obviously supports the decision embodied in the third amendment to the Act to provide repatriation cover for Australians serving with the Sinai peacekeeping force. Whatever our views on that involvement-they are similar to our views on Australia's earlier involvement in Vietnam -we nevertheless have the firm view that servicemen so deployed are entitled to cover, as they will be under this legislation. As I said in my earlier remarks, too often in the past we have been only too anxious to send troops away and not as anxious to ensure that they are adequately cared for on their return. It is unfortunately typical of this legislation that it has come before us only after the contingent has had time not only to settle in to the Sinai but also to be subjected to visits from Australian Ministers with all the grandstanding and the news coverage that such visits cause.

It is interesting that at one stage it looked as though the current crisis in the Falkland Islands would involve Australian servicemen on exchange duties on British ships. The special and difficult position of our servicemen with the special Commonwealth training unit in Uganda serves to highlight the haphazard way in which this legislation deals with these groups of people who from time to time represent our country in such forces. It is very easy to commit a few troops as a goodwill gesture or for political purposes to some apparently harmless expedition designed to ingratiate Australia with other countries within the South East Asia Treaty Organisation or the Commonwealth, or occasionally far beyond any legitimate sphere of interest in an attempt to buy favours against an uncertain future. It has apparently been more difficult to cover those servicemen and to treat them with justice and compassion on their return.

Last year's amending legislation was designed to establish a mechanism whereby Australian representatives performing peacekeeping or other duties in areas outside Australia where a state of tension exists would be eligible for repatriation benefits. This extension was to apply only to those members with service after 1 November 1981. This then involved Australian peacekeeping forces serving in Kashmir, the Middle East and Cyprus because they all come under the umbrella definition of a peacekeeping force raised or organised by the United Nations or another international body. We found, of course, that members of the proposed Sinai force were not covered by this amendment, though all the signs pointed to their imminent involvement in the United States-sponsored peacekeeping venture. Thus, the legislation presently before us deletes the phrase to which I have just referred. I think it is symptomatic of the manner in which the Australian contingent was despatched that a definition could not be found to cover it at the point at which it left our shores.

The trouble with this amendment is that it does not cover services provided by earlier peacekeeping forces to which Australia has contributed. These forces include the Australian involvement in Indonesia between 1948 and 1951; the peacekeeping force in Korea after the armistice in 1953 to 1957; observer groups sent to India, Pakistan and the Middle East at various stages; and now, I believe, the training team in Uganda. It is because of this gross inequity in the treatment meted out to our differently designated returning servicemen that the Opposition moved, unsuccessfully, in the House of Representatives the amendment which I will move again tonight; namely, the extension of repatriation benefits to Australians who served in peacekeeping forces prior to 1 November 1981. Allied to this, we moved in the House of Representatives-I will do so again tonight-that equality of repatriation entitlements should be established among veterans of World War I, World War II, Malaya and Vietnam. I do not think these amendments go far enough. Like so many amendments in this place, they are largely an expression of a view of the Senate, but I think they are worth moving and worth supporting as a start towards correcting many of the anomalies which exist in this legislation.

At the time of the notional debate which we held in this place on the commitment of Australian troops to the Sinai, much was made of the other recognised areas in which Australians had been deployed in peacekeeping and similar goodwill operations associated at various times with regional trouble spots. Yet few have been accorded the recognition they deserve in terms of public awareness for their contribution, specific repatriation or specific pension benefits, access to the defence service home loans or even, at times, full acceptance by the Returned Services League in this country.

I will quote as an example the case of the Special Royal Australian Air Force contingent which served in Ubon in Thailand in the 1960s. This seems to have been forgotten too easily by the public, the Parliament, the Repatriation Department and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The alarming aspect of the case of these veterans was that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in correspondence associated with the lack of recognition of that particular RAAF unit has admitted to a singular lack of awareness of the matters involved. He was unable to provide any satisfactory answer to the points raised in correspondence from people who served in the unit at Ubon. I am indebted to him for drawing this matter to my attention.

It is worthwhile going back to the parliamentary debates since 1956 and 1962 which saw the passage of the Repatriation (Far East Strategic Reserve) Act and the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act. The first related to services in a defined area, namely, services as part of the British Commonwealth Far East Strategic Reserve in Malaysia and Singapore. The second enabled appropriate repatriation benefits to be extended to members of the force serving in Vietnam. The legislation was to be applied immediately by a regulation to troops in Malaya serving in forward areas and to a comparatively small group then serving in an instructional capacity in the Republic of Vietnam and who, as we said then , might be exposed to some risk. One could say they were famous last words at the time.
Speaking on the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Bill in December 1962, at a time at which the RAAF unit was already serving in Thailand, the then Minister, Mr Swartz, stated:

The basic principle of the Bill is that eligibility for war pension and associated benefits shall stem from an occurrence including the contracting of a disease, that happened during a period of the members service which exposed him to hazards beyond those of normal peacetime service. This was the principle adopted by the Repatriation (Far East Strategic Reserve) Act in 1956.
He summed up:

The Bill provides that members of the Australian forces who serve abroad and whose service involves some operational risk beyond that normally associated with peacetime service and the dependants of those members will receive pensions and associated benefits in respect of death or incapacity attributed to that service on broadly the same basis as that on which benefits are available under the Repatriation Act to ex-servicemen of the two World Wars and the Korean and Malayan operations and their dependants.
At that time Labor's Les Haylen stated:

This group of measures is designed to ensure orderly control of repatriation procedures and I can see the wisdom of this, for there ought to be a guide for the future. A pattern should be laid down for service abroad in these special strategic and other forces so that in future new measures will not have to be introduced to deal with situations as they develop.

I suggest this was a valid comment in 1962, 10 years after our Korean involvement and on the threshold of Vietnam. It is even more valid 20 years later and several more overseas service decisions later. An RAAF contingent, the 79 squadron, was stationed at the Royal Thai Air Force base at Ubon between 1961 and 1966, in response to a Thai Government request made from one South East Asia Treaty Organisation member nation to another because of the concern with the Laotion border situation. The conditions under which that squadron served were certainly not normal peacetime conditions and there is no doubt that their health and safety were at risk. It seems that the Government believes that the RAAF Squadron was on some sort of tropical joyride. The contingent got no recognition, despite engendering respect and goodwill. Its members are ineligible for war service home loans and have limited access to the benefits provided for other members who served overseas.

The Australian base at that time was guarded by armed Thai service guards as were the airstrip, the hangars and the reservement areas. The RAAF service police, the United States Air Force and Thai service personnel carried out armed patrols during the evenings to protect the contingent from local insurgents. All rostered personnel were issued with arms. Living and working areas were punctuated with dugouts and sandbag shelters. Elevated buildings had wire mesh screens to prevent missiles being thrown under them. The RAAF accommodation was within 100 metres of the airfield perimeter and within 200 to 300 metres of the airstrip itself. They suffered, therefore, under conditions of considerable noise, especially when the United States Air Force was operating from this area. To all intents and purposes, they were in a war zone. I believe they should be more than considered for full benefits as other groups should have been in the past.

Just as RAAF personnel find it hard to accept the fact that their Ubon duty is regarded as nothing very special, so too do allied ex-merchant mariners wonder at the injustice that now denies them a benefit available to their merchant mariner colleagues in Australia and in fact other allied ex-servicemen in Australia. The benefit was first extended to Australian merchant mariners who served in a theatre of war. I remind the Minister of his astonishing claim in response to a question at the time that nobody had asked for it to be extended to allied ex-servicemen. This is an extraordinary claim when one reads the continual correspondence which came from merchant mariner organisations. These men and women were certainly not members of the forces but many of them suffered and worked under conditions which were far more severe than any members of the forces. Allied merchant mariners also served in the convoys, lighthouse tenders, pilot ships, hospital ships and troop transports under considerably difficult conditions. No Australian wanted to know their nationality when they were part of the struggle for freedom. It is churlish, I believe, to single them out because of their nationality or where they came from at the time, when providing these benefits quite correctly to other Australian ex-merchant mariners.

I hope this part of the amendment will encourage people to vote for the whole amendment. When I started my speech, I mentioned that we have no reason to oppose the amendments that are made to this legislation. We certainly agree with the principles of the four basic sections of this Bill. We believe other sections of the repatriation legislation in this country need looking at. We believe, and have expressed the view many times in this place, that the repatriation legislation is excessively complicated and is hedged about with excessive conditions. Mr Justice Toose in his very lengthy inquiry pointed out that the legislation needs considerable amendment. Conditions do change for veterans as they age. The nature of the conditions and the proportion of the different types of conditions that they suffer from do change from time to time. The legislation certainly needs changing in line not only with the changing conditions of the veterans but also with our views on how they should be treated .

It is for this purpose that we will continue to move amendments of the type that we have moved. I note, in passing, that the scrutiny of bills report has two complaints about this legislation. We may discuss those in the Committee stage. The Opposition cannot see that any good purpose will be served by amending the legislation in line with those two relatively minor considerations which were brought up by that report. I will be interested to hear the Minister' s views on what he and the Government think of that report. I repeat: We support the legislation. I move the amendment in the hope that the Senate will, by merely expressing a viewpoint on this matter, go some way towards further improving this legislation and further improving the lot of our war veterans in this community. I move:
At end of motion, add '', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should provide for:
(1) repatriation benefits for those who served in peacekeeping forces before 1 November 1981;
(2) eligibility for service pensions for all allied ex-merchant mariners as is provided for Allied ex-servicemen; and

(3) amendment to the Repatriation Act 1920, and related Acts, to provide equality of repatriation entitlements as between veterans of World War I, World War II, and the conflicts in Malaya and Vietnam, as is presently provided for World War II veterans under section 101 (1) (B) of that Act.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate tonight is again debating amendments to the Repatriation Act to which the Australian Labor Party has moved an amendment as an attachment to the motion that the Repatriation Amendment Bill be read a second time. As has already been said, the Repatriation Amendment Bill deals with a range of items probably the most contentious of which deals with the repeal of section 49. This has caused some considerable concern within the veteran community. The particular proposal when it was first mooted appeared in an unlikely place, that is, in the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the so-called Lynch committee report. The Government has said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government intends to abolish deductions for maintenance that currently reduce the veteran's pension by half and to hand control of the disability pensions of these veterans over to the State authorities.

It is true that this had previously been mooted by the Government. But raising the matter in a hard fashion in the Lynch report, I think, gave rise to serious disquiet amongst the various veterans' organisations that the Government was about to undertake an exercise to save money in relation to veterans' affairs. I believe that was unfortunate because, as it transpired, the intentions of the Government were nothing of the sort. Indeed, that concern was ill-founded. Nevertheless, that concern was there.

Since that time I and, I imagine, other senators and indeed the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), have had considerable correspondence and discussions with various groups, particularly with the totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners' associations. The major concerns, I think, of those groups stem from the fact that they work very closely with their veteran friends on a voluntary basis. Indeed, the TPI associations in Australia are the groups which visit mental hospitals, which visit their former comrades and which assist their wives or children in what would be an extremely difficult period for anybody in the community but more so for these particular people because of their often advanced ages. Those people who give voluntarily of their time, their energy and their efforts, I believe, have shown themselves to be exceedingly worthwhile members of the community. They are people who, not only in their previous service to the community in the armed forces but also now in their service to their previous comrades, have shown that the dedication that they had previously has not died. Therefore, it concerns me greatly in meeting those people that they have had that worry imposed on them. This is of extreme concern to me. Indeed, only three weeks ago I met such a group. The people were still at that stage very disturbed.

Since that time the Minister, I acknowledge, has been at great pains and has spent some considerable time to allay their fears. Indeed I have had, and I am sure the spokesperson from the Labor Party has similarly had, correspondence from the associations to say that the Minister has now completely satisfied them on all accounts and has given them his personal assurances in relation to the supervision that he will have over how this piece of legislation is implemented. I would be grateful if the Minister in his reply conveyed to the general public the import of those discussions that he has had and the types of assurances that he has given to the veterans. I believe that many veterans in Australia would be pleased with the type of discussions that he has had.

The type of problems that originally arose in relation to this, I think, were and still are of concern. They involve the care and welfare of the seriously mentally ill in this community insofar as they come under the Repatriation Act. The problems differ considerably from State to State. My own State of Queensland is not a shining example in terms of its legislation for the treatment of the mentally ill. Indeed, I believe it has on its statute books some of the worst laws in the Western world in relation to the mentally ill. I was very pleased to see within the last week that the Queensland Minister responsible for this area has indicated that he will be introducing legislation into the State House which will comprise a fairly massive review of these archiac laws. I believe that also will satisfy the veterans' associations in my State as to the future treatment of the mentally ill ex-Service people.

I raise a couple of issues which arise in the Minister's second reading speech alluding to a particular point on how this Bill will operate. I hope that we will have some elucidation on this matter when the Minister replies. The second reading speech states:

. . . that upon repeal of section 49, the accumulated moneys of these veterans will be transferred to the trusteeship of the Repatriation Commission under regulation 9 of the Repatriation Regulations or, if it is thought that the veteran is able to manage for himself, his pension will be returned to him with the interest earned.

I am not at all sure as to the meaning of that last section of the speech. Indeed, under the current regulations and current operation of the Act I was under the impression that if a veteran was indeed able to manage for himself or herself he or she had the pension returned. Since last year when the deductions for medical costs ceased that would have been the total amount received. In other words, if the veteran was capable of looking after his or her own affairs he or she would be able to look after his or her affairs. I am not quite sure whether that phrase means anything more than that, in other words, that the status quo might prevail. That matter has been expressed to me with some concern by a number of veterans. I would be pleased if the Minister would say that it means nothing more than retaining the status quo.

The next point I raise is the agreement that has been reached with five States on the proposed arrangements and the replies from the other State. I notice that in the debate in the House of Representatives it was suggested by way of interjection, I think, that the other State was Queensland. By way of another interjection it was suggested that it was not. I wonder whether the Minister would say what problems have been run into with the other State, whether they have been solved and what type of agreement has been reached with the State if it goes beyond any of the parts which are alluded to in the amending Bill.

I turn now to the amendment moved by the Australian Labor Party. I certainly concur with the points raised by Senator Grimes in his speech. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendment. I draw particular attention to paragraph (2) of the amendment which refers to the eligibility for service pensions of allied ex-merchant mariners. Although the motion does not say so it of course concerns allied ex-merchant mariners who are resident in Australia, most of whom are Australian citizens. The last time this matter came before the Senate the Government was congratulated for extending the benefits to Australian ex-merchant mariners. At that time it was said that they ought to be extended to allied ex-merchant mariners. Perusing that debate again, I can see no reason advanced by the Government for not doing that other than the monetary problems involved. Looking into it, I do not see that the problems are of such an extensive kind as to warrant the continuation of the denial of a pension to those allied ex-merchant mariners. There seem to be few people involved. Their claim, I believe, in terms of the operation in service, is as strong as that of Australians. It would carry a great deal of weight if we were to recognise the type of service provided to Australia by our allies during the war, particularly if those allies have since become residents of this country. It seems to me that war, although extremely costly in its operation, is probably more so subsequently. The picking-up after a war is necessarily of great expense to a country. I believe that the proposition that has been put forward, that those allied ex-merchant mariners ought to be provided for, is a reasonable one.

The other two items, I believe, speak for themselves-particularly the delay in the granting of pensions to members of peacekeeping forces. Those who served in them prior to 10 November 1981, although they are currently provided for under alternative legislation, ought to be brought under the same Act. That would be a cleaner and, in the long run, a preferable proposition. I remind honourable senators of the enormous problems which still exist in the changing of various Acts mid-way. We still have floating around-I hope it will be brought forward before too long-a further discussion of the relationship between the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits and the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits schemes. The type of problem that has arisen ought to be prevented in any other area, if at all possible. I believe that the Labor Party's proposed amendment, if taken up in legislative form by he Government, would in the long term cause the country fewer problems than would the keeping of the division we currently have before us. I believe that the last proposal is perfectly reasonable. The flux of time since World War I and World War II provides the justification for amendments to the Act. The same type of spirit could very well prevail now in relation to the veterans of the Malayan campaign and also of Vietnam.

I refer finally to the two proposals brought to the Senate's attention by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I believe that probably the best place to discuss those would be at the Committee stage of this Bill. I indicate that, for our part, we would have preferred some alteration in line with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's recommendation that the calculation of costs be done in actuality rather than by a written instrument of the Repatriation Commission, thereby alleviating possible duplication in court. However, there does not seem to be sufficient support within the Senate to bring that suggestion forward. I believe that the Minister will be alluding to that matter later. We will be listening to the Minister's summing up of the second reading debate to see whether there is any need for further action. The second recommendation of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is an extremely fine one which is well worth bringing forward but which would be extremely difficult to implement. Therefore, we have not proposed at any stage to undertake any action in relation to that particular item.

The whole area of veterans' affairs is an extremely difficult one. I do not think that anyone really envies the Minister's position terribly much in the operation of his portfolio. It is not one which can be administered in the same way as other portfolios. It has to be administered with an extraordinary amount of care and concern for people. Any amendments, before their introduction, ought to be canvassed, as far as is humanly possible, with all relevant associations and not simply with the high profile associations. In this case a lot of the concern that was expressed by many honourable senators in this chamber could have been alleviated if further consultation had taken place with those associations. I hope that in relation to future amendments to the Repatriation Act-I am quite sure we will be having them from time to time-the type of consultation which the Minister has undertaken extensively with this Bill will be continued and perhaps improved. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the second reading of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's piecemeal approach to anomalies and inadequacies in this legislation provides us with added opportunities upon which to draw attention to the extraordinarily blase approach by the Government to the plight of Vietnam veterans and others who have served their country in wars in days gone by. The amendments proposed by my colleague Senator Grimes are eminently sensible ones and have been very thoroughly canvassed, I believe. It is interesting to note that in relation to the second amendment, which refers to allied merchant marine personnel, there was a very positive response from nine Liberal and National Country Party members of the House of Representatives. I have no doubt that at least a few honourable senators opposite wrote to the organisations which circularised all parliamentarians some months ago soliciting support for this measure. Needless to say, none of the nine Liberal and National Country Party members of the House of Representatives was prepared to make the extreme sacrifice of crossing the floor when the vote on the Opposition's amendment was taken. Like the sea lord in HMS Pinafore, they voted at their party's call, and never thought of thinking for themselves at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The system of dealing with claims from veterans is obviously totally inadequate . At January 1982 there was a backlog of 17,000 claims awaiting hearing by the Repatriation Boards and some of those claims will not be heard for 12 months unless there is a drastic change for the better in the operations of the Boards. The Repatriation Review Tribunal has 9,000 claims awaiting hearing and a further wait of 12 months for some of the people involved with those claims is inevitable. A variety of reasons can be provided for these delays, some of which are inevitable-lack of foresight, lack of planning and lack of departmental awareness of a reasonable expectation of increases with the aging population of veterans and recent decisions which open up possibilities for those who previously considered themselves hopeless cases. Surely any department with a reasonable approach to the position would have realised that there would be an increasing number of claims, and provision would have been made for dealing with them. Vietnam veterans and their families, despite the prevarication and procrastination of this Government, still believe that they are entitled to a decent and fair deal from the repatriation authorities of this country in whose service they fought. Many of us agree that Vietnam veterans were exposed to an environment in which their health was endangered and their peace of mind shattered. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has sought time after time to minimise the number of people affected. He spoke last week of a very small number of veterans with severe problems. The Vietnam Veterans Association was incensed to the point where it accused the Minister of totally misrepresenting the situation. With completely justifiable indignation the Vietnam Veterans Association issued a Press release which stated:
Vietnam veterans are horrified at the very serious claims reportedly made by Veterans' Affairs Minister, Senator Messner, yesterday.
He apparently claimed that only a minute number of veterans had severe problems .
Any reasonable person reading the Australian article (1st Edition, 16 April 1982, page 2) could only assume that Vietnam veterans were drunken, anti-social malingerers and lunatics.
The VVAA refutes this suggestion and calls on the Minister to clarify his position and state whether he was correctly reported.

The Minister released certain statistics which apparently show a very small number of veterans with severe problems. He has ignored his own Department's figures (given to the Senate Committee in December 1981), which show that, to October 1981, approximately 17,200 claims had been made.

As far as I am aware up to this point the Minister has not clarified his position or stated whether he was correctly reported. Perhaps he will take the opportunity this evening, if necessary, to set the record straight. From the 53, 000 Vietnam veterans in this country there have been 17,200 claims-approximately one in three veterans had claimed at that point in October 1981. The third of the counselling centres-those jewels in the cardboard crown of the Minister-was opened in Perth last week. Despite a statement by the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Thomson, that only 63 veterans had visited counselling centres in Sydney and Adelaide-that statement was made early in March this year-the Vietnam Veterans Association information was that by then these centres had been consulted by over 340 clients and were having trouble handling the work load. Already they were seeking more staff. In Adelaide that centre was seeing 10 people a day. There is a clearly demonstrated need for a much more broadly structured counselling service-advice which was rejected by the Minister at the time the service was in the planning stages.

Experience in my electorate leads me to believe that amongst the wives and families of Vietnam veterans there are very many who are intensely cynical about the degree to which there is any real intention to provide other than superficial assistance. It was with some disappointment that I found the newly opened Perth counselling centre clinical and impersonal. Worse than that, the three staff members, all excellently well-qualified, sensitive and compassionate people, are male. I was assured that the sessional doctor to be employed-a part time doctor-would be a woman. I hope very much that this will be the case. I urge the Minister to make certain that women are employed in the counselling services. I am not denying the fact that there are very many men counsellors who , as I have described the Perth employees, are extremely appropriate for these positions. But I believe that where the clientelle will be substantially the wives and families of Vietnam veterans a great deal more needs to be available than the average, well-qualified male counsellor.

Lack of humanity and compassion have been the hallmarks of the treatment of too many returned servicemen. As Anzac Day 1982 approaches I hope that it will be possible to achieve a few more amendments than those proposed by the Government which will perhaps make life a little more tenable for many of those who have survived wars only to find that the peace was a great deal more trying than actual warfare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to speak for a reasonably brief period. I commence by saying that I support in toto the amendment moved in the other place, and moved in the Senate by Senator Grimes. I believe that the provision of those things that have been spelt out by Senator Grimes in his amendment are as urgent as many other benefits that should be applicable to ex- service people who have served in any war. It is true, as one of my colleagues said in the other place, that there is an excellent system of repatriation benefits but every so often weaknesses surface. I know that these amendments in fact set out to correct some of the three or four anomalies but there are other anomalies that also need correcting. The World War II table of repatriation benefits is probably the most comprehensive table within the British Commonwealth. We must remember that this system was initiated by a Labor government. Not only did it include compensation for those injured in war time but also it made provision for the training of ex-service persons, both male and female, so that they might properly fit into the community again.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose one of the good things about this system was the fact that if one was a certain age when one enlisted one automatically became entitled to those training schemes. On the other hand, of course, if one were severely wounded and unable to return to one's former occupation then one would receive the same entitlement to be trained in another trade or profession. Generally speaking at that point the repatriation system was working fairly smoothly. But after 1949 there were continuous attempts to erode many of the benefits. The situation has never been worse than it is at present. I realise that because of the Government 's inability to control the economic situation or even to make it operate smoothly it is endeavouring to pick up every spare dollar it can, often at the expense of ex-service persons. But this system was set in train long before this Government came to office in 1975.

In 1973-74 the Australian Labor Party set out to do some catchup work on the years of neglect prior to that period. This included such things as the picking up of the lag in the pensions of those persons who had been injured in war time and who were in receipt not of a full pension but the general pension or a part of the general pension. The Government, because of inflation and its neglect to catch up, has now indexed pensions to a certain degree. But that was not the case in those days. It was not the case until the Labor Party came into office. At the time of our dismissal from office we were looking at the possibility of picking up also the lag in the payments to dependants of wounded ex-service persons. Unfortunately, we went out of office before that situation could be corrected. We had hoped that this Government-we have encouraged it to do so- would look at that situation. But for a period of over 20 years there has been no catchup at all in that area. Today it would cost the Government very little money because most of the World War II and Korean veterans have grown families. In terms of cash a very small amount would be required to catch up on payments or just to bring the payments up to current monetary values for the dependants of ex-service persons.

I think it is significant that when there is a smell of war in the air the conservative element of society-that includes the conservative parties in this Parliament-has a tendency to do all the flag waving and all the cheering to the troops going away to war in the same way as we did to those troops going to the Vietnam war. When we had a lottery system of selecting conscripts members of the then government, who are now in government again, used to celebrate with cocktails and morning and afternoon teas as they drew out the lottery numbers to send another lot of conscripts away to the hopeless Vietnam war. But it was significant, because it was never a declared war, that a very great number of those people were not entitled to any repatriation benefits, nor were they entitled to war service homes or any of the other sorts of fringe benefits to which ex-service people are normally entitled. I had a relative who served as a sailor. He did not become eligible for a war service home until about his fourth trip into the war zone. He happened to be serving on an Australian Navy vessel that was accidentally bombed by the Americans. He came under fire-not by the enemy but by one of the Allies-quite accidentally. He then qualified because in that engagement one person was killed and several persons were injured.

That is an example of the sort of ad hoc way that we participated in the Vietnam war. We kept pouring people into that war. A lot of people in this country made a fortune out of the Vietnam war. I remember reading in this chamber one night a list of three or four pages of companies which were involved in selling war materials. Some of our primary products were being laundered through Czechoslovakia and other countries so that they could go to the so- called enemy and keep up the enemy's strength to shoot down our people. That shows the immoral sort of way that conservative parties and conservative societies approach war generally. It is not changing.

The agent orange debate has been going on for a very long time. The Government set up an epidemiological survey. Honourable senators on this side of the House said at the time that that was not the answer. We said that a judicial inquiry was the answer so that all the facts could come out. That is a long time ago now . Finally, the Government abandoned the survey because it realised, after spending all that money, that it was not worth while. A Senate committee came up with some propositions which the Government has ignored. In the meantime, Vietnam veterans are still suffering. Many cannot work. Many of them have broken domestic lives. Families have divided and broken up. The young people, as they were then, who served in Vietnam knew they were being affected by something but were told on the ground that agent orange and the other herbicides being used were quite harmless as long as they took certain precautions. In many instances, of course, they were sprayed without being told that the herbicides were dangerous.

The same thing happened to people associated with radiation fallout at the bomb test sites in this country. Some of those people were servicemen, others were civilian employees. I know of one case of which, I think, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is aware. We have endeavoured to chase up witnesses to this case. They are all prematurely dead from cancer. I have had some dealing with the Minister about a man at Esk in Queensland who has been ill for a long time. The Minister's office is treating him as something less than a human being. After years of unemployment and ill health he was finally granted a pension late last year. From memory he was granted a totally and permanently incapacitated pension. He wrote to the Repatriation Review Tribunal and said that he thought that that was fair enough. The man was so ill at the time that he was really incapable of writing a letter to anybody. I was distressed to find that the Minister's private secretary wrote back to this man after he applied for the pension to be made retrospective for a greater period and quoted the letter that the man had written to the Tribunal as vindication for not backdating the pension.

I think one of the big problems with these matters is the lack of humanity in dealing with people who are, in many instances, seriously ill. In some cases the illness might be a psychiatric one. Whatever it is, it is the sort of thing that ought to be treated with a great deal more humanity, softness and compassion than some people in the Department have a tendency to show. I realise that responsibility for a lot of this must fall back onto the Minister. He must ensure that his Department deals with a case in such a way that if there is any doubt at all the veteran should have the advantage of that doubt. They are not getting that today. The holdup in grants for war service homes is absolutely shocking. Many Vietnam veterans and their young families cannot possibly wait for a year or more just to get a loan to establish their first real home. They cannot afford bridging finance because the economy is now out of control and interest rates are so high, so they have to continue living in caravans and sub- standard accommodation. These are some of the things that are referred to in the Opposition's amendment.

I repeat that the Opposition was opposed to Australia's involvement in a private war in Vietnam. It meant the loss of many thousands of lives. It meant that many thousands of people, both Americans and Australians, were injured. More sophisticated countries did not get involved. Great Britain would not be talked into becoming involved in that war under any circumstances. The big problem with the Australian Government is that it needs to talk up wars. That is one of the ways, I suppose, of overcoming the economic ills. It happened in World War I and it happened in World War II. It happened to a lesser degree with the Korean war and it happened to some degree with Australia's involvement in the Vietnam war.

At the moment the establishment of this country and of the Western world generally needs another war. Metal prices have fallen drastically. I suppose some people in this country hope-certainly the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser ) has given full approval-that confrontation will take place over the Falkland Islands issue. I am surprised that Australia has not committed some servicemen to that confrontation. It is almost laughable that it takes almost three weeks even to get anybody into the so-called territory that Britain allegedly owns in order to have a confrontation. Australia has committed its servicemen to the Sinai peacekeeping force. This will be shown in the future to be a wrong political decision. The fact is that it is not a United Nations peacekeeping force; but another private peacekeeping force.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know why it is not covered by the United Nations.

—I suppose Senator Thomas has a theory about the United Nations. He is one of the hawks who would like to see it abolished. If that is what he wants, it proves that everything I have said in the last 10 minutes is dead right. He belongs to a hawkish section of society. If he were old enough he would not have believed in the League of Nations. He is young enough to have gone to Vietnam but did not bother to go because it was much more comfortable at home. But he sent his brothers, cousins and neighbours to Vietnam. Now, of course, he wants to abolish the United Nations, which is the only organisation in the world that might be able to make some contribution to peace generally. I am tired of the hawks in the establishment who keep on with this sort of rubbish . They are prepared to commit everybody else to a war while they make profits. I am surprised that Senator Thomas has committed himself publicly as one of those hawks.

SPEECH.PARA: The onus is now on the Government of Senator Thomas. People such as Senator Thomas committed these people to the Vietnam involvement but they were never prepared to call it a war. Now they are taking away any benefits they can. The servicemen of this country are entitled to make their positions a profession if they choose. The Government is making it extremely difficult for the regular soldier and other regular servicemen. I may not be speaking to the amendment but the fact is that we are now buying an aeroplane that we may never get. We have bought an aircraft carrier that cannot carry aeroplanes. We are committing it to service in the Falkland Islands area. A couple of well placed mortar bombs would probably put it out of action. I hope it is well insured. There is no live ammunition for carrying out proper manoeuvres. We have become almost a laughing stock because we find when manoeuvres are being held that the supplies of ammunition for the year have run out. The soldiers cannot even be trained with live ammunition.

The radar system in Darwin closes down at 5 o'clock every Friday afternooon. If somebody wanted to invade the northern parts of Australia they would merely have to find out when there will be a public holiday or weekend. They could then bring their planes in as high or as low as they wanted and they would not be picked up by the radar system The Government has private mercenaries running a surveillance system around Australia. I happened to be present in discussions with a person occupied in this surveillance scheme. He said: 'We are going back to Cairns this afternoon. There is a beer party in Cairns and we have decided that we are not going to finish our run'. The Government is paying many millions of dollars for that sort of surveillance. A series of navy vessels is currently being manufactured. After the design was approved, it was found that they were too heavy and would fall over sideways. I do not know what sort of corrections have been made but in any case there are not enough vessels. The Taiwanese, the Indonesians-anybody at all-can come in and wreck the reef. The can send one decrepit old boat through a hole in the reef. A patrol boat can race out to arrest it but it takes three days to get back to the coast and another three days to go back to the reef. In the meantime 20 other ships have come in, wrecked that part of the reef, collected their clam meat and gone. The defence system is a laughing stock.

If one wanted to go into all the details there would be a chance for a debate about the defence facilities of this country. The Government is unwilling to allow a first class debate about the defence of the country because it knows it does not have any. It tries to cover up with all sorts of smokescreens. I suppose that the Canberra bombers are the best aircraft we have. They are now being phased out instead of perhaps being dressed up. The Government cannot afford to buy the type of plane that is needed. The F111, which the Labor Government finally had to pay for, was a long ranging blueprint. The late Athol Townley was sent to the United States in 1963 by Sir Robert Menzies, who said to him: 'Buy planes quickly because the Commies are coming-they are, they are!-and we have to beat them'. The Government, because of the F111s and, earlier, the Petrov affair, was able to save its political bacon.

I support the amendment which has been moved. I hope that the Government, before it calls a double dissolution or whatever it intends to do, and before it sacks the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen)-I understand he will be promoted to the position of Speaker of the House of Representatives until the Government puts him out to grass in a diplomatic position-will take notice of the situation and do something about it. The veterans have served in every war and they ought to be given a fair go. It is all very well to be patriotic and flag waving when a war starts but for God's sake, they are entitled to the justice that they and their families have earned.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Gallery tonight of Mr Johnson, the President of the Legislative Council of the Parliament of New South Wales. I extend to him a very cordial welcome to our chamber this evening.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before coming to the main substance of what I intend to say tonight, I will attend to one or two points made by Senator Grimes and Senator Macklin in the course of their remarks. Both honourable senators drew attention to the problem of the repeal of section 49 of the Repatriation Act and some of the difficulties which some groups of ex-servicemen in the community have in understanding that move. I refer in particular to Senator Macklin's remarks. He realised that there was indeed a very real attempt by the Government to consult with organisations in this regard. In fact, it was only in the last few weeks that I had the opportunity to finalise arrangements with the totally and permanently incapacitated group in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This area is quite complicated. Both speakers correctly drew attention to the fact that totally and permanently incapacitated people would not be disadvantaged in any way by the passage of this legislation. In fact, they would be greatly advantaged. To confirm that remark, I will read into the record a passage from a letter that I have received from the Australian Federation of Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Ex-servicemen and Women, signed by the Secretary-Treasurer of that organisation, Mr P. G. Maley, J.P. I refer to the third paragraph of that letter, which states:

We were uncertain as to the allocation of funds that we thought may have accrued, and which if they were to be disbursed we felt should go to some worthy Veteran cause. However, it is now clear that the only funds held by the Department are in trust for the affected Veterans and when paid to the appropriate State Public Trustees will be solely available for the needs of the veteran in whose name it has accumulated, and must be paid to the Veteran if he recovers. If the Veteran dies, the normal inheritance laws prevail and the estate is disbursed accordingly.

I point out that clearly that organisation understands the situation now and is in support of this legislation. Senator Macklin referred to one other point which needs some attention. He said that there will be a need for the Department of Veterans' Affairs to monitor the administration of these funds by the public trustees in the various States. I give him my assurance that I will ensure that the Department undertakes that job diligently and, if there are any difficulties in the administration of the funds by the various States, other satisfactory arrangements will be made for the veterans. Senator Grimes mentioned the Ubon force. This is a matter of some complexity. The nature of the problem has its origin in the definition of the theatre of war and the difficulties with that definition. I undertake to look at the matter again and to communicate directly with Senator Grimes on it.

I take this opportunity to respond to some of the matters that have been raised during the debate on this Bill not only in this chamber but also in the House of Representatives. It has been many years since repatriation has attracted as much attention in the Parliament, the Press and the public forum as has occurred in recent months. For many years repatriation has been smooth flowing with no need for major changes of direction or any particularly deep questioning of its role. Over the last couple of years when considerable media attention has been given to Vietnam veterans and their problems, there has been considerable questioning of the role of the repatriation system; and there have been challenges to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Federal Court of Australia and the High Court of Australia. These have led to a greater degree of soul searching than has occurred in the repatriation sphere for some time.

The repatriation legislation provides for a comprehensive compensation scheme to pensioners and treatment for all veterans who suffered incapacities related to their service and to dependants of those veterans who have given their lives in the service of the country. In addition to this compensation scheme, a wide range of welfare benefits is provided to veterans and their dependants irrespective of service-related conditions.

Behind this repatriation scheme is a philosophy that was introduced in 1914 when the first wounded soldiers returned to Australia. There is an historical tradition to compensate those who have served, to meet with care and financial assistance those who answered the call. The philosophy is no less valid now than when it was born during the First World War. It is a philosophy which reflects the very best of the Australian character, that is, helping those in need, standing together in times of need and making sure that useful people are not thrown on the scrap heap before their time. Governments of all political persuasions have been the custodians of that tradition and of transmitting it into working, active programs for the care of veterans. I can assure you that we are no less mindful now of that responsibility than has been any government in the past. The repatriation system is a good scheme by world comparisons. It is as generous a scheme as any in existence in terms of the range and level of benefits, assistance and services. The system, however, was born to meet the needs of soldiers returning from the front. The clientele now has changed as many of the veterans are retiring from the work force and reaching old age. In fact, in June 1981, the eligible clientele of 636,000 had an average age of 63 years.

Some of the problems we now face require flexibility to meet the changing needs of veteran clients. There should be no suggestion that the repatriation function is fading away and that, therefore, action is unnecessary. On present numbers of veterans and treatment beneficiaries, the projections of future trends show clearly that there will be a very large client group well into the next century. For example, Mr Acting Deputy President, by the year 2000 there will be at least 230,000 surviving veterans at an average age of 75 years. The trends suggest that the treatment population of veterans will not peak for another three years for, as the age of veterans continually increases, so too does the need for the services of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This demand for increased services because of age will be far greater than any reduction that takes place because of declining numbers of beneficiaries.

Placed, then, in the context of repatriation history, the Department is faced with the requirement of developing new and more flexible response programs. In the treatment area we must pursue with vigour a program of rationalisation of services, both within the Department and in conjunction with the resources of the community hospital systems, to ensure that the aging veteran has available to him the best technology and the best thinking available for care of the aged. I announced in November last year that the Government had confirmed its commitment to the maintenance of the repatriation hospital system. That decision will ensure that the hospitals' high standards of care and services will continue while at the same time we can take every opportunity to rationalise services with the community hospitals system.

On the other end of the scale are the young veterans of the Vietnam conflict. I would like to say a few words about the action that has been taken to assist Vietnam veterans. These veterans have required a rethink of whether the current means of service delivery are adequate. It is a matter of concern that some sections of the Vietnam veterans' community have been critical of what they have seen as a lack of assistance. The Government has initiated a program for this group additional to the pre-existing benefits and services of the repatriation system. Our approach has been consistent and positive. I made a commitment on behalf of the Government that I would seek out those veterans with difficulties and provide a mechanism by which their difficulties could be properly addressed. Mr Acting Deputy President, in January last year I nominated counsellors in each branch office of my Department whom veterans could contact for counselling. I was also pleased to be able to say to Vietnam veterans that, in cases where urgent hospitalisation was necessary, this would be provided at a repatriation general hospital without cost to the veteran. I also went to the United States of America to examine at first hand the approach of the United States authorities in these matters.

Some Vietnam veterans felt that the existing machinery of the repatriation system, the interim counselling arrangements and the offer of hospital treatment in repatriation general hospitals, did not go far enough. After my visit to the United States I concluded that there was scope for helping those Vietnam veterans who feel most alienated by setting up facilities separated from departmental premises and staffed by personnel who know the Vietnam experience well. A counselling service was opened in Adelaide in January and a centre in Parramatta, Sydney in February and the Perth centre in April. Further centres will be opened in other cities in the near future.

The counselling centres for Vietnam veterans are a concept of reaching out in the community to find people who have problems and placing them into the system in circumstances in which they are comfortable and which provide the best hope of identifying and solving their problems. It is of fundamental significance when we are dealing with people with problems that they not be afraid to come forward or feel alienated from the system. Where they cannot approach the system I feel it is absolutely imperative that the system approaches them. The senior level staff of the centres are fully qualified counsellors and the centres provide professional counselling, both in terms of psychological and social problems, not only for the veterans themselves but also for their wives and children. It is intended that the centres develop extensive contacts with other groups in the community which provide expertise in particular areas such as marriage guidance and employment.

Following the decision of the Government to establish counselling centres, it was decided that where wives and children are considered by the counselling service to require emergency treatment and it can be provided at a repatriation general hospital, this will be provided at no cost to the family. This is a most important extension of the counselling operation. It meets the needs of Vietnam veterans who feel that they could act in ways which might harm their families. Where a veteran is undergoing a program of counselling therapy at a centre, that program will include all aspects of his family situation.

As I mentioned, the Government last year made provision for urgent treatment for Vietnam veterans to attend repatriation general hospitals in capital cities. Vietnam veterans in country areas may have felt that there was an element of discrimination in that proposal and the Government has decided that non-insured veterans in country areas can now receive urgent treatment in country hospitals and refer the costs to the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

I turn now to the Government's activity concerning the possibility of increased instances of disabilities in Vietnam veterans or of birth defects in their offspring. There has been consistency of approach in respect of the scientific resolution of various allegations by Vietnam veterans. Using the expertise of the Commonwealth Institute of Health, which in turn has been able to have its study plans assessed by the Advisory Committee in Science and Technology, the Government has acted on the advice of acknowledged experts in complex areas affecting the health of veterans.

The Commonwealth Institute of Health originally proposed a comprehensive epidemiological study with the participation of all Vietnam veterans to examine matters considered relevant to their own health and that of their families arising out of the use of herbicides in Vietnam. After closely examining the research carried out to date, the scientific advisers have concluded that the comprehensive survey of all Vietnam veterans is not needed. They have recommended preparation of a design protocol for a morbidity study of Vietnam veterans and controls which would be more limited but still with numbers large enough to produce results. The Government accepted this recommendation. Other studies which have already been through the initial scientific review process are now in progress. I refer to the case-control study of congenital abnormalities and the retrospective mortality study-that is, investigation of the causes and incidence of death among Vietnam veterans and a control group. There have been requests to set up a judicial inquiry into the effects of herbicides on the health of Vietnam veterans. The Government's attitude has been that a judicial inquiry would not provide a scientifically valid answer to the question of whether problems that some veterans and their families were experiencing could be related to possible exposure to herbicides or to any other aspect of Vietnam service.

The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, in its inquiry into the use of pesticides, has taken as its first priority the question of the possible effects on Vietnam veterans of exposure to herbicides. That inquiry commenced on 8 December 1981 and the Committee is engaged in a very thorough investigation of Vietnam questions. I believe that its investigation will be just as effective as any judicial inquiry. The treatment program, the counselling service and the study work represent important extensions of the Government's efforts to assist Vietnam veterans.

Another of the matters which has been raised in the Parliament is the problem of the delays that face applicants in the repatriation determining process. In recent years, considerable delays have occurred at each of the levels of determination. Mr Acting Deputy President, the repatriation determination system is a multi-tiered, independent determination system. This commences with the Repatriation Boards; there is an appeal right to the Repatriation Commission, and a right of review by the Repatriation Review Tribunal. In recent years a further process of judicial review has emerged, whereby any person may challenge a decision made at any level right through, if necessary, to the High Court of Australia. As part of the introduction of modern concepts of administrative law, we have imposed upon the determining authorities the need to provide a record of every element of their thinking in arriving at a particular decision so that the decision may be properly viewed if challeged legally at any level. The increased number of claims, the complex legislation and the emergent process of judicial review has naturally slowed determinations down. It is a very significant problem and as yet the delays have not been eliminated. This is not to suggest that action has not been taken.

One of the actions taken has been an approach to the ex-service organisations to join with the Commission and me in attempting to find the answers and find them quickly. In addition, the number of Boards has been increased from the equivalent of four full-time Boards in 1970 to 14. Repatriation Commission delegates who consider appeals to the Repatriation Commission have increased from three to 18. Members of the Repatriation Review Tribunal, which was created in 1979 to replace the former War Pensions Entitlement Appeal Tribunals and the Assessment Appeal Tribunals, have been increased to 21 full time and nine part time members compared with 16 full time members of the former tribunals. A good deal of effort has gone into streamlining medical reports and the administrative process of claims and appeals. These increased members, with the additional support staff and the other changes, are gradually eroding the backlog of cases and I am happy to say that in the case of the Tribunal and the Commission the delays are being reduced.

The recent High Court judgment in Law v Repatriation Commission and decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court have reversed a trend of declining claims and the influx has greatly increased the burden on the initial determining area. The Department is undertaking more comprehensive investigations to ensure that claims are fully investigated and that veterans' rights will be protected. These additional claims make it more difficult for a repatriation system of determination to cope. The Repatriation Commission, however, is keeping the matter under constant review. It is redirecting resources from other areas so that the problem can be overcome in as short a time as possible.

I have mentioned some of the effects of the changes of administrative law on the repatriation determination system. There has been some comment in another place that the Government is eroding benefits of veterans and that it will take the opportunity, following the High Court decision on the Law case, to further erode benefits. That is nonsense. What should be said is that for the first time a definitive statement has been given on the effect of certain provisions of the repatriation legislation. I can say that the success of claims following the Law case and other court and Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions has increased markedly. I have also mentioned that the number of claims from veterans wishing to test their eligibility, to make application to reopen claims or to make application for increased pensions have also increased.

I announced on 25 January that the Government had decided to take no action in the wake of the Law decision. This should have alleviated any fears that there was any intention to water down the repatriation compensation system. I should stress, however, that under the system it is still a statutory responsibility that each claim be considered on its merits and, although the decisions by these various higher authorities must be and are taken into consideration, there should be no acceptance of a disability in any individual case without proper investigation of the individual circumstances.

The repatriation system is a generous one and rightly so. As the High Court indicated, it was framed on the basis that people who suffered incapacity due to service would not be refused compensation. Mr Law was a Second World War veteran . He served first in the Middle East and later in Java where he became a prisoner of war of the Japanese. The High Court decision was based on the eligibility-liability provisions that apply to that war. These provisions are different in some respects to elegibility-liability provisions that apply to World War I or other conflicts. It has been suggested that the legislation be made uniform in respect of that elegibility-liability for all wars and conflicts . As I have mentioned, the repatriation legislation covers all wars and conflicts that Australians have been involved in since Federation. Perhaps, if I explain the history of the various liability provisions it will become clearer how the divergance has occurred so that nearly every conflict has a different provision. The only common elegibility is the provision for acceptance of an incapacity which was contributed to, or aggravated by, war service.

The basis of entitlement to compensation for veterans of World War I was governed by the War Pensions Act 1914. Because there was no Australian precedent , this Act followed the broad principles of the United Kingdom legislation which had covered earlier Australian contingents serving overseas as part of the Imperial Forces. Entitlement was based on 'incapacity or death resulting from the member's employment in connection with war-like operations' and was closely allied to the workers' compensation provisions of the time. The 'occurrence' provision was inserted in 1920. This provides for acceptance of an incapacity which resulted from an occurrance which happened during war service.

World War II prompted a major review of the legislation. In 1943, following recommendation of the committee of senators and members of the House of Representatives appointed to inquire into and report on the Australian Soldiers' Repatriation Act, separate provisions were inserted to distinguish between veterans who had active service and those who served only in Australia. The wide elegibility criteria were based primarily of the nature of the 1939 war, the entry of Japan and the need to view the whole area of the Commonwealth as a potential theatre of war. It was recognised that liability should be extended to cover incapacity or death which might not have occurred had the veteran not been enlisted, the primary cause of which was a disability not itself due to the members service. It was not considered necessary to amend the provision applying to World War I veterans and, therefore, the Act had two distinct eligibility provisions.

With the Korean-Malayan operations the Act was further amended to cover members who were allotted for duty in an operational area. Benefits were restricted to the 'occurrence' provision although members were covered if they were incapacitated or killed as a result of any action by the enemy or in combating the enemy. The Korea-Malayan provisions became the basis for later conflicts governing members of the British of Commonwealth Far East Strategic Reserve which served in areas such as Singapore and Malaya and the Special Overseas Service of Vietnam. Finally, when compensation benefits were extended to serving members in 1972 a further set of provisions was introduced.

Mr Justice Toose in reporting on the independent inquiry into the repatriation system concluded that the principles that have covered the granting of war pensions under the repatriation legislation are valid and continue to apply. He further added:

In respect of future service, entitlement to war pension under repatriation legislation should be granted where disablement or death results from an occurrence happening during the period of service, or for disablement which has been contributed to in any material degree or aggravated by the conditions of service, or for death which has been contributed to in any material degree by the conditions of service. Entitlement on this basis should apply to all types of service in respect of which eligibility under repatriation legislation is conferred.

Justice Toose, in restricting his recommendation to future pension cases, has overcome one of the greatest problems of introducing uniform criteria, that is, restrospective application of any view provisions. In workers' compensation it is possible to introduce new eligibility criteria as they can be made effective from a particular working day. However, in the repatriation area we are talking about past service in war and in war zones. The effect of any change in eligibility criteria cannot be restricted to future service and, therefore, applies retrospectively to all veterans.

Although I am not suggesting that this is detrimental, it raises several obvious problems in terms of administration and cost. If we were to adopt a uniform eligibility policy would we allow each veteran and dependent to re-open claims, or should it be just restricted to new claims? We would be raising hopes of success when, in fact, in many cases the new eligibility may result in little or no difference. I agree that the matter should be investigated and my Department is doing what it can but I feel that it should be part of an overall review of the whole repatriation compensation system. Eligibility is only one part of the pension structure. The system of paying pensions to veterans and dependants has basically remained unchanged since the original Act of 1920. If we are to undertake a review of the major part of the compensation system I am of the strong view that such a review should be done in an integrated approach to the whole system. A partial aproach as suggested by the Opposition may go some way to removing differences but could create greater overall probems.

I mention also that some strange comments were made in another place to the effect that administrative means were being sought to meet the effects of court decisions. Those comments appear to be based on a belief that any improvements in the administrative system or procedures are to be viewed with suspicion. It is very much in the interest of veterans that the administration of the repatriation system and of programs for veterans be as efficient and cost- beneficial as possible. Both the Repatriation Commission and I see it as an urgent need to speed up the determination systems. More resources have been obtained and action is being taken to improve and streamline administrative systems and procedures and to introduced better management information and training arrangements at all levels of the system.

Since the Government assumed office many benefits have been extended. Let me just mention some. We have extended the service pension to all allied veterans who served in theatres of war. Last year we extended the service pension to merchant mariners. I take the point about allied merchant mariners and that is something which I will be considering in the next few weeks leading up to the Budget. We have increased to 60 per cent the level of disability pension disregarded in the income test for service pension. The major pensions are indexed twice a year in line with movements in the consumer price index. We have extended free treatment to Australian merchant mariners who were prisoners of war and to veterans with certain service-related amputations or loss of vision in one eye. Disability pension eligibility has been extended to members of peacekeeping forces and former members of the Royal Papuan Constabulary and the New Guinea Police Force. The Repatriation Review Tribunal replaced the old War Pensions Entitlement and Assessment Appeals Tribunals in 1979 and for the first time veterans were given reasonable access.

To return to the philosophy that I mentioned earlier, this Government believes that veterans should be compensated for incapacity due to their service. However , as much as we would like to increase and extend benefits there must be a limit on the extension and increases. Veterans' Affairs is not an island. It is an area that has to take its place, high though it must be, in the expenditure priorities of the nation. The Government is firmly committed to the provision of the highest possible level of care for veterans.
