In Veterans' Affairs, as anywhere else, the best of intentions must be tempered by the reality that these are tight economic times and in no area of Government involvement can the taxpayers' dollar be expected to stretch indefinitely. There is a limit on the community's capacity to pay and the success of the Government's policy of stimulating economic activity while reducing inflation must always remain the most important influence on the degree to which benefits can be expanded. We must have regard to those in greatest need so as to ensure that the maximum benefit for the taxpayers' dollar is assured. The Government has been concerned that the real needs of the most severely disabled veterans must be measured and met.

This Bill reflects the Government's acceptance of its responsibility. It is extending compensation cover to members of the Sinai force; it is removing the stigma that has been placed on some mentally ill veterans; and it is removing the burden on patients by allowing the Repatriation Commission to recover costs from third parties. It is a Bill that recognises the tradition of the repatriation system. The Government, the Parliament and the public must ensure that no Australian veteran is treated in an undignified way or is disadvantaged by any program in the Veterans' Affairs arena. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be absorbed to hear the Bounty Acts Amendment Bill 1982 involves bounties and the continuation of bounties for another year on drilling bits and non-adjustable wrenches. The subject of non- adjustable wrenches is notable for perhaps two reasons. One is that since legislation on this matter appeared in this place it has been the subject of a continued series of execrable puns on the subject of inflexibly-minded persons of the female sex. The other thing that is notable in this Parliament about non- adjustable wrenches is that they represent the legislative debut of Senator Siddons, not in his capacity as an honourable senator but, of course, in his capacity through the Sidchrome organisation as one of the founding fathers of Australian spanners. Despite those various excitements associated with this Bill it must be ac- knowledged that the conjunction in a single piece of legislation of measures dealing with drilling bits and non-adjustable wrenches offers little scope for the exercise of the creative legislative imagination except perhaps to those whose minds are not as entirely pure as they should be.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation does, however, offer some scope for expansion on the general theme of the state of Australian manufacturing industry and on the relationship of that industry to the alleged resources boom which is occurring in this country. However, fascinating as those things may be, I think they were admirably expatiated upon by my learned colleague Mr Hurford in the other place and I do not propose to burden the Senate with a repetition of what was an excellent speech on that occasion. Indeed, although earlier today I was accused by Senator Walters in the context of the debate on the Australian Capital Territory Public Assembly Ordinance of being verbally intoxi- cated, I think I can assure Senator Walters and the Senate that I am not even the mildest bit verbally tiddly so far as this matter of non-adjustable wrenches and drilling bits is concerned.

In the few moments remaining to me, let me perform my allotted task as the representative in this place of the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce by saying something about what is clearly an important piece of legislation as far as it goes. The bounties or the subsidies for these industries were introduced as a short term assistance measure, initially at double the rate which is provided for in this Bill. The extension of the bounty scheme until the end of this year at half the rate can be seen as a phasing arrangement towards a lower rate of assistance. From the beginning of next year the form of assistance will revert to tariffs-25 per cent for the non-adjustable wrenches industry and 15 per cent for the drilling bits industry. We on the Opposition side of this Parliament have taken the view that these industries, despite their comparatively small size, are very important to the country. They confer industrial benefits of a kind that only local manufacturing industry can confer, namely advanced technology, the employment of skilled labour, security of supply of strategically and industrially important items, and the spreading of the benefits such as they are, that are available to the minerals industry and to a wider range of occupations.

The two industries concerned, we are reliably informed, are not likely to require heavy assistance in the longer term. Indeed, they have not received much assistance at all from the public purse so far. Senator Siddons advises me that in his previous incarnation as a manufacturer he has made something like five trips to the Industries Assistance Commission since 1958. This legislation represents the first time that he has so much as a crumb from the public purse. Although the assistance involved has been neither high nor very lengthy in its duration, I am sure that it has been appreciated so far as it has gone and I say on behalf of the Opposition, that I am sure it has been necessary. The tariffs that are proposed-of 25 per cent for the non-adjustable wrenches industry and 15 per cent for the drilling bits industry are not high by any standard, particularly in comparison with other industries generally and more particularly in comparison with the average manufacturing industry. I am told by Mr Hurford that the average for manufacturing industry was about 15 per cent and the average for the metal industries in particular was about 20 per cent. This is a lot lower than many people in our community think.

Finally, we take the view in relation to this Bill that the provision of additional short term assistance, such as is provided for in this legislation, is justified and is necessary to allow the firms engaged in these industries to improve their competitiveness through new investment and improved quality. If that proceeds according to plan it will not be necessary, as I say, for legislation of this kind to reappear much more often, if at all, in the future. For all those reasons, I indicate that the Opposition does not oppose this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise merely to thank Senator Evans for his contribution to the debate and his support for the Bounty Acts Amendment Bill 1982. It is a shame that Senator Siddons was not here to hear those words on this matter. I am sure he would have given it his support on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1982OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to put the point of view of the Opposition on the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1982 and the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill 1982. The Opposition does not oppose this legislation. However, we have some reservations about it. Because of those reservations, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that charges should not be levied against needy students from any developing country'.

The legislation before us is an amendment to the 1980 legislation introduced by the Fraser Government for the purpose of imposing fees for overseas students attending tertiary institutions in Australia. Most of those students are attending universities or colleges of advanced education. Other students are in other forms of post-secondary education. The present legislation introduces an exemption from those fees for students from the South Pacific, including Papua New Guinea. It also increases the charges which are to be levied. Undergraduate fees are being increased from $1,500 to $1,700 a year. Students in the faculties of medicine, veterinary science, science and dentistry will pay fees of $2,200, an increase from the $2,000 that they previously had to pay. Doctor of philosophy students will not have their fees changed.

Although the Australian Labor Party does not disagree in principle with the view that students from overseas who are wealthy and who have means at their disposal ought to pay fees if they attended Australian universities, it has never been happy about this legislation. At the time the Government introduced it we believed that there was not an adequate explanation of how the overseas students scheme worked, which students would be affected by the imposition of fees, which students would have their opportunity to study in Australia eliminated by the imposition of fees, and what effect the imposition of fees and the reduction in the numbers of students would have on Australian tertiary institutions. We still maintain that not enough information has been given to the Parliament by the Government to justify these amendments.

We are happy to see that exemptions have been provided for students from the South Pacific region, including the students of Papua New Guinea. We ask: Why have the exemptions been restricted to students from those areas? It is the view of the Australian Labor Party that exemption from fees ought to be based on need . If there are needy students in the areas now able to be exempted, we welcome that; but we put forward the view that there would be needy students coming from other areas overseas to study in Australia who also ought to be exempted. For that reason we have moved the second reading amendment in the terms that we have . It seems to the Opposition that the imposition of fees across the board means that overseas students who really need help and really need access to study in Australia will not get it. Those who can afford to pay are not likely to be those in the greatest need, either educational need or financial need.

We note that the Government expects to collect $12m from this imposition of fees. I question whether that $12m is worth the disruption that the imposition of fees is causing to many overseas students and is worth the loss of prestige-I suppose I could put it that way-for Australia, which had previously been regarded very favourably by many of our neighbours whose countries are in a developing situation because we were providing something that they could not provide in their own countries; that is, a high standard of tertiary education. I think we should question whether the measure before us can be justified in terms of providing an extra $12m in revenue. The sum of $12m is not a lot of money. Certainly it is only a very small amount compared with the amount the Australian Government spends on overseas aid.

It is the view of the Opposition that access to our education facilities is in fact a form of overseas aid to many of our neighbours. In some cases it is probably the best form of aid we can find. We would prefer to see access to our tertiary institutions regarded as a means of aiding developing countries rather than simply as a means of collecting revenue to assist the Fraser Government to balance its Budget. It is strongly argued that education and training should be an important part of our foreign aid program. If honourable senators visit developing countries, as I have done in recent times, they will easily see that the real need is often in terms of expertise, understanding of modern technologies, administrative skills and so on. We can provide these sorts of things in our tertiary institutions. It is very important that we do not introduce policies which cut off access by our neighbours to our tertiary institutions.

The views of the Opposition were set out in great detail in the debate in another place by my colleagues Mr Dawkins and Mr Beazley. Mr Beazley pointed out in his contribution to the debate that, prior to the imposition of fees, Australia had actually been providing a free university for Asia. I agree with Mr Beazley that that was, in fact, an excellent thing for Australia to be providing for Asia. The Labor Party regrets that the imposition of fees has meant that that facility is no longer available to many Asian students. We do not know how many Asian students are being prevented from studying in Australia because of fees since the Government has not been very thorough in its investigation of the operation of the program.

However, the kind of assistance that we can offer via liberal access to our tertiary education is the kind of assistance that many of our neighbours in the region need and the kind of assistance which will make an important contribution to stability and harmony in the region. I think, as all honourable senators will agree, the experience of going through a tertiary education is a very formative one for most young people. Those of our overseas neighbours who come to study in Australian universities acquire not only expertise, knowledge and qualifications but also an understanding of the Australian political and social system and, I hope, a sympathy for it. This can only be in the interests of Australia's relations in the regions generally. I conclude by saying that the Opposition does not oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition clearly supports the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1982 and the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill 1982. The Bills seek to impose fees on private overseas students attending educational institutions other than universities and colleges of advanced education on a pro rata basis to and consistent with fees currently being charged to overseas students in universities and colleges. The sentiments expressed in Senator Ryan's speech that this action is not a deterrent to students from overseas countries coming to study in Australia and gaining the advantages that we seek to afford them are shared by many in the Parliament. Indeed, the Government does not by this measure, as I understand it, seek in any way to deter overseas students from gaining access to our universities, colleges of advanced education and colleges of technical and further education. Rather we are noting the ability of that group of overseas students who are so participating to make a part contribution through their private means towards the education that Australia is providing them. The taxpayers' interests in any government program must always be protected by this Parliament. It is the taxpayers' interests that the Bills look to in seeking an appropriate part payment by these overseas students.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government already acknowledges the main thrust of Senator Ryan's comments by specifically excluding from the measures in the legislation students from Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific countries. Indeed, almost all students from other developing countries receive full scholarships provided for by the Australian taxpayer through the Colombo Plan scheme and its parallel and extended programs. I do not know of any needy student from a developing country who will suffer from the charges brought about by the Bills. The Government and certainly I, as one Liberal senator who has taken a special interest in education matters and in overseas aid matters, recognise the measures in these Bills as in no way deterring overseas students from studying in Australia as they have done in the past nor do these measures deter needy students or place an extra burden upon them. Certainly, I would want it drawn to my attention in the coming months if there were even a single case of special need by an overseas student from a needy country.

The amendment moved by the Opposition is pious. We all recognise that what it seeks is important, but that aspect is already incorporated in the legislation. The amendment is unnecessary. The legislation, of course, achieves consistency in relation to technical and further education and other courses provided by the Commonwealth by charging the same level of fees to overseas students as are paid by their counterparts attending universities and colleges. For the reasons that I have stated I support the Bills before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague said that the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill and the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill were in the taxpayers' interests. I think that sums up the attitude of this Government on this very crucial matter which is a mixture of foreign policy and educational concerns rather than the very limited perspective in which Senator Teague and the Government has sought to place these Bills as though the whole question of our relationships with South East Asia, Papua New Guinea and the Pacific can be seen in a narrow, confined realm of the moneys to be paid out by the Federal Treasury.

SPEECH.PARA: I can think of no better investment in Australia's relations with South East Asia, the Pacific and the developing countries generally than the expenditure of moneys on the education in our educational institutions of the talented young people from those areas. There can be no doubt that the expenditure of several million dollars in that regard is worth four, five or ten times as much as direct aid in those countries. I put that quite seriously because it seems evident to me that, when such people return to their home countries, by virtue of their education quite clearly they will be in positions of influence and of decision making in the various levels whether it be industry, commerce, public corporations, the Public Service, professional areas or, of course, political life. That is where we need decision makers who are favourably disposed towards Australia. Furthermore, I believe their experience of some three or four years in Australia in a liberal democracy can only be beneficial to the political development of their countries when they return. They return with an understanding which, I believe, can only benefit our commercial and political relations with those countries.
To be quite frank, I was appalled at the bland way in which the second reading speech delivered by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) simply stated:

. . . the Government also decided, as part of Australia's special assistance, to meet the costs of overseas students charges from 1982 for nationals of Papua New Guinea and other South Pacific countries from its aid program for the region. The aim is to encourage more students from the area to come and study in Australia.

Senator Teague said he would want brought to his attention any case-even one-of a needy student who is denied access to Australia's educational institutions because of the operation of this scheme of levying a charge on overseas students when they undertake studies in this country. It seems to me quite apparent from reading that paragraph that the Government itself and the interdepartmental committee on which it depends must have come to the conclusion that needy, talented students from Papua New Guinea and the Pacific area have over the past two years been denied access to this country because their families, extended groups or supportive groups in their home villages, towns and countries could not support their education here.

Let us not forget: It is not merely a question of the fees that a particular institution might be en- abled to charge; it is a question of supporting the students here with reasonable accommodation, warmth and clothing in order to undertake their studies on a reasonable par with Australian students. That involves, perhaps, twice as much again as the actual fee component of their annual undertaking of studies in Australia. If $1,500 in fees is to be paid, one can say that perhaps each student's stay in Australia might cost from $5,000 to $6,000. That is a tremendous burden on a needy or average family or even a family group or an extended supportive group in the developing countries. As I said, the Government in that paragraph clearly admitted the validity of the points made by the Opposition back on 25 October 1979 when in that debate we emphasised that the effect of the Government's imposition of charges would be to narrow the opportunity for education to those young people from developing countries whose families already belong to a moneyed or racial elite. Let us not forget also that Australia's open-door policy not only enabled-as it should- students from developing countries without a wealthy family background to come and study here but also enabled those who, for racial or ethnic reasons, were denied access to higher education in their own countries to come to Australia to continue their studies. In fact, without being terribly selective one could surmise that many of Chinese or Indian origin in Malaysia, or perhaps the Tamils in Sri Lanka despite their relative wealth, could not find an opportunity to engage in higher education except for the opportunities that Australia had given them. The amendment proposed by the Opposition reads:
That the Senate is of the opinion that charges should not be levied against needy students from any developing country.

Senator Teague said that the amendment is not needed in light of the Government' s concession concerning students from Papua New Guinea and the Pacific countries . Why is South East Asia not important to Australia any longer in the fostering of good political relations?

TALK.START.PARA: —But they have the Colombo Plan scholarship.

—The more Senator Teague indicates the need for special aid programs, whether a particular South East Asian program, a Pacific program or a Papua New Guinea program, the more he admits the validity of the Opposition's original charge that this attempt by the Federal Treasury to raise some meagre millions is, in fact, inimical to Australia's foreign policy interests as shown by the various plans to which he alluded being used in order to overcome the deleterious impacts of this Act. I query whether the moneys entering the Australian education system via this Act-we have not heard from the Minister; before this debate finishes I want to hear what moneys are involved-are balancing the moneys spent on the administration of the Act, whether by the Commonwealth Public Service or by the educational institutions involved. It seems to me that the Senate deserves to know how much money is expended in ensuring that the Act is adhered to and how much money is actually raised by virtue of the operation of the Act. How much money is raised directly from those students, or their families, who do not benefit from a scholarship scheme, whether of their own government's making or of the Australian Government's making? Of course, the Minister's second reading speech said nothing of this.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that Senator Messner is anxious to hear any further comments I have to make on this point. I am amazed that such Bills are still introduced into the Parliament by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). Is it an educational matter primarily or is it a foreign affairs matter primarily? I think it is at least more in those spheres than it is in the sphere of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, except that the Government chooses to dress up this tuition fee as virtually a visa fee. That is the only reason why the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has a part to play in it. That is merely a mechanism. But it shows that the Government is obsessed by mechanisms instead of the substantive issues involved which are issues of foreign policy and of educational equity.

That is possibly the extent of the remarks that I wish to make, except to say that the Government gave an undertaking in 1979, as I recall, that it would bring to the Senate after a period of full assessment of the operation of the Act-its impact on the numbers of students entering the country.

Honourable senators will remember that part of the deal was that the numerical ceiling on the number of overseas students would be lifted. Why did the Minister not detail in his second reading speech what the impact of this Act has been after two years on the number of students entering Australia, from what countries they have come and, most importantly-given the tacit admission in the second reading speech-from what family and social backgrounds they have come? There is no doubt that the second reading speech tacitly admitted that the effect of this legislation has been to sustain the privileged, wealthy and ethnically or racially superior groups in the developing countries in the education of their children. The Government has got away with it because these overseas students are voteless. They are voteless and, therefore, voiceless and vulnerable to this sort of attitude of the Government that the taxpayers' interest is paramount, as Senator Teague so directly and honestly put it. That is the attitude and the policy of this Government. It has selected these students who are voteless and voiceless. It is up to the Senate to try to protect them.

I am only sorry, as I look at the list of speakers, that the Australian Democrats have not joined in this debate because I know and expect that Senator Macklin, in particular, would share the sorts of concerns which I have put forward, though, as I say, I have to assume that. I believe that this Senate has a very real duty on behalf of these voiceless and, therefore, vulnerable students to state as clearly as possible our opposition to these Bills in relation to charges on overseas students. It is with absolute support that I enter this debate with Senator Susan Ryan to say that the Senate should state very clearly to the Government that it is of the opinion that charges should not be levied against needy students from any developing country and that, furthermore, we should have the fullest possible rendering of accounts by the Government of the impact of this legislation over the past two years. The interdepartmental committee report is obviously in the hands of the Government. That IDC report must have looked at these matters exhaustively. Why could it not be tabled or at least its substance outlined to the Senate by the Minister so we can know what has really been going on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for its support of the legislation and note the amendment that reflects its concern in the area of needy students from any developing country. I make the point that it is extremely difficult to define such people; and I think both Senator Ryan and Senator Tate, speaking on behalf of the Opposition, would well acknowledge the difficulties in those areas. However, I noted the comments in the House of Representatives of my colleague the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) when he indicated that there would be a constant on-going study of this problem by both his Department and the departments with which he is working; that is, the Department of Education and others. Consequently, we hope to be able to gain more information on this matter as time goes by. These are clearly difficult areas on which to gain information and it is this Government's concern to get as much as is available into its hands.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate asked about the amount of revenue that would be forthcoming. I point out that the estimated amount to be collected in this financial year, 1981 -82, will be of the order of $11.9m. He raised a question about the cost of administration of the legislation. I am informed that it will not be very high. In fact, it will be undertaken by the staff of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is not expected that there will be dramatic increases in the cost of operating the Department as a result. I am unable to give him exact amounts as to the administration costs. Of course, it would be very difficult to try to get those for him during this debate. I undertake to refer the question to the Minister to see whether there is any more detailed information that I can provide to him.

Senator Tate raised a question concerning the trend in the numbers of overseas students arriving in Australia as a result of the implementation of this policy in 1979. It is useful to note that in 1979, 1,509 students from the Association of South East Asian Nation countries entered Australia. In 1980 that number jumped to 2,275. This indicates an increasing trend and one which I understand is continuing, although I am not able to give the honourable senator specific information about that. It is clear that legislation in respect of that area certainly has not adversely affected student arrivals. With regard to Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific, in 1979, 633 students entered Australia and in 1980 there was a decrease in that number to 537. I understand that in 1981 that number increased slightly but I am unable to give the honourable senator a specific figure. For that reason, in order to encourage students from that region and recognising our responsibilities and taking into account the considerations which Senator Tate mentioned during his speech, an exemption will be introduced to encourage more students to come from both Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific region. I understand that that exemption will be introduced by ministerial direction and consequently will not require legislation and nor will it be incorporated in the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill. I believe that the Bill in general terms, apart from the amendment, has the support of all parties in the Senate. Consequently I wish it a speedy passage.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) said in answer to a matter which I raised during the second reading stage-that $11.9m would be raised this financial year. I think there is some ambiguity in that statement and I just want to clear it up in my own mind. The question I asked was: What moneys would be contributed by the students or their families alone? I do not want to know whether educational institutions will receive $11.9m from whatever source, in other words, from home government scholarships, Australian Government aid, or whatever. I want to know how much money will actually come into the Federal Treasury from overseas students' private sources. I wonder also whether the Minister can tell me, how much money has been set aside to fund the aid program to Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific islands? Approximately how many students will benefit from that money being set aside for this purpose? Are those moneys additional aid moneys or are they to be taken out of existing aid moneys to the detriment of other programs in those developing countries?

—The amount of $11.9m which is estimated to be raised by the legislation is to be sourced from the students. That is the amount which will be charged to them. I am not certain whether that is precisely the information the honourable senator is seeking. Perhaps the honourable senator could make his point more clearly in later discussions. We might then be able to get further information for him on that point direct from the Department. With regard to the question of the cost of aid for the exemption of South Pacific and/or Papua New Guinea students, it is estimated that the cost in forgone revenue this year will be of the order of $500,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond briefly to the remarks Senator Tate made during the second reading stage. From my point of view he noted that the Government's position was to make the taxpayer's interest paramount. That is an overemphasis of what I said and, I believe, of what the Minister for Veteran's Affairs (Senator Messner) said during the second reading stage. There is the question of the interests of our foreign policy in terms of overseas aid development to neighbouring and developing countries; the question of the educational needs of the students from Australia and overseas; and the question of the taxpayers' interest. It is appropriate to see a balance between these interests. I am not wanting to argue that in this matter the taxpayers' interest is so paramount that we exclude the other interests. Indeed the cost these days of a tertiary course of study is in recurrent terms, $6,000 a year. Overseas students with private means, often from wealthy families, are required by the overseas student charges, to pay about one-third of that recurrent cost. That does not take into account the capital provision in developing our educational institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate said that he would prefer the forgoing of these overseas student charges and have even four times the amount of that money involved in direct overseas aid, such as food aid, to developing countries in our region. If there are elite, wealthy families in all of the countries around us-and there are- including the developing countries, does Senator Tate seriously contend that rather than spend even four times that amount of money on food for the poorest in those countries we should allow the children of those wealthy, elitist families, who quite properly seek the best education available for their children, to come to Australia? I do not agree with that proposition. I believe that that perspective is misplaced.

I want also to note that in all of the countries about us from which students are coming to Australia there are well-established and often excellent universities such as the university in Kuala Lumpar, the university in Singapore , the University of the South Pacific in Fiji which serves many in the developing countries of the South Pacific such as Kiribati, Vanuatu, the Solomon Islands and so on. I believe that the idealism which has been expressed by Opposition speakers is already fully incorporated in the Bill. By not referring to the wealthy resources in the hands of some of the families who have some of the highest incomes even in developing countries, we have lost some perspective. By not referring to the educational institutions that are often of a very excellent standard in those countries again we are losing perspective. I wish to put it on the record that many interests are in the balance, including the Australian taxpayers' interests. We should by no means distort this matter by saying that we would prefer to forgo this $11m instead of allocating say $44m for food aid which is so important to those in much greater need in the countries round about us.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a brilliant second reading speech in the Committee stage. I want to ask a simple question. I was attracted to a matter that Senator Tate raised. I ask the Minister: When aid is given to overseas students is aid also given to bring the families of those students to Australia? In other words, are the fares of those dependants paid?

—There is no provision of aid for the families to be brought to Australia. Of course, I repeat that the charge about which we are speaking is estimated to total $500, 000. It represents a forgone revenue in terms of fees not actually charged to those students.

—I now emphasise the matter that Senator Tate raised. Is it now the case that because full assistance is not given to these students only those of moneyed or elitist families can take advantage of the aid that we are proffering? Does not the Minister realise that by not assisting the families of these students we place the students and their families in a situation of separation and further hardship? I raise the point now because I think it necessary for the Minister and the Department to take on board the need to give the fullest assistance to these students in such a way that it can be of benefit to them and not add a hardship to an already existing hardship.

—I note Senator Georges's point. But during my earlier remarks I mentioned that the area of needy students, their needs and the way in which these are properly assessed is an ongoing concern of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs which operates this legislation. Also of course, as the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) pointed out in the House of Representatives, there will be ongoing co-ordination with the other departments involved to ensure that more information is gathered on this question which, as I hope Senator Georges and the Opposition will appreciate, is one of some difficulty in terms of accumulating data.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is gratifying to hear that there will be an ongoing study into these matters. The fact is that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) and the Government have had available to them an interdepartmental committee report which, no doubt, must have reviewed two years of operation of this legislation, leading as it did, to the decision concerning the Papua New Guinea and Pacific Islander students in this country. I wish to ask a couple of questions which were raised in the debate of 25 October 1979. Government speakers at that time-I probably have to except Senator Teague who was a moderate at that stage but who has been a little more extreme tonight- spoke in defence of the legislation. They indicated two quite defamatory points in support of the Bill. One was the overseas students in this country were pursuing courses which were useless to them back home. In fact, I brought evidence to the Senate that showed, for example, that whereas 33 per cent of Australian students undertake what one might call liberal-arts-humanities courses, only just over 10 per cent of overseas students undertook such courses.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the proportion of overseas students in engineering, architecture and so on, which skills were essential to those developing nations, was much higher than the proportion of Australian students undertaking such courses. I would like to know whether the Minister can make available to the Committee a survey of the fields of study of overseas students in Australia over the last two to three years to see whether there has been any change in that trend and whether there is anything to support a statement by, I remember, Senator Davidson, who was in the Senate at that time that these students were pursuing courses that were of no use to them at home, leaving the inference that, in fact, they were here simply because they were indulging themselves at the expense of their wealthy parents and the Australian taxpayers.

The other argument put forward was that some 70 to 75 per cent of these overseas students were applying for permanent residence in Australia and were receiving that permission from the Government. In other words it was put that these students were not returning home to serve their developing countries as they should. That argument failed to recognise that those figures were based on two facts peculiar to Australia's situation at that time. Many of the students involved who were applying for and obtaining permanent residency, at that time were in fact refugees from Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. Of course, it was unthinkable that they should be returned compulsorily somehow to their homelands if, in fact, their families and their social lives in those war-torn countries had been destroyed. So there was an artificial levelling of the figures in that regard from that situation.

Secondly, it is a fact that if we simply do not want to school these students and if we simply do not want to give them graduate diplomas or degrees there has to be some mechanism which allows them to stay in the country for two or three years, maybe to obtain professional or technical expertise in the area of their study. Particularly does this apply to a field like engineering-that is, as I say, if we want to educate them. So my second question is: Can the Minister now indicate to the Senate on the basis of the IDC report which, to be exhaustive, must have looked into this, what percentage of overseas students are returning to their developing countries in order to help the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coming directly to Senator Tate's question I understand the situation now is that almost all students are returning to their home countries. I point out that, further to the points that he made during his remarks, before 1979 the criteria for entry was based mainly on the non-availability of courses in the home countries of overseas students as he pointed out. This sometimes led to the students proposing to undertake courses of little relevance to their home countries. Since 1980, new private student criteria have enabled more students to be accepted from wider groups of countries. Those criteria take into account the training capacity of Australia, that is, without displacing Australian students in institutions in this country and such other factors as academic ability of overseas students, the relevance and the value of the proposed courses to their home countries and, of course, the value of those courses to themselves as students. I hope that satisfies Senator Tate's concerns in this matter. There are, of course, the normal requirements with regard to the interdepartmental committee report. But I understand that these matters were thought through as is indicated by the remarks that I have just made.

— My mind is still haunted by the possibility of a student coming to this country for five years and being separated from his wife and children. What specific comfort can the Minister give to me that when the Government considers the needy category it will consider this sort of case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to Senator Georges earlier that I would draw those remarks to the Minister's attention and ask that, in the ongoing concerns and investigation of these matters, he take into account the kinds of views that Senator Georges has put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment or requests; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Messner) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 25 March, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill is another of the fat omnibus Bills which have been popping up at the rate of about two a year for the last couple of years in respect of a miscellany of so- called non-controversial matters. This Bill contains 237 clauses. It deals with amendments to 39 different Acts and involves in ministerial portfolio areas about 10 different Ministers or, in the case of the Opposition, shadow Ministers . That means that it is not with a huge amount of confidence, even given the three weeks the Opposition has had to look at this Bill, that I can advise the Senate that there is nothing in the legislation which is controversial. Our look at it to this date-it is a difficult business dealing with such a sprawling piece of legislation- suggests that the description of it as non-controversial by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is accurate and for that reason we will not oppose it.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish, however, to refer to several matters arising out of this Bill. One comes again to the question of the presentation of legislation in this form. We acknowledge that tidy-up Bills of this kind, as they might be described, have a useful function but only within certain narrow limits. The test as to whether it is appropriate for amendments to be included in an omnibus Bill of this kind or whether they should have separate Bills to themselves must be twofold-firstly, whether they have an impact of real substance on a particular class of citizens and, secondly, whether it is important in practice that there be ready and convenient access to the legislative changes in question by those affected by them and, of course, by those who advise them. By that test I guess it is perfectly appropriate to include matters relating to such things as the parliamentary disallowance of delegated legislation, the composition and structure of statutory tribunals and a number of matters relating to the formal administration of territories and such like. Matters of that kind are perfectly appropriate to be dealt with in a Bill of this kind but I and the Opposition are not at all sure that that is the correct approach to adopt in dealing with matters as momentous in this legislation as those concerned with the operation of the national companies and securities legislation. We had occasion to make remarks of a similar kind in respect of several categories of amendment in the last round of omnibus legislation of this kind. It is in respect of the companies and securities legislation and the amendments relating to companies and securities that I make the same remarks on this occasion.

The companies and securities scheme, about which I will have more to say in a few moments as it is affected by these particular amendments is already notriously complex and difficult to untangle from the point of view of companies on the ground and legal practitioners advising them. That was not the intention of the new national co-operative scheme which has been recently set in train. It was the hope that practitioners could get by with reference to the Australian Capital Territory legislation in force at any given time without having to have regard to the accompanying State legislation which gave that Australian Capital Territory legislation in force for the time being application in the respective States. But, as things have already turned out and as it appears from the first round of litigation that the companies legislation has experienced, it is already evident that there have been cries of pain, not only from practitioners but also from judges coming to grips with the matter for the first time, about the number of different Bills, both State and Federal, that it is necessary to juggle on one's judicial lap in order to work out what the law is on a particular matter at any given time.

It is obvious that it just adds an extra layer of difficulty to the business of working out what the law is when very important amendments to national legislation of the kind contained in the Bill before us tonight are contained in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, which deals with literally dozens of matters other than the companies and securities legislation and is not by its very nature easy material to find, to get access to and to work out its application to the companies area in question. Things may be different if and when we ever get a national computerised information retrieval system and instant access to and instant consolidation of legislation as it exists from time to time with legal practitioners right around the country being plugged into computer terminals which will throw up that information. Pending that particular millennium it is important, in our submission, to keep the statute book as streamlined as possible. Where there are, I repeat, important amendments of the kind in issue in this Bill they ought to have separate Bills to themselves labelled accordingly.

Having got that off my chest, I will refer to three particular substantive areas dealt with by this Bill-two of them very briefly and the third at more length. The first area I refer to is that of the very important amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act as they relate to the status of delegated legislation which is repealed by subsequent regulations and ordinances. At the moment, when a new ordinance or regulation comes into effect and has the operative effect of repealing some earlier regulation the earlier regulation does not spring back to life if and when the new piece of subordinate legislation is disallowed by the Parliament. What happens if the Parliament disallows, for any one of the reasons available to it, a new regulation or ordinance is that in a sense a legislative vacuum is created. The previous law repealed by the new regulation does not spring back to life when the new regulation itself dies. That is the kind of situation we had occasion to refer to earlier today in the context of the new Australian Capital Territory Public Assemblies Ordinance. The difficulty that the existence of this state of affairs creates for the Senate is that there is a disincentive on some occasions to the Senate proceeding to disallow a piece of legislation because to do so a legislative vacuum would thereby be created in areas which may be crying out for some continued form of regulation. That matter was the subject of recommendations not so long ago from the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. It is with some pleasure that we note in this legislation their emergence into law. I will not say anything more about this matter except to draw the Senate's attention to a quite learned note on the effect of this legislation by Mr Ernst Willheim in the Australian Law Journal of October 1981.

The second substantive matter to which I refer concerns some significant machinery changes to the membership and structure of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. They are all detailed in the Attorney-General's second reading speech. I have no need to go over the ground in any detail except to note for the record clause 22 of this Bill, which changes in very important ways the provisions relating to statements of reasons under section 28 of the existing Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act. The Tribunal is now to be empowered to review a refusal by a decision-maker to give a statement of reasons for a decision whereas previously that option was not available where that kind of intransigence was being confronted. There are further provisions-I am summarising some complicated provisions rather quickly-to ensure that, where a certificate is given by the Attorney-General preventing disclosures of certain material, that will not result necessarily in the whole of the material in question being withheld but only so much of it as is covered by the certificate. There is a provision, in other words, for splitting certified confidential material in a way that will, I think, expedite the administration of justice in this area. Other things can be said about those procedural changes, but essentially they are straightforward and are welcomed by the Opposition.

The main substance of what I wish to say in the time remaining to me relates to the amendments to the National Companies and Securities Scheme. There are important amendments in this legislation to three of the five copies which comprise the Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme, namely, the companies code, the takeover code and the securities industry code. In accordance with the formal agreement between the Commonwealth and the States governing the creation of this Scheme, amendments to the Scheme legislation have to be agreed to by the Ministerial Council. Once they are agreed to, brought before the Commonwealth Parliament and enacted by the Commonwealth Parliament they are automatically given operative force in the States.

Given the complexity of that process which I have had occasion to criticise on several occasions in the past, I think it is important to note, and to note approvingly, the speed with which these amendments, in particular the remedial ones to which I will refer in more detail in a moment, were drafted, approved, and now presented to Parliament. It is just two months since the then late lamented Minister, Mr Moore, who I notice in September last year in the House of Representatives described himself perhaps rather prophetically as a simple country lad, announced that amendments would be introduced at the earliest opportunity to shore up the powers of the NCSC against inroads which were being made into them. Two months may not seem like lightning speed, but given the lethargy with which the Government has been acting in a number of other related areas in recent times, which may conceivably be the subject of some attention during Estimates committees' hearings tomorrow, it is a matter for applause that things have moved as quickly as they have in this area. I grant the Government that applause unstintingly and unreservedly. It was important that there be remedial legislation here, and that remedial legislation has been prepared. The Government acted, extraordinary as it may sound, with dispatch.

Let me say something about the major categories of amendment. First, I shall refer to the Companies Act. The most significant amendment in terms of the overall operation of this Scheme is clause 85 of this Bill inserting a new Section 16A into the Companies Act. This will empower the National Companies and Securities Commission to institute an investigation when it has reason to suspect that a person has committed an offence under the Companies Act. That is an eminently sensible addition to NCSC's armoury, one might think, and indeed so it is. The real question is this: Why was it not included in the Companies Act in the first place as the companion power to the special investigations provisions in Part VII of that Act and the power of inspection in Part II, division I, there already being, for example, such an explicit power of investigation provided for in the Securities Industry Act, in addition to those other powers.

The point to be made, I guess, is that this new section 16A is not primarily being inserted for its own sake but rather as a response to the very bad scare which the NCSC and the Ministerial Council recieved at the hands of the Queensland Supreme Court in the Pine Vale case in February. It is being inserted to ensure that the NCSC is able to hold public hearings in relation to matters arising under the Companies Act and, more importantly, under the takeover code. There is a general power under section 36 of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act, and section 7 as it is of corresponding State Acts, to hold public hearings 'for the purpose of the performance of any of its functions or the exercise of any of its powers'. But the Queensland Supreme Court in its wisdom held, however, that a hearing could not be held in relation to takeover matters unless there was in the takeover code a power of investigation.

It has been my firm view which I have expressed in this place before that this involves a quite mistaken interpretation of the law and that the public hearing power is in fact quite general and unlimited as it exists at the moment. As it turned out, however, the NCSC chose not to appeal the decision and the Ministerial Council cautiously, but quite understandably in the circumstances, decided to secure the amendment of the legislation to make doubly sure that the Commission's power to hold hearings is clear and unchallengable. That is technical stuff, but it is very important and I am glad to see that the action has been taken.

Secondly, I shall refer to the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act, the takeover code. There are several important amendments. The first of them relates to the power of the court to make interim orders when applications are made under sections 45, 47, 48, 57 and 60 of the code. This will enable the court to make an order pending the hearing and determination of the application when it regards it as desirable to do so. That means that immediate action can now be taken where necessary, for example, to protect rights under section 47 without having to wait for the full argument before the court and the decision of the court. I hope that the ever-cautious Australian courts will make use of this new power to serve its manifest purpose.

The second amendment in this area relates to the power of the NCSC to declare the acquisition of shares or other conduct to be unacceptable. Section 60 is amended so that the NCSC will have 90 days instead of 14 days in which to decide to make such a declaration. Fourteen days was clearly too short a period in practice and, as this is an extremely important power in practice enabling the NCSC to enforce the spirit as well as the letter of the takeover scheme legislation, and these matters being as they are invariably complex, requiring time to unravel, I supported, in speaking to the NCSC 1980-81 report, the NCSC's call for such an extension of its powers in this respect and I welcome this as again a very sensible change.

The third matter to which I draw attention under this head, and the most significant change in this batch of amendments-it is a change of a creative rather than a remedial kind-is the insertion of a new section 60A by clause 133 of this Bill. This will empower the NCSC, when it has made a declaration under section 60 that an acquisition of shares or other conduct is unacceptable, to make certain orders simply by an instrument published in the Commonwealth Government Gazette. Those orders will expire after 30 days if no earlier expiry date is specified. Further, there is the provision that no order may be made unless the person to whom the order is directed has had an opportunity to appear at a hearing before the Commission to make submissions. The orders thus available to the NCSC are similar to those already available to the court on application by the Commission and are virtually identical to those available to the Commission under section 35 of the securities industry code and section 311 of the companies code in the course of investigations under those codes.

I think it is important to emphasise to anyone who considers that this is, as some people apparently do, an alarming new accretion of power to a regulatory body, that the power of the Commission to make orders of a similar kind has existed in section 35 of the Securities Industry Act since that Act first came into operation on 1 July 1981 and also, as I said, in section 311 of the Companies Act. To my knowledge there has been no public opposition to the existence of that power in that context and I am surprised that there are signs of it being voiced in the context of the Bill before us tonight.

The real significance of this change is that it reverses the onus of going to court. Instead of the NCSC having to go to court to have orders made as at present and then confronting the legalistic negativisim of the common law tradition, as has been graphically demonstrated by the cases in which the NCSC has already come to grief, it will now be up to any person aggrieved by the court to apply to the court for variation or revocation of the order. In a very important way this will enhance the flexibility and speed of movement of the Commission while maintaining the necessary protection of the right of appeal to the court.

The final matter to which I refer is the securities industry code which is amended by clauses 209, 210 and 213 of the Bill in ways that are attractive and acceptable and are welcomed by the Opposition. When I spoke on 18 February on the report of the NCSC annual report, I suggested that a strong need had been demonstrated for a section 15AA-type provision directing the courts to have regard to the purpose of the scheme as set out in the formal agreement in the legislation and in the scheme as a whole. That is conspicuous by its absence. I understood that there was some opposition from the States. I reiterate the importance of that provision and my mystification and that of the Opposition that there should be any opposition to it. The Opposition does not oppose the speedy passage of this legislation.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question :

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Opposition for its support of the measure and hope it will have a very speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Trachoma and Eye Health Program-Anti-discrimination Legislation-Arts Funding-Queensland Premier-Bureau of Customs: Procedures-Membership of Sporting Clubs-Queensland Aboriginal Land Rights

PROCTEXT.PARA: National Trachoma and Eye Health Program-Anti-discrimination Legislation-Arts Funding-Queensland Premier-Bureau of Customs: Procedures-Membership of Sporting Clubs-Queensland Aboriginal Land Rights
Motion (by Senator Durack) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for delaying the Senate this evening to speak in the adjournment debate but I think it is very important that I do in light of recent events and recent statements concerning a very important matter. I say to my Senate colleagues that if they are interested in the matter I am to talk about tonight it would be beneficial for them to look at the Hansard record of 8 November 1977, page 2263, when I made a speech concerning a matter that is very important and relevant to the matter I am raising tonight, that is, the trachoma project that was taking place in my State of Queensland. On 1 April 1980 I again made a speech in this place about the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program in my State of Queensland. If honourable senators like to refresh their memories they can look at the Senate Hansard of 1 April 1980, page 1299. I made quite a lengthy speech concerning these matters. Again, they seem to have been raised in my State of Queensland. If one looks at the Courier-Mail of yesterday's date, one will find that the Premier of Queensland has raised some questions concerning the trachoma problem in Queensland. The statement that is allegedly attributed to the Premier of Queensland was made under the headline 'Joh questions eye program' the article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Reintroduction of a trachoma and eye health program for Queensland Aboriginals would depend on the political affiliations of the program officials concerned, the Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, declared yesterday.
'We naturally would want to assist in helping to improve Aboriginal health standards, Mr Bjelke-Petersen said.
But I would like to have a close look at the program first to see who's on it.
'I have no objection provided it is used as a medical and not a political exercise.

If one looks at the speeches I made in this place on the dates I have already cited, one will recall that the Premier of Queensland consulted with his Federal colleague, the Hon. Ralph Hunt, who was at that time the Minister for Health. The Premier was able to block the trachoma scheme in Queensland because he said that Aboriginal political activists were going around telling Aboriginal people to vote for the Australian Labor Party. Whether that was true or not is beside the point. The point I brought up at that time and I bring up again tonight because of what the Premier has said, is that the trachoma and eye health scheme in Queensland will not go ahead despite Federal funding and Federal support for the scheme. It will not go ahead if the Premier of Queensland believes the people involved in the delivery of that service may have some affiliation with some political party.

One does not need to ask the question: What political party? It could be the Australian Labor Party; it could be the Liberal Party of Australia, but because it is not the National Party, the Premier will not be happy about it. But if it happens that some of those officials or some of those Aboriginal people involved in this scheme who are working for the benefit and the betterment of Aboriginal people in my State of Queensland are not supporters of the National Party the scheme will not go ahead. I was upset-naturally so-because the Queensland Premier seemed to have this kind of power over a scheme that was supported financially and in every other way by the Federal Government and by all those people who are concerned with the health of Aboriginal people. He could stop that program and he did. It does not matter what anyone in this chamber may say after I have finished speaking tonight. He did not stop the program at that time and now he is saying that he will prevent it from going ahead if he feels that some of the people involved with the scheme may support a different political ideology from that which he supports. We are talking about the lives of people. As we know, trachoma can result in total blindness if it is not arrested and taken care of by the people who want to prevent it from getting to the stage where people are blinded.

We have a man who is prepared to say that that scheme will not go ahead, regardless of what effect it has on people's lives, if people's political affiliations and ideologies do not coincide with his. Let us not fool ourselves. He does not just mean the Australian Labor Party; he means the Liberal Party in Queensland as well. He has said so many things on a number of occasions about me as a member of the Liberal Party representing the State of Queensland in this chamber. He has branded me as an activist and a commo. His close friend and confidante Russ Hinze even branded me 'a little Afghan camel driver'. He and his machinery campaigned against me and my partner, Yvonne McComb in 1980 when we contested the Senate election. They said that the Liberal Party had put up a ' nigger and a nagger' and therefore people should not vote for us. I am not a nigger; I am proudly-fiercely proudly-an Australian Aborigine. I am not an Afghan camel driver. I do not say that in any denigration of the Afghan people. They are a fine and very nice people. I have met them. I have known them and I admire and respect them, but I do not happen to be one of them. Perhaps I should title this address 'the Joh and Flo Show', because they both come into the act. The editorial in yesterday's Courier-Mail-a major newspaper in the State of Queensland-is headed 'Let us save their sight' and states:
The plan to re-introduce trachoma teams to treat Queensland Aboriginals must go ahead, with or without State Government support.
It would be wrong, indeed inhuman, not to ensure that everything possible is done to save the eye sight of Queenslanders, black or white, who live in remote areas.

Hopefully the State Government will throw all its weight-and all its facilities -behind the new plan. Although the program would be funded by the Commonwealth it would need State support to be fully effective.

It is more than four years since the work of the trachoma survey team in north Queensland under Professor F. Hollows was interrupted by a dispute over a claim taken up by the Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, that two of Professor Hollows' field workers were urging Aboriginals to vote for the Labor Party-an allegation denied by the team leader.

The past should now be put aside. The proposal for a new team should not be a matter of party politics at all, but have the support of all parties and all Queenslanders. Trachoma, if untreated, causes blindness in a high percentage of sufferers.
The Premier yesterday indicated the State Government would consider supporting a new team provided it did not involve itself in politics and the people involved were acceptable.

Acceptable to whom? Acceptable to the Premier of Queensland? Why should they be acceptable to him? Why should they not be judged on their merits, on the job that they are about to do, will do and can do? Why should party policies come into it at all? We are talking about human beings-not animals, but people. The Premier says that these people can go blind if some of them in his opinion happen to support some party political ideology. I pray to God that we are above that kind of thing. I pray to God that this Commonwealth Government will say to the Premier of Queensland that the program will go ahead despite what he may think or what he may want, because people are more important than party politics . I know the people who were involved in the last program before it was halted and disbanded. Sure, they support a different party political ideology from mine . That is their prerogative. When I go out on the hustings before an election I try to encourage people to support my party and my party's candidates. I speak throughout the length and breadth of Queensland. Am I, then, to be classified by the Premier as a political activist? Goodness gracious me, there is not an honourable senator in this chamber-or an honourable senator who should be in this chamber-who does not go out and fight tooth and nail for his or her party and its candidates. Why would an honourable senator not do so? That is what politics is all about. Because some people were classified by the Premier of Queensland as political activists, a scheme that was going to provide relief to people who suffer from trachoma and who could eventually finish up blind was denied those people.

That is one side of the coin. On 11 March 1982 I asked a question of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). It concerned a statement by the same Premier, Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, that six Aborigines were undergoing training in Libya in guerrilla and terrorist activities. I asked a further question today following receipt of a reply from the Minister for Foreign Affairs stating that nothing like that is happening. But the Premier made that statement. He denigrated the Aboriginal people, putting them in a shocking light amongst their fellow Queenslanders, by alleging that they were training in Libya to disrupt, and to terrorise participants in, the Commonwealth Games to be held in Queensland later this year. An editorial in the Courier-Mail is headed 'Libyans training blacks in terrorism-Bjelke' and states:

Aboriginal activists are being trained in terror tactics in Libya, according to information in a Queensland police report which has been passed on to the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and the Australian Federal Police.

Mr President, I pose the question to you: If this information as given to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) when was it tabled in either the House of Representatives or in this chamber? To my knowledge it has not been tabled in this chamber. The information has been categorically denied by Aboriginal people . The Minister for Foreign Affairs in the answer he provided to my question stated:

I am advised that inquiries conducted by my Department and other relevant authorities have produced no evidence to verify that Aborigines are currently undergoing guerilla or terrorist training in Libya.

The Premier of Queensland says that they are being trained. Where are they being trained? By whom are they being trained? The Department of Foreign Affairs and other authorities in this country can find no evidence of that. The Premier says so. The people of Australia and the people of Queensland believe that Aborigines are being trained as terrorists.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are being fed a line.

—The point is that people read that and accept it. The only people who suffer are the Aboriginal people. They are branded by the Premier of my State of Queensland. No one, besides me, has said that this is not true. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided me with an answer. Why is that answer not reported by the Press?
—Do they really care?

—No, I do not think they do. The caption 'Aborigines training as terrorists in Libya' makes good headlines. They are going to come back to Australia and perform terrorist actions in this country! What a lost of nonsense . What a lot of poppycock. But the gullible public will take what these people write and accept it. They say that those nasty, naughty Aborigines, those vile terrorists, are going to do these things in Australia. I have not found a single , solitary Aboriginal who wants to disrupt or in any way harm the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane. I have not spoken to one. Statements have been made by a few people, but there are 160,000 Aborigines in this country. About half a dozen have talked about bloodshed at the Games. Is that a fair percentage? I think not .

SPEECH.PARA: I was talking about the so-called political activists in the trachoma scheme. The Premier of Queensland will not allow the scheme to go ahead. Let us look at the report in the Courier-Mail. There is the heading: 'TAB chief detained in his Rolls. Knight faces drive charge'. This is political patronage. The article states:
The TAB chairman and trustee of the National Party, Sir Edward Lyons, was detained by police over a drink driving offence last Friday morning but was not charged or arrested.

This is political patronage. If Aborigines who might be involved in this trachoma scheme, working for the betterment or the health of Aboriginal people, happen to be members of the Australian Labor Party or the Liberal Party, then the scheme will not go ahead. Here we have a knight in shining armour who is a trustee of the National Party in Queensland. He is accosted on a drink driving charge. That is all covered up because he happens to be a trustee of the National party.

TALK.START.PARA: —He also happens to be white.

—Of course. That makes a great deal of difference. The saying goes: 'If you are white, you are right. If you are brown, stand around. If you are black, step back'. That has gone on for years. That brings me to the third part of what I want to talk about tonight. There is a report in the Courier-Mail of 10 April 1982. It is entitled 'Use blacks funds for roads-Flo'. I do not need to elaborate on who Flo might be. I said at the beginning of my speech that perhaps I should call my address tonight: 'The Joh and Flo show'. The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government's $48 million allocation to buy properties for Aboriginals would be better spent on Queensland roads, Senator Flo Bjelke- Petersen said yesterday.

What, $48m is to be used to buy land? The whole budget of the Aboriginal Development Commission is $48m. This amount is for all the things the Aboriginal Development Commission has to do. It has not bought one single solitary acre of land in Queensland. Some time ago before the creation of the Aboriginal Development Commission another body tried to buy land in Queensland. It tried to buy the Archer River cattle station for the use of Aboriginal people, but the Queensland Government which had the final authority through the Department of Lands refused to have the lease transferred to the Aboriginal people because the Premier said that it would create an Aboriginal enclave. That is a dirty word. Blacks cannot have land, but the Japanese can have land. Honourable senators only have to look at Iwasaki at Yeppoon. The article continues.
'The Federal Government should stop buying properties for Aboriginals through its Aboriginal Development Commission chairman, Mr Charles Perkins,' she said.
'It would be $48 million well saved. It's not necessary for Mr Perkins to go around buying whatever land he thinks would be good,' she said.
'A large allocation of funds already goes to the Aboriginal Affairs Department. The Aboriginals are pretty well looked after by both State and Federal Governments.'
Senator Bjelke-Petersen said she would push hard for the Federal Government to direct funds from such 'much less important areas' to road works in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to have roads before people.

—Of course. Let us look at some of the figures in the annual report of the Department of Social Security for 1980-81. An amount of $3,935,796 was for expenditure on aged pensions. Should we take some of that money from the aged people and put it into the roads in Queensland? Why not do so? If we are going to take it from the Aboriginal people, why not take it from the pensioners ? What is the difference? Pensioners are people; Aborigines are people. I wonder whether Senator Flo would suggest to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) that in future, instead of giving that enormous amount of money to our senior citizens, we should spend it on roads in Queensland. Why not do so? If we are going to take the money from the Aboriginal people, why not take it from the pensioners? Let us look at the expenditure on unemployment benefit in 1980-81 -$995,748,000. Let us take a chunk from there and give it to Joh for his roads in Queensland. If we are going to take it from the Aboriginal people why not take it from the unemployed people? Let us look at a couple of other areas. Special benefits involve an expenditure of $66,100,000. We could use a chunk of that for roads in Queensland. Why not do so? What is the difference? Why take it just off the Aborigines? Why not take it off the people receiving special benefits? One could go on and on about areas from which money could be taken and put into roads because Flo thinks it should go into roads and not to people.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it not time that we started to look at what is best for people? What are we talking about? Whom are we talking about? What are we supposed to be here for? Why do we sit around this chamber? Why do we listen to speech after speech? Are we not concerned about people, their future, their lives, what affects them and how we can best serve them? Are we more concerned with denigrating a powerless, helpless, voiceless group of people within our community? I do not say that in any denigrating way. The Aboriginal people of this nation are voiceless and helpless. They have no political muscle and they depend on goodwill, generosity and Christian charity, if one likes to put it that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whoops-a-daisy; the charity.

—I am sorry if I offend the Minister but I talk as a Christian and I talk about Christian charity. If I offend the Minister I am sorry but I talk about Christian charity because I am a God-fearing man and I make no apology for that. I talk about the Christian charity of those of us who sit in this chamber and in the other place to bring about justice for a people who can do naught else for themselves. They depend on us. Senator Peter Baume is still, I hope, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. A lot rests on his shoulders as to whether the things that I have talked about tonight will go ahead or will be frustrated and prevented from going ahead by someone who has no feeling, no understanding, of the Aboriginal question and the Aboriginal people of a State over which he reigns supreme. He has done and will continue to do to the Aboriginal people of my State a disservice. I hope and pray that the Minister will not let this happen on this occasion, as it happened on the last occasion.
