SPEECH.PARA: Is it not time that this national Government, this Federal Government, this Commonwealth Government, had the intestinal fortitude to say to the Premier of Queensland and his government: 'We are going to do something and we are going to do it with or without your co-operation. We are going to do it despite you, not because of you'? I may have offended the Minister because I referred to Christian charity, but I am a Christian and I do not apologise for that. What we are lacking, what we need, in this country is a feeling for people-not just the Aboriginal people; many people in this country need our help, our compassion and our understanding of the plights in which they find themselves. I hope and pray that after I have spoken tonight some positive action will be taken in relation to what is happening in my State of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend delaying the Senate for too long. I was hoping earlier this evening to have an opportunity to raise these issues in a first reading debate. That opportunity did not come to hand, so I have to use the adjournment debate to speak on these three fairly important matters. The first matter relates to Customs. I recognise the difficulties which have been experienced by the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs and the new Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown), who have been in charge of Customs, in getting caught up with correspondence; but this is a matter of some concern because it relates to the attitudes expressed by Customs officers to members of the Australian community in Australia. A letter was written to the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs on 5 April. To the best of my knowledge no response has been received. A number of questions are contained in the letter.
—That is 5 April-about two weeks ago?
—Yes, two weeks ago. I will read the letter because I believe it is important. Unfortunately, it was addressed to 'Senator John Moore'. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: On February 3, 1982, I returned to Australia after a two and a half year privately funded study session at the West Virginia University in the United States of America.
The writer then gives her passport number. The letter continues:

A few days prior to my departure from the U.S., on January 8, 1982, I ordered and paid for an academic gown, cap and hood, the tailoring and airfreighted transport time of which were estimated at four to six weeks. Recently, on March 23-
The dates are very important-

I received a phone call from the academic dress co-ordinator at the West Virginia University who informed me, as a result of a communication from Mascot Airport, that the gown, cap and hood were being held up by the Sydney Customs Bureau at that airport and would not be forwarded to me at the above address because I had not re-entered Australia.
I make the point that she had re-entered Australia on 3 February, and this was now 23 March. The letter goes on:

Furthermore, the W.V.U. co-ordinator advised me that the above goods had been at the Mascot Airport for approximately four weeks and that she was warned that they were to be returned to the United States.
Subsequent to receiving this information I took the following action:

1. On the evening of March 23, I telephoned the Perth Customs after-hours section and asked to speak to the officer-in-charge. A Mr Jim O'Neil took the call. After outlining the above circumstances to him, I asked for his assistance by way of a phone call to the appropriate authority at the Mascot Sydney Customs Bureau. While sympathising with my problem, he refused this request, saying 'I am not prepared to do it. I'm not prepared to give a reason. My reasons are personal'. He was prepared however to be quoted.

2. Later on the same evening I placed a reverse charge phone call to the officer -in-charge of the Sydney Customs Bureau at Mascot Airport. The gentleman who answered the phone refused to accept the call.

3. On the morning of March 24 I placed a reverse charge phone call to the Sydney Customs Bureau at Mascot Airport. On this occasion the call was accepted. After detailing the problem I was transferred to a Mr Thorne from Pan-Am, who undertook to search for the goods, and advise me of the result. Later on the same day Mr Thorne telephone to say he had located the parcel, had cleared it through the Sydney Customs Bureau for transportation to Perth Airport, and had requested the domestic carrier, Ansett, to advise me of its arrival in Perth. This advice was received on March 25.
I am at a loss to understand why this was not done four weeks before, when the parcel was received. The letter continues:

4. At 10.20 a.m. on March 29, I attended the office of the Perth Customs Bureau with the appropriate papers from Ansett for clearance of the goods. Sixty minutes later, after begrudging cooperation in form-filling from one Customs officer, and 100% search by another, the parcel was released into my possession.
As a result of this experience, I respectfully request answers to the following questions:
1. Who, and by what manner, was it determined that I had not re-entered Australia on February 3, 1982?
2. On whose authority were the described goods detained in Sydney?
3. What is the connection between my residence or otherwise in Australia and the decision not to forward the goods which were addressed from the tailoring company in the United States to
Dr J. Stephenson,
P.O. Box 129,
Wembley,
Western Australia, 6014?
4. Why was Mr Jim O'Neill not prepared to make a phone call on my behalf, and what are the kinds of personal reasons that preclude a public servant from assisting an Australian citizen?
5. Is it possible to improve the standard of co-operation with the public of the officers at the Perth Customs Bureau?
6. Why did these goods have to be cleared by both the Sydney and the Perth Customs Bureau?
Your prompt reply to these questions would be appreciated.

I think a number of other questions need to be asked and answered. The first point is that the Customs officers are normally the first people whom people coming from overseas have contact with, and it is most important that a good public relations job is done by those Customs officers. As a general rule, my own experience and that of other people I have spoken with is that the public relations side of the Bureau of Customs is very good, although that has not been the case in the experience of Dr Stephenson. I will leave that matter with the Minister and I expect to get a fairly speedy response so that I can reply to Dr Stephenson.

The second matter I wish to raise is a matter of blatant discrimination in Victoria. I am sure that it is not an isolated case. It certainly applies in some areas of my State of Western Australia. I have not yet seen fit to take action, but it may be necessary for me to do so on behalf of this particular person. Firstly, I make the point that the person involved in this particular instance is at the moment just 11 years of age. She is an ardent cricket fan. As part of that passion, she wanted badly to become a member of a cricket club. She was a little unfortunate in that she chose the Melbourne Cricket Club which, I am sure everybody knows, is and always has been a very superior type club-at least in the eyes of its members! I might add that one of the first things I was informed about when I became a member of this chamber eight years ago was that my gold pass would admit me to the members section of the Melbourne Cricket Club . That I doubted then and still doubt, because I am female. But I would be very interested to hear from the MCC if it is prepared to admit me.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are lucky. You should be an Aboriginal and try to get in there.

—I go to lots of Aboriginal communities, I can assure you, Senator. I am not sure, quite frankly, whether this incident occurred late last year or early this year, but the girl in question approached the club with regard to membership. Under the dateline of 22 February this year she received the following letter addressed to Miss C. Howe, 6 Brennand Street, North Fitzroy , 3068:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Miss Howe,
Thank you for your letter of 10 February 1982 and your interest in the Club.
Unfortunately the constitution of the Club does not allow for the inclusion of female members and this situation is not likely to change in the foreseeable future.
At the present moment, the waiting period for membership is over 20 years and so you would not receive any immediate benefits if your name was permitted to be added to the waiting list.
With best wishes.
Yours faithfully,

I add that the letter is signed 'June Fitch, Assistant Registrar'-a female writing to another female and not only describing the sexist and discriminatory attitude of her employer but also virtually lauding her employer by saying:
. . . the waiting period for membership is over 20 years and so you would not receive any immediate benefits if your name was permitted to be added to the waiting list.

I have some sympathy with Ms June Fitch, the Assistant Registrar, but she obviously knew the rules of the club when she took the position. However, Miss Howe decided that, even at her tender years, she should not be prepared to accept that attitude. She approached the Equal Opportunities Council in Victoria . She was advised that she should approach the club to obtain a copy of its rules. This she did. Under the dateline of 5 March she received this response:
Dear Catherine-
We have now gone from 'Dear Miss Howe' to 'Dear Catherine'-
-I regret that I am unable to accede to your request to forward our Rules et cetera.
That raises a question in my mind, but I will come back to it later.
The letter continued:
However, if you wish to telephone me I would be happy to discuss the situation, and perhaps offer you some comfort in your quest.
Yours faithfully,
BRYCE THOMAS
Assistant Secretary

Now, quite frankly, what comfort could be offered by Mr Bryce Thomas to Miss Howe escapes me. If there is a situation in which one wants to participate in a particular activity but, because of one's sex and for no other reason-the fact that there is a 20-year waiting list is of no concern to the club; it is only of concern to the applicant-one is precluded from participating in that activity, I suggest that very little comfort is to be derived from a telephone conversation.

I could further suggest that, as there is supposedly a 20-year waiting list for membership, perhaps it is being occasioned by existing members taking advantage, as I understand is done at most public schools in the larger cities, of the opportunity to register the names of male offspring at birth to ensure that, when it might be appropriate to be able to say 'I am a member of the Melbourne Cricket Club', they will have the right club to which to belong. Perhaps I could suggest that there might be another cricket club in Victoria that would actually welcome having a 10-year-old female member. It would be a little public relations exercise on its part and perhaps it would get a little kudos through the media if it were to contact her and say: 'We are pleased that you are an enthusiastic supporter of our sport'. That is what clubs are supposed to be all about-supporters of the sport-but obviously the Melbourne Cricket Club is not that way inclined.

Perhaps some little comfort can be derived by Miss Howe, rather than as a result of Mr Thomas attempting to soothe her ruffled feathers by a telephone call, from the knowledge that she is not the only one to which this applies. For those honourable senators who did not read the Age yesterday I will read into the record a passage from the column headed 'Table talk'. A photograph shows Lady Murray and Mrs Toner. Of course, Lady Murray is the wife of Victoria's new Governor and Pauline Toner is the new Minister for Community Welfare Services. The report reads:

Lady Murray, the wife of Victoria's new Governor, and Pauline Toner, the new Minister for Community Welfare Services, are not exactly enamored of the Victorian sporting clubs' practices of separating men from women at official functions. Lady Murray was quite astounded to be separated from her husband the last time she attended a VFL luncheon, and Mrs Toner has been a long-time opponent of the dreaded white line.
We can only presume that it was with some surprise that they found themselves seated at the 'women's only' table in the VFL VIP room at the Richmond- Collingwood game on Saturday at Waverley.
The pair shared a meal and chat with Marjorie Aylett, the wife of the VFL president, Allen Aylett, and Joan Hamilton, the wife of the VFL general manager, Jack Hamilton. Meanwhile, the Governor--
Who, after all, is only Lady Murray's husband-
Rear Admiral Sir Brian Murray, dined with the men.

Mr Hamilton tells us that after the official luncheon, the women were free to mingle. 'At afternoon tea, they could sit with their husbands,' he says. 'They could sit with anyone they liked during the game'.

That is a classic case of discrimination, one which really we do not need in Australia in this day and age. After all, we are well into the twentieth century ; women are equal human beings. It has been said many times that women are on the move. I give a warning now to clubs that practise blatant discrimination that they may find that women are on the move outside their very doors.

It is interesting to note what has developed in the leagues clubs of New South Wales since the anti-discrimination legislation was passed by the State Government. I understand that female members of leagues clubs which previously displayed such signs as 'associate members'-who of course were always the female members-'are not permitted to use the sauna; associate members are not permitted to use the billiard rooms', are now finding that instead of being limited to associate membership they are quite entitled to full membership. The clubs are now blatantly advertising that their facilities are available to them.

Perhaps we have to look now to the Victorian State Government and other governments to introduce as rapidly as possible similar anti-discriminatory legislation as the New South Wales Government has done. I cannot, for instance, see it happening in my State of Western Australia at the moment where we have a rather ludicrous situation with the State conservative government saying: 'No, we will not have legal casinos but we will allow at least five illegal casinos to operate in which women are not welcome'. They may well look out for me on their doorstep one of these nights. I might pay them a visit and dare them to not let me in.

The final matter which I wish to raise concerns a question which was asked by Senator Bjelke-Petersen during Question Time today which related to the funding of the performing arts. I was not aware at the time that I put my name down with my party Whip to speak in this adjournment debate-as a matter of interest I did this yesterday-that a question on this subject would be asked. But it now gives me an opportunity to point out to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who represents the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) that there is a crisis in all States in regard to the funding of particularly the performing arts. In Western Australia we are looking at a situation where it is quite possible that at least an entire generation of Western Australian people will be deprived of access to the performing arts. I wish to read quickly into the Hansard record a letter from the Western Australian Opera Company Inc. dated 8 April 1982 and headed 'Federal Funds Withdrawn-Opera Against the Wall'. It states:

On the 11th February, 1982, the Australia Council advised that basic grants, paid to State Opera Companies since 1967, would cease after 1982. This is the realisation of a threat made by the Music Board of the Australia Council in 1977 and is only the 'thin' edge of the wedge.

Yet another blow to Western Australia, in particular, as it receives no benefit from the Australian Opera although its taxpayers and the State Government support the National Company both indirectly and directly-through the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust. The Australian Opera currently receives 80% of the Australia Council Music Board's funds.

The funding of our company has been inequitable as the enclosed table of grants made to the State companies since 1975 shows and the latest cut decreases our grant funds, on current values, by 17%. We now have to consider whether, in fact , we can continue providing W.A. with Opera and Music Theatre of the highest standards at all.

Standards of our productions have been acclaimed by both the public and critics and a steadily growing audience is proof of our acceptance in the community. During 1981 we played to over 33,000 patrons and audiences are increasing as a consequence of aggressive marketing.

Apart from the proven public need for our activity, it is not often realised that our industry provides considerable employment during the year. In 1981 we paid $443,000 in salaries to singing artists, musicians, technicians and support personnel. The employment of such people resulted in the Federal Government receiving over $50,000 in income tax, deducted at source, and the State Government receiving over $19,000 in payroll tax.

As a consequence of the Federal agency (Australia Council) abdicating its responsibility to Western Australia, jobs for artists, musicians, technicians and administrative support personnel will be lost, not to mention the loss of income and payroll tax to Federal and State Governments, sales tax on all items purchased for set construction and costume making and spin offs to other local industries.
Indeed, taxes paid to the Federal Government far exceed grants received, so for what purpose does the Australia Council make the decision to eliminate grants to state based opera companies?
We need your help to have Federal funding through the Australia Council re- instated.

May we therefore look forward to you making representation on our behalf to the Federal Minister representing the Arts, the Honourable Ian B. C. Wilson, Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment, to have funding restored to this company on the basis of it being a special case due to its isolation and, as a consequence of that isolation, the lack of service from the Australian Opera, which regularly visits the other States.

The letter is signed by Mr V. A. Warrener, General Manager of the Western Australia Opera Company. I am well aware of the response that the Minister gave Senator Bjelke-Peterson this morning. I wish to make a number of points. Firstly , if we are to have national bodies, then they have to be truly national. In the case of Western Australia the last time that that State had a visit from the Australian Opera Company was in 1973 when there were in all five performances of The Marriage of Figaro in Perth. I know that difficulties are being experienced by all sections of the performing arts in this country. But I strongly put the case that it is the exposure perhaps to all forms of culture through creative performing arts that is an absolute essential in the backgrounding of the people of the future, the development of people, particularly young people.

I think it is also important to relate matters that have taken place in other States and that have been recorded. For instance, in South Australia the Liberal Government has pulled back on its grants to the Australian Opera company, which means that the national company which had only two performing weeks in that State during 1981 will not have any during the 1982 financial year. In 1981 there were 28 performing weeks in New South Wales and there will be 30 in 1982. In the Australian Capital Territory in 1981 there were one and a half performing weeks and in this current financial year the figure will be the same. In Queensland there were two performing weeks in 1981 and that State will have one and a half weeks this year. Melbourne had 12 in 1981 and it will have nine this year.

I have already been advised that if things continue in this manner it may be necessary to confine the activities of the Australian Opera company to New South Wales and Victoria. I am conscious of the fact that when the South Australian Government decided to pull back on its grant to the Australian Opera company serious consideration was given to taking the Australian Opera company to Western Australia. But if one looks at the cost of transporting a company such as the Australian Opera company around the country one realises that suggestion is completely impractical. In fact, a three week 13-performance tour in that State-that is allowing for the transportation of goods, the material, the sets, the costumes and the people and provided that every single seat for every performance were sold-there would still be a deficit of $175,000. I do not anticipate that a national organisatoin or any organisation could stand a deficit of that nature. But the point that I am making is that if the people of Western Australia do not get visits by the naional body, at least they are entitled to be assured of adequate funding so that the Western Australian Opera company can continue.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen raised in this place this morning the problems of the people she represents in the State of Queensland. I press a valid point that I think is important. Western Australia very seldom enjoys the advantages that are available to those States on the eastern seaboard of Australia-the regular visits of overseas artists. Western Australia gets very few such visits and therefore it has to depend to a large extent for its cultural development on organisations such as the Western Australian Opera company.

I reiterate the point I made earlier. If we are to have a national body then it has to be truly national. The Federal Government has to accept a responsibility for adequate funding to ensure that those cultural, recreational activities that are available so readily in New South Wales and Victoria are available to all Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to be brief. I think it is important to raise this week, as it is the first opportunity I have had to do so , the concern the Australian Democrats feel in relation to the Aboriginal land rights issue in my State of Queensland. I refer to the Bill which has passed the Queensland Parliament entitled 'A Bill to Amend the Land Act 1962-1981 in certain particulars and to amend the Forestry Act 1959-1979 in a certain particular, and for other purposes', the short title of which is the Land Act ( Aboriginal and Islander Land Grants Amendments Act) 1982. The foreshadowing of the passage of this Act has been the subject of discussion in this chamber for quite some time and indeed it is the subject of a Bill which has passed this chamber and has gone to the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise a number of points, and will do so very briefly because of the late hour, about what we find still objectionable about the provisions in the Queensland Act. First of all, the Minister for Water Resources and Aboriginal and Island Affairs has indicated that the Bill and the deeds of trust in the Bill were referred to community reserves and, to quote the Minister, 'some Aboriginal reserves will remain'. If one reads his second reading speech, one certainly gains the impression that the country reserves in Queensland will not be included. There are at least 28 of these country reserves which, on a conservative estimate, may have upwards of 30 per cent of the Queensland Aboriginal and Islander community living on them. So the actual lands under consideration are still of enormous concern to us. Secondly, the Bill enables the Governor-in-Council to exclude from the grant or to reserve any land for public purpose such an access road, a camping place, pasturage reserves, ports and quarries, hospitals, police stations, et cetera. I refer honourable senators to clauses 5 and 334D.

Thirdly, the Governor-in-Council may, at any time, rescind, amend, alter, vary, or modify any grant. This is an absolute power under section 334 and is not in any way controlled by Parliament. Fourthly, any by-laws relating to the use of the land must have the approval of the Governor-in-Council. That is provided for under section 339. Fifthly, the consent of the Minister is needed in some cases mainly for the occupation of certain portions of land granted for periods exceeding one month. Sixthly, in addition to the power to rescind under section 334, there is, under section 353, a further power which empowers the Governor-in -Council to revoke totally a grant, subject to disallowance by the Parliament. Here I draw the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to a statement that he made that this may be normal in Queensland. I refer him to the fact that one of the Acts which is amended is the Forestry Act 1959-79. I refer him specifically to the following sections: Section 26 on the revocation of the declaration of a State forest is done in a totally different fashion; section 28 dealing with the revocation of timber reserves is done in a totally different fashion; section 31 dealing with the revocation of the declaration of a national park is done, again, in a totally different fashion. I draw the Minister's attention to the fashion in which they are done. I ask him to compare those situations with this situation. I think he will then see where he may have been misled by his own advisers. I read section 26 (2) (2) as an example:

Any such proposal has been laid before the Legislative Assembly that the Governor-in-Council on a resolution whereof, not less than 14 days notice having been given passed by the Legislative Assembly, that such proposal be carried out .

In other words, the point that is made here is that the Governor-in-Council may have cause to lay on the table of the Legislative Assembly a proposal for such revocation but that the Legislative Assembly must, by deliberative vote, carry out that revocation, not as is contained in the Act. The Minister said: 'That may be normal in Queensland'. It is not normal in Queensland. I have quoted from the very Act which is amended in this Act which gives power.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the Acts, Senator.
—There are two Acts, the Land Act and the Forestry Act.
—I said it was normal for the Land Act.
—You did not say the Land Act, Senator.
—You are quibbling.

—Senator Baume said that this may be normal practice in Queensland; and that is not a quibble. It is not normal practice in Queensland. I am quoting from one of the very Acts which were amended in that Act.
—You are not quoting from the other one.

—Senator Baume may quote from the other one, if he likes. It is not a quibble. It is indeed in one of the Acts which were amended. In addition to the power to rescind there is this additional power under section 353. The method that is engaged in-the Minister may like to investigate this; his knowledge of the legislative Assembly's procedures seems to be vast-is this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-in-Council may totally revoke a deed of grant at any time.

This deed of revocation takes effect on the day of its publication. It must then be laid on the table in Parliament within 14 days from publication, if Parliament is sitting, or within 14 days of commencement if it is not.

In the latter case this may take many months. In any case-the Minister may care to check this out-failure to table an order made in accordance with this Bill would not nullify that order. There are many cases currently on record in the Legislative Assembly where that has occurred. If the order is tabled the Parliamentary Committee on Subordinate Legislation in the Legislative Assembly would, of course, as our committees do, scrutinise such proposals for possible disallowance. Alternatively a member of parliament may move, as in this chamber, for disallowance. The motion of disallowance must be moved within 18 days. This may be difficult since the Committee is extremely busy, as is our committee. The latest figures that I could find-it is somewhat difficult to find material in terms of the Legislative Assembly-show that in the last couple of days of its 1979 Budget session there were 209 instruments to which that Committee had to pay attention. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the legislative methodologies of the Queensland Parliament are such that far more legislation is done by way of regulation in that State than probably any State in Australia and certainly by this chamber. Leases may be granted to individuals, groups or families, but in such cases they are subject to the approval of the Minister for Lands who may require a council to charge the highest rent obtainable. I have no reason to draw the Minister's attention to that. He would know what it would mean if the Minister for Lands wanted to use it. That is dealt with in section 344B.

A proposed amendment to section 45 of the Forestry Act ensures that reserve councils may not use forestry or quarry products. The Governor-in-Council may at his absolute discretion give permission to anyone to enter land held under the provisions of the Bill. There are no provisions for compensation under the Mining Act similar to the ones enjoyed by occupiers of private land or Crown land in the State of Queensland. Finally, a reserve council may need the approval of the Governor-in-Council to carry its own prospecting. No provision has been made to guarantee traditional hunting, foraging and fishing rights. I draw the Minister's attention to a section of the speech that he made. He pointed to four principles for securing tenure. They were:

The integrity of the present boundaries be maintained; secure tenure for occupants and the preservation of their rights to use the land; local communities to play a significant role in the management of the reserves; full consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people before any decisions are made.
Avoiding the confusing term 'land rights', the Minister said:

The essential element is security of land tenure. Of course, there is a whole variety of ways in which that can be achieved and in which we should approach the matter. At this moment the reserves in Queensland are not secure. The Aboriginals and the Islanders do not have secure tenure today. They can be de- gazetted overnight. They were de-gazetted overnight a couple of years ago in one notorious example.

The Australian Democrats and I would contend that the legislation passed by the Queensland Parliament does not change that situation. Until the Commonwealth Government uses its power-the power granted to it by the people of Australia- then that will remain the situation in Queensland. The Aboriginal and Island peoples will not have secure title to their rightful land. This Parliament must continue its action to secure for those peoples their legitimate and longed for rights.
Thursday, 22 April 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — Several honourable senators have taken part in the adjournment debate tonight. It has taken 70 minutes and it may not be possible to respond to each of them in less than a few minutes. I apologise if honourable senators want to get away. In responding to Senator Macklin first, I make a point that some people have failed to comprehend. The Commonwealth's view of the package which applies in Queensland is that it consists of three elements. It consists of the statement by the Queensland Government on 1 March, the legislation which the Queensland Government has passed-I understand there is more legislation to come to secure the other parts of the arrangement to do with management-and, thirdly, a guarantee which was given by the Commonwealth to pick up some of the uncertainties to which Senator Macklin and others have referred and which were contained in some of the analyses of the Act.

People have taken a worst case view. They have asked what would happen if the worst possible case were applied. We think it very unlikely that the Queensland Government will move away from its stated intentions as to how it will operate these matters of land tenure. In the event that this happens the Commonwealth has given an unequivocal guarantee that it will stand behind the stated intent of the Queensland Government to provide security of tenure and integrity of the reserve land and that if there are actions which transgress those principles, that is the principles set down by Queensland, or which indicate an unreasonable use of the discretions in the legislation, which may be the discretions to which Senator Macklin referred, the Commonwealth will act accordingly. I make it quite clear that if Queensland, in a very unlikely situation, were to follow a course in which an instrument was not tabled in the Parliament or if action were to be taken when the Parliament was not able to meet these would be matters which the Commonwealth would want to examine. Certainly, any failure to table a document would require the Commonwealth guarantee to be exercised.

I have spoken on this matter a number of times. I thank Senator Macklin for the view of the Australian Democrats. The Queensland Government has progressed miles from where it was a year ago. It has moved its position publicly and legislatively. The reserve communities will now have title to their reserves. Perpetual title will be held directly by the communities. That title will be secure to the extent that parliamentary review would be necessary in any unlikely event of revocation. Senator Macklin is quite correct that there are other reserves, the status of which have still to be determined. I think it is also fair that the conditions to apply on particular deeds of grant will be the subject of negotiations one by one. The Commonwealth guarantee that has been given should be taken very seriously.

Senator Coleman raised several matters. I will deal with them in reverse order as it happens to be convenient. She referred to the performing arts. I understand the point she made in relation to the isolation of Western Australia, certainly in the context of what she called cultural isolation. She referred to the high costs of moving national companies to Western Australia to perform and the problems which have occurred because the State opera company of Western Australia is no longer able to fill that gap. The questions which she asked and suggestions which she made will have to be resolved in a Budget context. They are matters which the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) will have to take into account in a Budget context. I will pass on to him, as I said I would do for Senator Bjelke-Petersen this morning, that point. I raise one query with Senator Coleman. To the extent that the Australia Council is an autonomous operation I would be reluctant to follow up the suggestion that there should be ministerial direction to the Council in relation to how it should allocate its programming and resources. I think the Australia Council would want to read what the honourable senator said but it might be inappropriate for it to be given instructions in this or in other such matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume that there would be no reason why the Minister should not ensure that the Australia Council does read what has been said.

—I intended to indicate that. I am grateful for the interjection. In passing Senator Coleman's comments on to the Minister I would want to make sure that Dr Pascoe received the comments and that he paid attention to them.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter related to the Melbourne Cricket Club-I take it that that is the club related to the Melbourne Cricket Ground-and questions of equal opportunity which arise there. The 20-year wait does not worry me. It applies all over the State. I understand Senator Coleman's point. I hope that she will encourage the young lady, as quite a separate matter, to become a member of the East Torrens District Cricket Club. I do not know whether Senator Coleman is a member of that club. I am certainly a member. It is a club in Adelaide and it functions as a non-smoking cricket club. I have been seeking parliamentary members to become members of that club because it has decided to operate independently of the money available from the South Australian Cricket Association on the basis that it will not take sponsorship from certain sources. Having said that, the matters which have been raised-

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you must admit that it would be difficult for a 10- year-old child to envisage membership of a club in South Australia. She is an ardent supporter of the game. I would anticipate that a Melbourne club, a Victorian club, will offer her membership.

—I am offering Senator Coleman membership of the East Torrens District Cricket Club, and I would be happy to process her very nominal contribution to that club. The question of unequal opportunity is a serious matter and I take on board the point she makes. We are seeing the barriers crashing down; I think it will be a matter of time. Senator Coleman made another point about the rather quaint custom of separating wives and husbands at social functions. I concur completely with her. This is not an experience which many couples seek. Indeed, there are some functions which I attend in Sydney which my wife now no longer attends because we are not willing to dine separately.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coleman raised a third matter-she raised it first-which concerned a Dr J. Stephenson and his experience with Customs. I heard the story unfold and I accept the facts as set out. We can certainly make them known to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Brown. I am sure he will want to know the events. It was a matter of front counter attitudes and practice but it sounds as though some quite major administrative error or mixup occurred in this matter. I will not cover the ground again except to say that it seems appropirate, as the honourable senator requested, that this be passed to the Minister for early response to see why it was that the academic gown and goods were held up at Mascot, why the wrong information was sent back to West Virginia, why there was difficulty in communication between the west and east coast and why the whole series of events occurred.

That brings me to the points raised by Senator Bonner in his contribution. He raised a number of matters, all of them quite serious, and I would like to advert to those. I will start with the question of trachoma and the trachoma program. The honourable senator was not really concerned with the trachoma program itself but asked about its reception in Queensland and about certain bars which seem to have been raised about the participation in the program. I make it clear that there is a difference between programs through the Department of Aboriginal Affairs which are grants-in-aid programs and State grants programs . We make grants-in-aid programs to organisations. I have established as a matter of principle that I do not accept and will not accept a State veto on grants-in-aid programs by the Commonwealth to an organisation. That is a matter between the Commonwealth and an organisation. I think honourable senators would want it that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was vetoed once before by the Premier despite the fact that it was funded by the Commonwealth.

—I think the point may be that if a State grant element is needed there is a need to co-operate with the State. While it is a grant-in-aid to an organisation, there is no need to involve the State. Of course, it is desirable always to work in co-operation with our State colleagues, but I remind honourable senators that last year in Western Australia I had occasion to ensure that certain medical services were funded. I have done the same in Queensland. The Wu Chopperen service in Cairns has been funded now. Because it is a grant-in -aid fund, it is a decision for me. Whilst I seek the advice of State colleagues , it is not something on which I require concurrence or on which I will accept a veto. Clearly, I would try to work, and I think any honourable senator would try to work, by co-operation in these matters. Having said that, Senator Bonner was concerned that there was, apparently, a political test to be put on people participating in the program. Let me answer him in this way: Someone's political affiliations are irrelevant. When one is carrying out a professional function- for example, during the time that I as a doctor am giving medical advice-one should be giving professional advice in that field, not political advice. I think we all would agree with that. If Senator Peter Rae is giving legal advice he should not be combining that with giving political advice. I think that is a perfectly simple proposition with which we all can agree.
—It depends on who is interpreting what a person is doing. We have a person who says that if a person involved in this scheme happens to be a member of a political party the scheme will not go ahead.

—I understand what Senator Bonner said and I have said that, to the extent that funds may be grant-in-aid funds, no State has a capacity to veto its grant. It is as simple as that. I am just saying that as a matter of good practice for any one of us when we are carrying out the professional part of our activities we must be apolitical and that what we do after hours is our own business and no one else's business. I think that is a problem. I must say that-
—We already have an example of the scheme being stopped.

—Yes. I am not sure whether it was funded through the State. I am making the point that if it is grant-in-aid funding that situation need not recur because it is not a matter that is subject to a State veto. That is the point I am trying to make.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to talk about another couple of matters raised by Senator Bonner. First of all, I refer to the Aboriginal Development Commission funding. Let me give the exact figure for this year. The Aboriginal Development Commission received $ 48m. That is the figure that has been mentioned, and it is accurate. Of that sum $3.4m was set aside for land purchases. I understand that during this year the Aboriginal Development Commission has spent about $370,000 in Queensland for small parcels of land or for improvements on land which was taken over. Some issues are continuing on the question of land purchases. Some of them involve the possibility of further negotiations between the ADC and Queensland. Until those possibilities are exhausted, I do not think it would help things very much for me to go over the matters raised by Senator Bonner, except to say that I note them, I am aware of them and I hope they can be resolved.

The only other matter I wish to mention is the concern Senator Bonner expressed about people training in Libya. I agree with Senator Bonner; I know of no evidence to support the assertions that Aboriginals are training in Libya. That whole story is quite fanciful. I must say that those kinds of statements will occur; people will say these kinds of things from time to time. It may be that a Premier receives from one source or another information that may eventually prove to be false. But I say to honourable senators that there are elements within Australia today, both in the Aboriginal and the non-Aboriginal communities, who are not proceeding in the way which Senator Bonner set down as the desirable way to proceed. I am as concerned--

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are a tiny minority.

—I wish to say a little bit about this tiny minority because they are a concern when they are in the non-Aboriginal community. They are also a concern when they are in the Aboriginal community. I want to set on record that at a conference at the University of New South Wales last October, dealing with land tenure, I had the doubtful pleasure of listening to Mr Gary Foley speaking. I mention this matter in this context because, as I recall what he said, first of all he accused me of having Australian Security Intelligence Organisation people present, which was rather fanciful. He identified one of my officers as an ASIO person, which is fairly fanciful. He said that he was about to go overseas and that we could guess where. However, he did make the point, when talking about the needs of Aboriginal people, that if the matter could not be resolved in Australia they would be perfectly justified in seeking support from friendly Middle Eastern powers. I believe that we can resolve our problems here, within the framework of law and our political structures.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that at both Federal and State levels we have a will. We have an emerging record of enormous progress over 10 years. Be it accusations from one side that people are being trained in Libya when there is no evidence that that is so or statements from the other side that people are going to seek the help of friendly Middle Eastern powers, all that can do is make a situation more difficult. I do not believe either of those courses is one which honourable senators here would endorse or promote.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12.26 a.m. (Thursday)

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have recent moves by the Government of Mr Mugabe turned the white people of Zimbabwe into economic prisoners?
(2) If whites do leave Zimbabwe from now on, will the Australian Government request the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to recognise them as refugees from political persecution?
(3) Has the Zimbabwe Government in a recent budget imposed severe economic restrictions on white citizens?
(4) Did the Zimbabwe Government recently take over 40 private schools for blacks and whites so that they could be further integrated?
(5) Has the Zimbabwe Government acted to end the availability of dual passports ?
(6) Has the Zimbabwe Government raised special North Korean-trained armoured brigades of 5,000 crack troops to act as an internal police force without normal police constraints?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is incorrect to say that moves taken by the Zimbabwe Government have turned the white people of Zimbabwe into economic prisoners. Zimbabwe has limits on the amount of foreign exchange that people wishing to leave the country may take with them. It should be noted that these limits were determined in April 1979, before the Mugabe Government came into office. Such controls are imposed by a number of Governments, not only that of Zimbabwe, and it is a matter for each country to decide, according to its economic circumstances, the appropriate level of foreign exchange those departing may take. I understand that in fact the present controls represent a more flexible arrangement than previous foreign exchange regulations. The limits set by the Zimbabwe Government apply equally to black and white Zimbabweans.

(2) It would not be appropriate for Australia to approach the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, as there are no grounds for believing white citizens wishing to leave Zimbabwe are doing so as refugees from political persecution. Since independence, the Zimbabwe Government has followed a policy of reconciliation after a long and bitter war. The importance given by Mr Mugabe 's Government to co-operation and harmony between the different peoples of Zimbabwe has also received recognition from leading white Zimbabweans. A number of white MPs, formerly members of the white Republican Front Party, recently announced their intention to sit in Parliament as independents in order to help build an atmosphere of trust and confidence, and so as to be able to work more closely with Prime Minister Mugabe.

(3) No. The 1981/82 Budget brought down on 31 July 1981 did not single out white citizens for the imposition of severe economic restrictions. Economic measures introduced by the Zimbabwe Government in the Budget-including increases in sales tax, duty on petrol, customs surtax and estate duty-as well as a reduction in the holiday allowance, i.e. foreign exchange that may be taken abroad for vacation purposes, apply to all citizens of Zimbabwe.

(4) While I have no information to confirm or deny this particular report, I am aware that it is Zimbabwe Government policy to remove segregation along racial lines in all schools. On independence the Zimbabwe Government inherited a dual system of education catering on the one hand for the whites, coloured and Asians , and on the other for the blacks. The Government has merged these two education divisions and is according priority to the lengthy process of developing unified curricula.

(5) Yes. In December last year Zimbabwean authorities announced that Rhodesia passports and Zimbabwe/Rhodesia passports would not be valid after 20 January 1982 and that Zimbabwean citizens travelling outside their country must be in possession of a Zimbabwe passport.

(6) The future role of the North Korean-trained Brigade of the Zimbabwe National Army is not entirely clear, but at this stage it seems an exaggeration to say it will act as an internal police force without normal police restraints. There are five Brigades in the Zimbabwe National Army and one of these is currently being trained by North Korean advisers under an agreement due to expire in May this year. Early reports on the intended role of the Fifth Brigade quoted Mr Mugabe as saying it would be a special unit to be sent to trouble spots in Zimbabwe. Subsequent reports however, suggested that the Brigade was likely to remain a normal part of the Zimbabwe National Army, to be used within Zimbabwe's borders for defensive purposes only. Mr Mugabe said in answer to a question in Parliament on 15 September 1981 that the main reason North Korean military instructors were in Zimbabwe was to train Zimbabwean troops in the use of arms provided by North Korea.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to the article in the Taxpayer of 12 September 1981 stating that more time should be allowed for the payment of sales tax.
(2) Has the Treasurer given consideration to this request; if so, what decision has been reached.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Since its enactment in 1930, the sales tax has provided that, generally, sales tax is to be paid no later than 21 days after the close of the month in which the taxable transactions occurs. The question of extending this time has been considered on many occasions by Governments and by independent taxation review committees since 1930. It has always been recognised that it is a matter of balancing the varying credit terms of taxpayers (including many who deal on a cash basis) with the needs of the revenue. It would not be administratively feasible to have one due date for taxpayers who deal on a cash basis and another for those who deal on credit terms. It also needs to be borne in mind that, if the proposal contained in the article referred to in the honourable senator's question were implemented, there would be a cost to the revenue of about $250m in the year in which the charge was made.

While the proposals to amend the machinery and liability provisions of the sales tax law announced by me on 20 August 1981 do not specifically cover the matter raised by the honourable senator, the Government will, in light of representations it has received, consider the time for payment question in the context of its review of the other changes to the machinery and liability provisions of the law.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, in 1978, substantiate that some of the methods for obtaining convictions of alleged Irish Republican Army members in Northern Ireland were done by extremely brutal measures.

(2) Has Amnesty International stated in a report that maltreatment of suspected terrorists by the Royal Ulster Constabulary has taken place with sufficient frequency to warrant the establishment of a public inquiry to investigate it. If so, has the Australian Government indicated its support for such an inquiry. If not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following an application by the Government of the Republic of Ireland to the European Commission on Human Rights in December 1974, the European Court of Human Rights found in a judgment handed down in January 1978 that the combined use of certain interrogation techniques by the British Government in Northern Ireland constituted inhuman and degrading treatment but did not amount to torture. The British Government did not contest the finding but noted that the practices in question had been voluntarily and publicly abandoned in 1972 with substantial compensation being paid to those involved.

(2) Yes. In the light of recommendations of the Amnesty International Report of June 1978, an independent Committee of Inquiry, chaired by Judge H. G. Bennett, was established the same month to consider police interrogation practices and procedures in Northern Ireland. The British Government has stated that virtually all the 66 major conclusions and recommendations of this Committee's report have been accepted and put into effect.

The Australian Government did not comment either upon the Amnesty International report or on the report of the Committee of Inquiry. The Government recognised both the British Government's prompt remedial action and the fact that the problems of Northern Ireland are essentially a domestic matter for the British Government and local people to resolve.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

(3) What is the future of the Budd cars which were parked outside the locomotive shed at Port Augusta and not used since the discontinuation of the Whyalla/Port Augusta passenger service;
(4) Can these cars be upgraded so as to be able to provide a reliable and efficient service between Port Pirie and Adelaide; if so, what is the estimated cost;
(5) Is it intended to operate a passenger service between Adelaide/Whyalla with the completion of the standard gauge link.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(2) The word 'returned' in part 2 has been interpreted as 'retained' and the question answered accordingly. Yes. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a British Commission set up in 1972 under the Chairmanship of Lord Diplock and that part of the terms of reference were to find ways to determine the method of arrest and imprisonment of IRA members.

(2) Did the Commission result in a 'conveyor belt' system of justice and recommend that as long as the 'emergency' lasted certain offences such as possession of arms and explosive charges should be known as 'scheduled offences' .

(3) Are those charged with 'scheduled offences' denied trial by jury and are alleged offenders detained for questioning without access to relatives or legal advisors and are determined guilty of a further offence if they refuse to answer questions.
(4) Has the Government expressed its concern to the British over these alleged infringements of human rights. If not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The terms of reference required the Commission, chaired by Lord Diplock, to consider 'what arrangements for the administration of justice in Northern Ireland could be made in order to deal more effectively with terrorist organisations by bringing to book, otherwise than by internment by the Executive , individuals involved in terrorist activities, particularly those who plan and direct, but not necessarily take part in, terrorist acts, and to make recommendations'.

(2) The Diplock Commission concluded that because of experience with the intimidation of jurors, trial by jury was not practicable in certain classes of offence in Northern Ireland, designated as 'scheduled offences'.

(3) Trials of those accused of such offences are conducted in open court before four judges without a jury, with the prosecution having the onus to provide guilt beyond reasonable doubt. The accused has the right to take legal advice, to be represented by a lawyer and has full rights of appeal. Those accused of ' schedule offences' can however be detained up to forty-eight hours without being charged or having access to legal representation.

I am not aware of any offence being constituted merely by failure to respond to questions. I am also advised that these provisions are subject to regular public scrutiny through twice-yearly House of Commons debates and to regular mandatory renewal by Parliament.

(4) The Australian Government has made known its concern about the complex and tragic situation in Northern Ireland. The Government believes, however, that the problems in that troubled region are essentially a domestic matter for the local people and the British Government to resolve. For its part, the British Government has publicly acknowledged that measures to prevent terrorism in Northern Ireland have regrettably made inroads into civil liberties. At the same time, the British Government has stressed the temporary nature of these measures and the regular Parliamentary review procedures which apply to them. I reiterate the Australian Government's hope for an early end to the troubles and a return to normal life in Northern Ireland, including of course the full restoration of the civil liberties of its inhabitants.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister for Industrial Relations finally determined to accept Senator Mulvihill's earlier request to utilise the ethnic press to list the names of persons entitled to monies gained by the Industrial Relations Bureau from employers who breached award payments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Section 124 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act provides for an employer to pay to the Commonwealth, monies due to an employee under an order or award of the Commission, in circumstances where the employee has left the employment and the employer is unable to make payment because the whereabouts of the employee is unknown to him.

I am informed that prior to the Industrial Relations Bureau assuming responsibility for the trust accounts and the transfer of the monies held therein into Consolidated Revenue it had not been the practice to give publicity to the individual amounts held in trust or to the names of the employee or the employer.

It is the responsibility of the Director of the Bureau to decide the manner in which further publicity can be given to the monies held in trust. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has Air Queensland been appointed general sales agent for Qantas in North Queensland, if so:
(a) When was the appointment made;
(b) Does Qantas have any other general sales agents in Australia;
(c) What is the commission paid by Qantas to Air Queensland;
(d) How much has Air Queensland received in commission since becoming general sales agent for Qantas;
(e) What are the conditions required of general sales agents;
(f) Has Air Queensland met these conditions;
(g) Is it normal for an airline company with its own offices in Queensland to appoint a general sales agent; and
(h) Why is there any need for Qantas to have a general sales agent in North Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Qantas has advised that Air Queensland, previously known as Bush Pilots Airways is the general sales agent for Qantas in respect of passenger sales in the North Queensland area. Qantas has further advised in relation to the particular questions:
(a) the appointment was made on 1 April 1978.
(b) Yes. Airlines of New South Wales and East West Airlines in rural New South Wales and Westjet Consolidated Air Service Pty Ltd in north western Western Australia.

(c) In accordance with approved IATA Resolutions incorporated in Qantas' tariff of charges, nine per cent commission is paid on sales of Qantas services made in an Air Queensland office. In addition, three per cent commission is paid to Air Queensland on all sales of Qantas services made in the general sales agent territory. (e) The required services and sales functions to be supplied by a general sales agent are those set down in International Air Transport Association Resolution 876 and include soliciting and promoting traffic for the principal; providing and maintaining an office for transacting business on behalf of the principal servicing and supervising appointed agents of the principal in the general sales agent territory; distributing and displaying the principal's advertising and promotional material in the area.

(f) Qantas' travelled revenue results from the general sales agent area were 22 .9 per cent higher during January 1982, and 36.3 per cent higher during the period April 1981 to January 1982 than in corresponding periods in the previous year. For the same periods direct sales by Air Queensland increased 32.6 per cent and 55.1 per cent respectively over the previous year's levels. Qantas therefore believe the conditions have been met.

(g) Yes. Several foreign airlines with their own sales offices in Queensland have Ansett and TAA under appointment as general sales agents in the State. The same practice occurs in other States of Australia as well as in other countries, not only with Qantas but also with other airlines.

(h) It is the Company's assessment that at the time of Air Queensland's appointment, Qantas' market share and exploitation of potential travel markets in the area were inadequate and the level of revenues earned through IATA agents in the area was unsatisfactory. The estimated cost of mounting an effective sales coverage to reverse the trend involved considerable cost increases particularly in staff because of the vast distances between centres in North Queensland and the limited accessibility of the area. Consideration of the general sales agent option showed this to be a more cost-effective arrangement. Air Queensland, with its strong route structure, own route agency network, and growing status and dominance in Queensland was ideally placed to take on the general sales agent role.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have children's car seats and infants' restraining harnesses for use in motor vehicles been exempted from sales tax.

(2) Are seat belts and other safety devices for the use of adults in automobiles to remain subject to sales tax; if so, why are seat belts taxed when they have been proven over the past decade to be outstandingly effective in reducing the number of fatalities and serious injuries in road accidents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Seat belts for adults are required parts for motor cars before registration of a vehicle will be approved in accordance with the Australian design rules.
Seat belts are therefore standard equipment of motor cars, as are brakes, windscreen wipers, lights and other safety equipment.
There is therefore no longer a case for exemption of seat belts to encourage voluntary fitting by motor car owners.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Department of Transport now ceased its practice of approving operational manuals for aircraft operations; if so, when did the Department cease to approve these manuals, and why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes; the requirement for operations manuals to be approved by the Secretary to the Department of Transport was deleted from Air Navigation Regulation 212 in 1971. The reason why the need for approval was deleted was because the bulk of the information required by Regulation 212 to be included in an operations manual must be devised by the operator and does not need to be specifically approved by the Department. Notwithstanding the amendment, provision was retained under Regulation 212 for the Secretary, or his delegate, to direct the inclusion, revision or variation of any information contained in the manual. This enables the Department to ensure that accurate and essential operational information is contained in any manual.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the names of the organisations, funds and institutions which attract tax deductibility for gifts made to them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act lists the particular bodies and classes of bodies in respect of which gifts may be allowed as deductions for income tax purposes. Over the years very many bodies have been accepted as falling within the classes of bodies specified in the section, e.g. public benevolent institutions (section 78 (1) (a) (ii)). The numbers of eligible bodies would run into thousands and it would not be practicable to list them all here. If the honourable senator is interested in a particular body, I can arrange for its status to be advised to him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What basis does the Government use to index compensation payments under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971.
(2) On what dates are the payments indexed.
(3) What previous months do the six monthly indexation involve, for calculation purposes.
(4) What is the percentage indexation of the first six months, and when will it date from.
(5) When will the increases be received.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) Compensation benefits payable under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 will be adjusted each 1 May and 1 November ( commencing on 1 May 1982) to reflect the percentage movement in the weighted average weekly wage rate under Federal awards (Australian Bureau of Statistics publication, Series 6312 Table 8) during the preceding six month period 1 July to 31 December, or 1 January to 30 June.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 17 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Government withdraw its direction that some totally and permanently incapacitated and Service pensioners shall lose a telephone rental concession they have enjoyed for many years if some person other than a pensioner or a low income person also resides in the same dwelling.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Provision for the grant of a telephone rental concession is made in the Telecommunications Act 1975. The conditions under which a pensioner is eligible for the concession are defined in Schedule 3 of the by-laws made in accordance with section 111 of that Act. For certain classes of pensioners one of these conditions relates to the domestic circumstances of the pensioner: that is, the separate income of each person living with the pensioner (other than eligible persons) should not be greater than $99.70 a week.

The exercise referred to by the honourable senator is a review of all persons receiving the concession. The eligibility criteria have not been changed. What the honourable senator apparently is suggesting would represent a change to the eligibility criteria.

In conjunction with Telecom Australia which has the statutory responsibility, the Department of Veterans' Affairs has been undertaking a review of all repatriation recipients of telephone rental concessions. On the basis of a questionnaire, the review is determining whether recipients continue to be eligible for the concession.

Concurrent with the eligibility review, the opportunity was taken to advise all pensioners who were shown on Departmental records as having basic eligibility but who were not receiving the concession, that they may be eligible. As a result, in the States where reviews have been completed, (New South Wales, Queensland and Tasmania) there were actually increases in the numbers of concessions.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard, page 561) Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning the extension of the multi-cultural television service and the costs of establishing transmitting facilities for Channel 0-28.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Minister is aware of the reference by Mr Krumins, Chairman of the Ethnic Affairs Commission, to the possibility of the introduction of Channel 0-28 Multicultural Television to South Australia.

The Government is yet to consider the extension of the multi-cultural television service beyond Sydney and Melbourne though it is conscious of its success and the demand from other areas for a similar service. However, before the service can be extended, the competing claims of a variety of areas for this new service will have to be evaluated.

The capital cost of establishing UHF transmitting facilities in other Capital cities, including Adelaide, is estimated at between $700,000 and $1m per city. Annual operational costs will vary according to the city. For Adelaide, these are estimated to be approximately $400,000. It should be noted, however, that SBS anticipates that the costs of purchasing programs for screening will rise substantially as the number of Australians able to receive Channel 0-28 outside Sydney and Melbourne increases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard, page 890) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning the departments, commissions and statutory organisations which provide subsidised housing to their employees in the form of lower rental or interest payments or other benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister assisting the Prime Minister has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Department of Administrative Services has advised that as a matter of policy departments and authorities provide housing only where necessary for the efficient discharge of Government functions such as where there is not an acceptable rental market or where an employee is required to live on an establishment. Employees are charged rental for such accommodation. Rents for housing vary, common charges currently being 10 per cent of salary or economic rental (that is recovery of capital costs and recurrent expenses) whichever is the lesser. The bases for these charges are presently under review.

As a matter of policy, employees are not assisted to purchase housing through subsidised interest rates. Where, for example, surplus Government housing stock is sold on terms to employees in occupation, the interest rate charged is that notified by the Department of Finance from time to time. It is linked to the bank overdraft rate and is currently 11.5 per cent per annum.

I understand from the Public Service Board that allowances are provided in some circumstances for excess water rates in arid areas, for high electricity charges in remote districts and operating costs of air-conditioning in tropical areas, in recognition of the extra costs and discomfort faced by employees in certain localities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1982 (Hansard, page 476), Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Could Australia Post give consideration to the issuing in Australia of regional postage stamps, similar to the practice in the United Kingdom, aimed at promoting certain regions of Australia.
