Australia Post's stamp issue policy, which was formulated having regard to public attitudes on postage stamps and philately, provides for the issue of stamps featuring subjects of general interest to a wide section of the Australian community and occasions of outstanding national importance.

Under this policy, Australia Post already recognises certain regions in Australia by issuing, from time to time, stamps which feature States and Territories as well as the natural and historical attributes of parts of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1982 (Hansard, page 471), Senator Colston asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice which included whether the Government has made a contribution towards a subsidy for air transport in western Queensland; if so, what is the level of subsidy, to whom is it paid and does the proposed reduction of air services for Winton and Longreach from 1 May this year accord with the conditions attaching to it.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commonwealth has agreed to match the Queensland Government's subsidy to Trans Australia Airlines for continuation of F27 services to western Queensland . This involves up to $1m per annum contribution by each Government for 1982-83 and 1983-84 with a review at the end of 1982-83. The new arrangements are expected to commence on or about 1 May 1982.

In deciding to provide a subsidy both the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments agreed that a rationalisation of services was necessary to reduce the losses incurred by TAA while at the same time maintaining an appropriate standard of service. Although detailed administrative arrangements have not been finalised between the two Governments and TAA, frequency reductions will occur on both the Townsville/Mt Isa and Brisbane/Central Queensland routes. The only service to be withdrawn is the once weekly Birdsville/Alice Springs sector .

On the Townsville/Mt Isa route, the overall frequency of F27 services will be reduced from seven to four per week with one weekly service reduction to Hughenden, Richmond, Julia Creek and Cloncurry. Reduced direct F27 services between Townsville and Mt Isa are offset by increased direct jet services. TAA' s annual loss on this route can be reduced from $1.3m to $0.8m.

On the Brisbane/Central Queensland route, the new arrangements will include one service from Brisbane to Charleville and one return service to Longreach and Winton. Under these arrangements TAA's annual loss can be reduced from $1. 8m to $1.2m, the total loss requiring a total subsidy of $2m per annum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1982, (Hansard, page 641) Senator Missen asked me, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is addressed to the Attorney-General, relates to the negotiations towards an international convention on torture currently being conducted by a working group of the Commission of Human Rights in Geneva and, in particular, to the principle of universality of jurisdiction with respect to alleged tortures, which Australia recently accepted. I ask: Is it correct that all delegations of the Western group have now accepted the principle of universality of jurisdiction? If so, when will negotiations on the international convention on torture be completed and the convention implemented ? Will the Attorney-General assure the Senate that the Australian Government will lend its full support to the implementation and enforcement of the convention to help ensure that it successfully promotes and protects human rights throughout the world?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information to the answer I gave to the honourable senator's question:

It is correct that all western delegations have now accepted the principle of universal jurisdiction. It is not possible however at this stage to determine when negotiations on the Convention will be completed. There are still a number of important substantive issues to be resolved, especially those relating to the implementation of the Convention. One such issue is the nature of the body to be established to oversee the operation of the Convention. The recently concluded 38th Session of the UN Commission on Human Rights adopted a resolution providing for the open-ended working group considering the draft Convention to meet for the period of one week prior to the 39th Session of the Commission scheduled for February 1983 to enable the group to complete its work on the draft Convention.

The Australian delegation to the 38th Session of the UN Commission on Human Rights played a significant role in the Working Group on Torture making a number of interventions stressing the particular need for effective implementation and enforcement provisions as the key to a successful Convention . The Australian Government will continue to work for the early conclusion of an effective and widely acceptable Convention against torture.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1982 (Hansard, page 639) Senator McLaren asked me a question, without notice, concerning water research and River Murray matters as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) When will the report of a working group of the Australian Water Resources Council on water research be tabled.
(ii) When will a new River Murray Waters Agreement be tabled.

(iii) Has advice been received from the South Australian Minister for Water Resources, Mr Arnold, that he intends to withdraw his objections to applications for further water diversion from the River Darling in New South Wales and his reasons for doing so.
The answers are as follows:
(i) Copies of the report of the AWRC working group on water research have been lodged with the Parliamentary Library.

(ii) The final draft of a new River Murray Waters Agreement has now been referred to the States for their endorsement, but I am not in a position at present to foreshadow when the completed Agreement will be available for tabling in the Parliament.
(iii) The South Australian Minister of Water Resources made a statement in the State Parliament on 2 March on this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1982 (Hansard, page 644) Senator Tate asked me a question without notice concerning oil prices, which reads in part:

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, approximately what percentage of crude oil imports over the last three months has been purchased for Australian distribution at prices below those set by the Saudi Light crude bench-mark?
I undertook to secure this information, together with information on oil purchases from countries other than Saudi Arabia.
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Details of crude oil shipments are reported to my Department but, because of the commercial-in-confidence nature of each company's information, I am not in a position to release details of individual shipments.

In aggregate the returns from the oil companies show that in the three months December 1981 to February 1982 crude oil imports totalled 2.5 million tonnes, of which 49 per cent was Saudi Arabian Light crude oil. The remainder comprised heavier crudes from Saudi Arabia (13 per cent) and crudes from other Middle East countries (11 per cent) and Indonesia (27 per cent).

On the basis of the information supplied by the companies it would appear that practically all of these cargoes were imported at prices close to official government selling prices. The lowest price paid for Saudi Arabian Light crude, for example, was $US33.9748 per barrel, which compares with the official selling price of $US34. Small variations above and below official selling prices can arise because of variations in the specific gravity (*API) of the individual oil cargoes involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1982 (Hansard, page 637): Senator Mason asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Does the Minister agree with the broadly expressed professional view that because of its high profile, relatively slow full speed of 28 knots and relative scarcity of defensive armament, HMS Invincible would be highly vulnerable to guided missile attack in time of war? Is it still the case, as the Minister for Defence informed me on 11 September 1980 in answer to a question on notice, that there is no available defence system in the world against such missiles fired in salvos? Is it a fact that most nations including some of Australia's near neighbours, have the ability to fire missiles in salvos? Is it not a fact that a determined missile attack from the sea or the air would sink Invincible if she were armed to the extent of Government announcements so far? Does the Government propose to equip Invincible with the Phalanx quick-firing gun system which can provide some defence against small numbers of missiles? If so, what will be the cost?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

HMS Invincible is less vulnerable to missile attack than other smaller less capable ships. Her size enables the installation of many damage control features and the use of specific design criteria which minimise the effects of battle damage, in the unlikely event that this should occur. Furthermore, it must be remembered that this ship will operate with other ships of the Royal Australian Navy as part of an integrated group exploiting the principle of concentration of force. Such a group's anti-ship missile defences are provided by a wide range of weapons and tactics which are available to the group, for example, anti-aircraft missile and gun systems, electronic counter measures, and active and passive deception techniques. The effectiveness of these measures is enhanced because they can be employed in a co-ordinated fashion by the group commander using the excellent facilities available in Invincible.

Whilst it remains true that no single system exists which can defeat a large number of missiles arriving at a ship simultaneously, it should be understood that the defence of a group of ships does not rely on the effectiveness of one single system, but rather on the cumulative effect of a number of systems. Successful anti-ship missile defence rests with the effective employment of supporting aircraft and ships, ship board electronic counter measures and decoy systems, area defence surface to air missile systems, and self defence gun and missile systems, to firstly attempt to destroy the launch platform or confuse its targeting picture and then engage or decoy any missiles which may be fired. It is relevant that the Exocet missile referred to in answer to Question on Notice No. 3179 (Hansard, page 1425 of 19 September 1980) must be fired from ranges well within the range of the Harpoon surface to surface missile fitted in RAN FFGs, and it would be most unlikely that any attacking craft could ever achieve a firing position. Additionally, the level of co-ordination required for a number of units to achieve a simultaneous salvo attack is extremely difficult even when unopposed. In the face of opposition it is next to impossible. It is relevant that the much vaunted ability of missile firing patrol boats is of limited application in our area because of their relatively short range, susceptibility to weather and extreme vulnerability to air attack. The difficulties I have outlined above, apply to those navies which do have craft with the potential to fire missiles in salvos.

Equally, provided the range of area and self defence measures discussed above is available, it cannot be said that a determined missile attack from sea or air would sink Invincible if she were armed to the extent of Government announcements so far.

The question of fitting Phalanx Close-in Weapon Systems is being examined in the context of the special study into the question of whether or not to retain the Sea Dart area air defence missile system, which was announced in my statement concerning the purchase of HMS Invincible. Decisions relating to the possible enhancement of Invincible's existing air defence capability will be taken after consideration of the results of this study.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1982 (Hansard, page 700), Senator Hill asked me a question, without notice, concerning industrial research and development in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Science and Technology has supplied the following additional advice to the answer I gave the honourable senator on that occasion:

The latest figures available as a basis for comparisons (1978-79) show that, while Australia may be considered among the medium level research and development performers of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, private business enterprises and public sector businesses (for example utilities) performed only 23 per cent of the total value of research and development in Australia. The same joint category of businesses in other OECD countries generally performed between 45 per cent and 75 per cent of national research and development.

This comparatively low level of proportionate performance of research and development by business enterprises in Australia is of concern to the Government. In recognition of this, and to induce greater research and development by private industry, the Government has:

increased the financial incentives provided through the Industrial Research and Development Incentive scheme to industry to undertake research and development both as it affects the individual company and at the aggregate level;

encouraged Government departments and instrumentalities, including Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, to stimulate more industrial research and development through establishment of closer links with industry and through adoption of a policy of contracting out wherever practicable;

strengthened and developed its procurement and 'offset' policies to encourage the introduction into and development within Australia of high technology with associated industrial research and development; and

promoted debate on the need for and effect of technological change and, by implication, industrial research and development through establishment of a Technological Change Committee to the Australian Science and Technology Council .

The effect of these positive measures may be influenced by Government decisions taken in the light of the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission following its inquiries into 'Certain Budgetary Assistance to Industry' and 'Approaches to General Reductions in Protection'. Clearly, it would be improper for me to speculate on these influences at this time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1982 (Hansard, page 699), Senator Watson asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Transport a question without notice which enquired as to the Minister's satisfaction at the controls exercised over the light aircraft and commuter airline industries in view of the reported increase in the number of accidents during the first two months of 1982.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There were 46 general aviation aircraft accidents-including commuters-in the first two months of 1982. Although this was five more accidents than occurred in the first two months of 1981 it was only one more than the figure for the same two months averaged over the preceding three years.

This situation supports the view that little reliance should be placed upon relatively low accident numbers representing short time periods. The doctrine of regression to the mean is almost certain to operate.

The much more significant statistical information is that, between 1971 and 1980, the number of general aviation accidents per 100,000 hours flown in this country reduced steadily from 21.93 to 14.09. Not all general aviation activities shared equally in this improvement. Private and business flying, particularly, did not match the other areas but I believe the recent introduction of the biennial flight review will go a long way towards remedying that situation.
However, I believe the overall steady improvement reflects the exercise of adequate and proper safety controls by my Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1023), Senator Jessop asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, although the question may overlap other portfolios. Is it a fact that the New South Wales power crisis, which has been aggravated by industrial disputation, has interfered with Australia's overseas and interstate trade? I ask whether the Minister recalls that section 51 of the Commonwealth Constitution states:
'The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:
(i) Trade and commerce with other countries, and among the States:'

Does the Minister agree that this situation in New South Wales is interfering with interstate and overseas trade? It appears that the Constitution provides for the Commonwealth to make laws in this sort of emergency to deal with unions under a Federal jurisdiction to ensure that adequate maintenance is carried out at these power stations.
I referred legal aspects of the question to the Attorney-General.
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government is aware of the existence of a power under section 51 (i) of the Constitution to make laws with respect to industrial disputes which affect inter-State and foreign trade and commerce. This power is relied upon, for example, in sections 30J and 30K (d), (e) and (f) of the Crimes Act 1914 and section 82 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904. The fact that power from New South Wales power stations is used for the purposes of inter-State and foreign trade and commerce does not in itself result in the Parliament having power to make laws with respect to the maintenance of generators at those stations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1092), Senator McLaren asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Department of National Development and Energy had any discussions or negotiations with the Electricity Trust of South Australia and CSR Ltd in respect of brown coal reserves at Sedan near Mannum in South Australia? If so, what is the extent and quality of the reserves? When is it anticipated that a power station will be constructed, and at what cost? Finally, has he had any request from the South Australian Government for financial assistance to construct the power station? If so, what amount was sought?
The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

(1) The Department of National Development and Energy has had no discussions or negotiations with the Electricity Trust of South Australia and CSR Ltd in respect of low grade coal reserves at Sedan, beyond its normal role of maintaining an awareness of coal reserves and their utilisation.

(2) Reserves are estimated by CSR to be approximately 290 million tonnes. Bulk samples are currently being tested by laboratories in West Germany and the United States of America but the results have not yet been published.

(3) The Electricity Trust of South Australia is investigating coal deposits at various locations including Sedan to determine whether they are suitable as fuel for future power stations. No decision has yet been made as to when a power station using this type of coal will be constructed. Accurate cost estimates are not available but in the course of the recent Commonwealth/State Inquiry into Electricity Generation and the Sharing of Power Resources in Australia (Zeidler Inquiry), the construction cost of a power station using low grade South Australian coal was estimated at $1 000 per kW of installed capacity. On this basis the cost of a 500 MW power station would be $500.
(4) The South Australian Government has not approached the Federal Government for any financial assistance to construct a power station using Sedan coal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 February 1982 (Hansard, page 78) asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question without notice.

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and it refers to public telephones. I preface it by saying that I note from a letter I received a couple of years ago from Telecom Australia that it anticipated income of some $1,100 from each public telephone before a new one was installed. Of course I realise that that figure may now be somewhat higher. Now that Telecom has decided to increase public telephone calls to 20 cents, will this mean that Telecom will re-examine the number of public telephones that are installed and consequently install many more so that those people who are without a private telephone will have a public telephone more easily available to them?

Will Telecom convert most telephones to take 50 cent pieces as well as 20 cent pieces so that people who make subscriber trunk dialling calls, long distance calls, will not get arm ache from putting the 20 cent pieces in?

Finally, will Telecom convert as many public telephones as possible to the international subscriber dialling system so that people without that service available to them at home will have it available at public telephones?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:-

As background to the honourable senator's questions, Telcom advises that the loss on the public telephone service in the 1980-81 was about $43.3m or the equivalent of over $1.350 per public telephone in service at the end of that year.

The figure of $1,100 quoted by the honourable senator was assessed some years ago and has the average annual revenue used as a guide in determining whether a public telephone should be installed at a particular location. Clearly, in the light of the above loss figure, $1,100 is insufficient to offset the network costs of handling calls from the unit plus the maintenance and continuing running costs of clearing, cleaning and lighting the unit itself. The figure of $1,100 is therefore being re-assessed in view of cost increases to Telecom since it was first established.

Turning to the honourable senator's specific queries, the recent increase in the public telephone fee was designed to help offset the high loss being incurred on the public telephone service rather than to provide additional public telephones which will continue to be installed in particular locations on the basis of expected revenue and community needs.

There are currently some 26,000 of the new type green public telephones in service. Whilst similar in appearance, there are two types-the CT3 and the CT3 (I)-and, because of the technical and cost considerations, the earlier CT3 units (some 20,000) will be conveted to 20c operation only. Of the remaining 6, 000 CT3 (I) units, 2,500 will be converted to 20/50c operation in 1982-83 at a relatively low cost. Also, 2,000 new type public telephones will be installed in 1982-83 and these will have 20/50c operation.

The 20/50c units will be available in areas with a high incidence of STD and/ or ISD usage. Telecom will convert as many public telephones to ISD as is practicable bearing in mind particular local exchange equipment restrictions an the need for such a service. It will also give consideration to 'out of area' provision of ISD public telephone facilities in areas where the local exhange equipment is not suitable for ISD and where subscriber requirements justify such action, for example, where there is a high level of overseas calls being booked through operators from public telephones.
